It's not even bad enough to be good. It's pure junk food that will distract your senses for a split second and encourage you to perhaps buy an over-priced bowl of popcorn. Amazingly bad. My friend had to tell me the premise "Sharon Stone invented a facial product that will destroy your face if you stop using it." I had to ask him to repeat it. No way did they spend $85 million dollars to base a movie on that premise. No chance. That's simply obscene. It's stupid. It's beyond base. But yes. Now, did the producers pick three writers randomly off the L.A. Metro and force them to decide on the premise before the next stop? What was their first choice? "Act 1: Catwoman gets feline leukemia and must save herself by traveling into the sun for radiation treatment..." This is a classic case of giving a project too much money and allowing utter amateurs to get behind and in front of the camera. Every scene was framed and executed with the absolute minimum of forethought. It was as though this had no development time. But I expect it had too much development time. Everyone said their piece, hundreds of opinions were sorted through and lastly, no one was satisfied. When the script started to suffer they hired another writer to help. Then the lawsuits started. So they split the credit but no one wanted or was able to IMPROVE THE SCRIPT. I guarantee the writers lost jobs because of this junk. The producer is probably delivering mail in Glendale. With $85 million dollars they made a movie that is not watchable except in the most vegetative state. It is distracting like chicken mcnuggets. You eat one and forget you ate it. Ten minutes later you wish you had eaten a carrot. A simple carrot. Or, out of respect for catwoman, a sardine.

"I'm a woman; I'm used to doing all kinds of things I don't wanna do." Although Sharon Stone's prancing villain speaks these ironic words, perhaps actress Halle Berry should have. This is an awful movie loaded with unintentional hilarity.Berry plays Patience Philips, a different kind of comic book loser than we're used to. Meek, humble, totally gorgeous and scared of her own shadow, Philips is lured to her apartment ledge to save a cat. She's rescued by gallant cop who sees instant potential in this distressed damsel – perhaps it's her supermodel appearance.Cut to the important stuff: Patience, an underling at a cosmetics corporation headed by Sharon Stone and her husband... distributing non-aging makeup with bad long-term effects... takes a package to the factory and, for no apparent reason, is hunted and killed by goons. Now her life, or um, death changes everything. Revived by the same feline that'd lured her to the edge, Patience becomes Catwoman: a lithe vixen climbing walls and leaping around at will. Whenever Berry provides her feline traits – like hissing in the face of her adversaries or sensuously purring dialog – the film goes from vapid to pure camp cinema.In fact this entire adaptation of the Batman heroine, with horrendously corny dialog and limp action sequences pumped by a techno/R&B soundtrack, constantly reminds us we're not supposed to laugh. Making this an iconic howler the likes of SHOWGIRLS and any other guilty pleasure.For More Reviews: www.cultfilmfreaks.com

A mild-mannered lady, Patience (Halle Barry), works for a cosmetics company. She is unaware that they folks who own the company are evil...and are making cosmetics that turn women into weirdo mutants. They know it and they're prepared to sell it anyway (does this make ANY sense at all?!). But when Patience accidentally learns the secret, she's killed and brought back to life by a cat. Then, amazingly, she develops cat-like skills and decides to expose the cosmetics company for what it is."Catwoman" is not as bad as its reputation suggests...but it's still a bad movie in many ways. The dialog is often rather stupid, the story is bizarre and the film is a great example of style over substance. The script is stupid and doesn't make a lot of sense--nor does it make sense when Catwoman instantly believes everything her evil boss, Laurel (Sharon Stone), tells her. So, the director tried to hide these and many other deficits by having loud and abrasive music, big stunts and lots of weird artsy moments. Overall, I'd say that the film is notorious mostly because it was so expensive and glitzy and yet so hollow and ridiculous. It also has a story line that simply wasn't going to work no matter how they tried to disguise it.

This is my favorite comic book movie of all time. Apart from The Fantastic Four, it's the only one that gave me the same kind of square, giddy delight comics themselves used to, when I was young enough to be steeped in them, and before they became "graphic novels" and gained academic approval. It also recalled the kindred simple pleasures of the early James Bond films. More than any other picturization of a superhero, and especially in contrast to the Spider-Man series, Catwoman follows through on its central fantasy: to suddenly have superpowers and to find out how to use them. The movie shows you how it would feel to be a superhero, and leads you to imagine yourself as one. But it's only for people who want to surrender to that fantasy, not those who are set on holding back and feeling superior to it. In other words, it's for kids, not people trying to be grown-ups. But apparently many former children who haven't quite managed to put away childish things have cast off the only ones that mattered; and so they rejected this movie en masse. But I was content to let it bear me whither it would, and this it was able to do easily, since it has a spry, catlike grace of its own, and a rich, posterlike beauty besides. Not to overlook Halle Berry: although she did some dissing of the movie after the fact, by the evidence on screen she was fully immersed in the fantasy, and fully enjoying it. Cultural forecasts are always risky, but I predict that in twenty years' time, when some of the people who first experienced this movie when they were too young to resist it begin writing about movies, Catwoman will acquire a reputation more in accord with its deserts.

Everyone is saying that Catwoman is by far the worst movie of the summer; this movie is not that bad you guys. I have seen Gili and went into watching Catwoman with the feeling that it would be another disappointment equivalent to Gili. Actually, I was intrigued by the story and feel that the only thing the movie needed more work on were the computer graphics (by far the worst I've seen). Halle Berry is breath-takingly beautiful and she made the movie. Sharon Stone's character was underdeveloped and lacked the characteristics of a typical villain (pure human abilities). When watching the two fight your left wondering, "Is this it?" Catwoman is worth watching because of the performance given by Halle Berry, she is by far the best catwoman to date.

Halle Berry is a shy, declasse office worker. She's ill-groomed. Everyone walks all over her, although she works hard. Then, with a wave of a magic wand, she becomes a cat woman. In this persona, she fights the villainous Sharon Stone and her mob of goons, as well as assorted other miscreants like jewelry-store burglars and people who hold loud parties next door.You might think that the most interesting thing about the movie -- that is, if a small minus number is more interesting than a large minus number -- is her conflict with the forces arrayed against law and order. Law and order, appropriately enough, comes packed in the form of Benjamin Bratt. But, no! You'd be wrong.The most interesting thing about the movie -- or the least uninteresting, depending on your metric -- is Halle Berry's Catwoman disguise. First of all, it doesn't disguise much of this cutie-pie's figure, which is why I gave it two stars instead of only one.The director, Pitof, has only a single name because, as far as it's possible to judge, he hasn't earned a second. He's given the juicy Berry a black leather jump suit with a very low top in front and no back at all. If it weren't for that costume, Pitof wouldn't even have ONE name. Oh -- and he gave her what I assume is a kind of feline walk, which most of us would call slinky. She thrusts her hips forward, lowers her face, glowers up at the target through her perfunctory mask, and walks by placing one foot directly in front of the other, like a runway model.That's enough. The pattern is surely exhausted by now. I'm beginning to loathe the original "Superman" which started this whole business of comic-strip heroes and their sequelae. What is Spider-Man up to now? Number four? Enough is enough.

reviews.review_title: Don't bother - stick with the comic book
reviews.content: I have never rated a movie as awful but it was easy to do so with this one. Halle Berry is a beautiful and talented actress but in this movie looked and acted like a cardboard cut-out. What could have been a funny movie filled with campy humor turned out to be a meaningless sequence of events that neither told a story or developed a character. Even the special effects were not realistic or visually appealing. The real true star of the film was the cat who saved Halle Berry's character from death. This beautiful feline (the real cat) stole every scene it was in. If you start with a fantasy as the premise for a film be sure you support the fantasy and try to tell the audience a story, which is entertaining. Save your money there are a lot of great films available, unfortunately, this isn't one.

reviews.review_title: "The best Catwoman is Julie Newmar, Lee Meriwther or Eartha Kitt." Or Michelle Pfeiffer. Or even Adrienne Barbeau.
reviews.content: The problem with "Catwoman" isn't so much that this isn't the one from the Batworld (the city it's set in is never named, but it's not likely to be Gotham City), but that it commits the dual offence of spitting in the face of buffs while providing hardly anything for newcomers. With writers including the team of John Brancato and Michael Ferris (whose disappointing CV already includes "The Net," "Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines" and the equally dreary TV series "The Others") and direction by Pitof - whose name, as Jasper Carrott once put it, is one letter away from the truth - this origins movie even achieves the seemingly impossible in making Halle Berry unsexy. I blame that horrible costume.Our heroine's friend Alex Borstein has "comic relief" stamped all over her face, but the whole movie has the worst kind of campy vibe about it - impossible to take seriously, but done in such a straight-faced way that it's equally impossible to laugh at it. Badly-done camp isn't the only way it's reminiscent of earlier "Batman" efforts - the plot point of face cream that has a drastic effect on women comes from the first Tim Burton movie (though Beau-line isn't as deadly as Smylex), and no one can think of Catwoman without thinking of "Batman Returns," although Halle Berry isn't half as effective as Michelle Pfeiffer was. Though it has to be said that Michelle had much better material on her side, so you can't blame Halle for the end result.But you can blame her for not being that convincing as Catwoman, you can blame Sharon Stone and Lambert Wilson for being useless villains (Wilson's acting as the head of the cosmetics firm our heroine works at is excruciating), and you can blame the fight scenes for being constantly undercut by out-of-place songs, in addition to not being terribly exciting to begin with (Klaus Badelt's score is another minus). You can also blame the bad effects, the draggy pace, the silly plot turns (about the only thing she doesn't do after she gets her cat powers is cough up a hairball)... "Catwoman" would make "Daredevil" look like a masterpiece if it weren't for such a thing being impossible. Special lament to Frances Conroy for slumming it here between episodes of "Six Feet Under."Halle and Sharon notwithstanding, it's Kim Smith as the company's new model who sums up "Catwoman" in one of her two lines of dialogue (both to Wilson) - sitting in the audience of a ballet, she gives new meaning to the expression "Out of the mouths of babes" by saying "I think this is a total waste of time." Shortly afterwards she walks out of both the ballet and the movie; many would be wise to follow her lead.

reviews.review_title: My cat's breath smells like cat food...
reviews.content: You know the old saying, "Do not change horses mid-race", well I think that heavily applies to this film. I think the biggest hurdle that most of us had to overcome in this film was that Catwoman was not Michelle Pfeiffer. Most of us are still a generation of Batman Returns fans, as well as Tim Burton's darkness, and Halle just couldn't fit those shoes. Pfeiffer gave us this unbridled performance as this tormented woman who is given a rebirth by some cats, while Berry continually felt as if she was just going through the motions in order to try to be cooler than Pfeiffer was. You could see the competition going on in the film, and it hurt the overall story and characters. I will agree, this film had a very weak plot, but with the right person behind the mask of Catwoman, this could have been a decent film. Sadly, Berry just didn't put the force into it that I felt Pfeiffer did. There wasn't enough passion in the eyes, just this uncanny ability to act like a cat. Catwoman was more than "just a cat", she was this troubled soul that had to deal with both the good side of her actions as well as the devilish. That is what never came through with Berry.Outside of the complete miscast of Halle Berry, there were a couple other points that I just felt cheated after watching the film. The scene where the cat breaths on Halle was too eerily like Ralph Wiggum's "My cat's breath smells like cat food" moment. I kept waiting to hear that whenever possible. It would have granted this film one additional star more. Sadly, we had to live with what was in this film, and not what wasn't. What was in this film was shoddy acting, a very flimsy script, and scenario after scenario that just didn't seem to work. I realize the Pitof (the director) was trying to show a very feminine film that could be seen as a feminist picture, but to me it just didn't work. All of the sudden this cat brings out what Patience couldn't in the past? Suddenly, with the quick breath of a cat, she could play basketball better than ever, crack a whip, and drive a motorcycle. There was no development here, just plain assumption. I needed more development of this character instead of just this light-speed characterization that lead nowhere.Another element that didn't brood well with me were the villains. Who were they? What was their purpose behind their situations? Without giving us any of this information, we can only assume that they really weren't evil and that perhaps Catwoman was caught up in this big misunderstanding? I know that is far fetched, but honestly Sharon Stone and Lambert Wilson were not that sinister. Sure, every company that you work for has that boss that is not going to treat you with the greatest of respect, but does that make him the super-villain? Then you have Sharon Stone with this pathetic super power that works and doesn't work half the time. I just didn't care at this point what Catwoman was to do to stop the corporation. It was this huge dilemma that I could have solved quickly by perhaps incorporating something about the Umbrella Corporation and a tie into Resident Evil 3. Anything could have been better than what Pitof presented here.The themes were also as jumbled as a child's playroom. Scattered throughout this picture you had different themes that never quite tied into the big solution. There were the feminist issues, the skin care/growing old is "ok" theme, the dual personalities and to live life to the fullest moments, and then there was the pro-self sidesteps that just never took us anywhere. It was like bobbing for themes in this mess. Nearly every five minutes, Pitof would present to us either a new theme or an older one that should have been dropped, but instead found itself back in the picture. It became increasingly clear with these scattered themes why Berry couldn't quite capture her character. There were supposed to be several layers to her character, but instead with all the layers everywhere except on Berry, it became increasingly more difficult to uncover. This caused both problems for the film itself as well as for the audience forced to sit through this mess. I mean who wants to visit a place of rest and have to clean up before being able to enjoy it. Not me, and that is how I felt with this film. I felt that it was this huge mess that Pitof created and wanted me to clean up. It was pathetic.Overall, I was not happy with this film. Either Pfeiffer should have been in it or it should have been shelved. With the growing business behind superheroes in today's cinema, Hollywood studios will have to pick and choose which ones they think will be big. You cannot release them all, and it proves with the attempt to capitalize on this small hero that ultimately failed. I hate to go with the rest of the critics with this one, but I just did not enjoy the final result. The costume, the style, the themes, and the acting all put a hinder on this film that was unrepairable from the beginning. This is a perfect example of a film that should have been scrapped from the beginning instead of rushed to theaters. Procrastination does not pay off in the long run!Grade: * out of *****

For all of you guys interested in seeing Halle Berry in skin-tight leather, then this flick will at least achieve that. Now that I think about it, that's probably about all it does.We have the same borrowed Marvel story about how an ordinary woman becomes superhuman. This is given a little more development though, showing us Egyptian roots to cats as sacred beings and protectors. This hocus pocus background meets up with a talented and zany Berry (also carefully portrayed as weak). The transformed "Catwoman" seeks revenge against her murdering employers.We see way too much CG in this film, to the point that I felt entire scenes were generated by computer and didn't look very passable. *SPOILER* As a way of doing a big "showdown" between Catwoman and some formidable foe, the director took a new-age spin of pinning superwoman versus superwoman. An aging Sharon Stone plays a villain whose skin is as hard as iron and doesn't transmit pain. She and the feline engage in a pretty hokey/lame battle. This film carries several head shakes and silly laughs. 2/10

While I think the rating of 3.5/10 is a little too harsh, 'Catwoman' is far from the best superhero movies. The main problem about it is that everything is too over the top and the script lacks depth. Starting from the inconsistent camera-work, the acting, the CGI...it's all overdone. The CGI is so overdone that it looks fake. The characters are too sketchy and the story loses focus. Ironically the ending is very 'Spiderman' like. Halle Berry looks extremely sexy in that small tight leather suit but she really exaggerates the sexy catness too much. Think of Michelle Pfeiffer's Catwoman in Burton's 'Batman Returns' and how she fit the part so naturally. Ms. Berry emphasizes on the seduction a little too much. But it would be wrong to deny that she was very pleasing to look at. As Patience she seems a little lost. Sharon Stone's Laurel Hedare is the caricature villain but she too looked quite alluring. Benjamin Bratt is the typical boyfriend. Now Frances Conroy is another actress who's also unintentionally funny. Alex Borstein acts very natural. While 'Catwoman' is very flawed, I wouldn't say it's terrible. It's a disappointing film but not disastrous and one should just see it with an open mind. The action scenes are quite alright but for an action film, it's a little too slow-paced. Some scenes were quite entertaining like the contortionists at the opera, the interiors of the Beauty product company and the basketball scene. For a one-time watch, I didn't mind it so much. It's still much better than the Tomb Raider Lara Croft movies.

reviews.review_title: What a Load of Kitty Litter
reviews.content: Out of all the Batman characters to have their own feature length movie, none have been more infamous than one of his greatest foes, Catwoman. Made after years of development hell following the successful albeit controversial Batman Returns, a stand alone Catwoman origin story was brought to the big screen in 2004, with Academy Award winning actress Halle Berry in the title role. Despite the hype, the film was met with scathing reviews and a poor financial performance, and is often considered one of the worst comic book movies of all time, let alone movies in general. After seeing the final result, it sure is one big pile of kitty litter.As a more one off origin story of Catwoman, the film centers on meek designer Patience Phillips, who discovers a conspiracy within the cosmetics company Hedare Beauty that involves their biggest product possibly leading to serious health dilemmas. After being murdered by the conspirators, she is revived by Egyptian cats that grant her superhuman cat-like abilities and becomes the crime-fighting crusader Catwoman. While that plot may sound bizarrely fascinating on paper, the movie unfortunately comes off as way too bizarre for its own good. The main fact that the villains in the movie are makeup company owners is ridiculous enough, but their actual motives are even more baffling once you get into the film's poor take on corporate expansion. It's really insulting how the movie tries to present this huge theme of female empowerment, yet it comes off as manipulatively sexist, as if the script was made up by a bunch of old men in a boardroom rather than a passionate screenwriter. Then again, the whole movie reeks of sexual overtones that you can't take it that seriously.A good example would have to be Catwoman's outfit, which looks so skimpy and unintentionally degrading that Patience comes off more as a gimp than an actual superhero. Also, given that the film's director was formerly a visual effects artist, one can understand a lot of gritty backdrops and computer effects throughout, including some portions of a computer generated Catwoman for hard to reach places. The sets do look pretty grim and disturbing from time to time, but the visual effects actually detract from their frightening look and age the film like rancid cat milk. That joke may have been bad, but it's still better than any of the tired cat puns this film's script coughs up. However, the greatest crime the film committed overall might have to be the editing. A lot of the sequences have so many cuts per second, and it becomes so hard to comprehend what is happening on screen, be it an action scene or a casual conversation. It feels like the filmmakers couldn't trust their audience to sit still for one whole minute that they desperately wanted to jump around with one shot after another.If there is one true saving grace throughout the whole movie, it would have to be Halle Berry performing her damndest as Patience/Catwoman. Granted, her hoaky acting does explain why she received a Razzie, but she is definitely the most convincing in terms of bringing this oddball woman to life through the weak dialogue and jumbled narrative. She also does a good job transitioning from neurotically quiet mess to cat conniving crusader, even if some of her scenes can come off as a little too corny. As for the rest of the cast, Benjamin Bratt is hammily charismatic as detective Tom Lone, Alex Borstein is annoying as Patience's comical friend Sally, and Sharon Stone and Lambert Wilson might have the most boring roles in the whole movie: the Hedares. While seemingly subtly sly at first, they barely have much going on outside of being the one note baddies, and let's just their performances are not the least believable in the slightest. It really is saying something when a movie about a feline-esque superheroine has a less fascinating cast than it should.Catwoman has seen better days in a lot of Batman accompanied properties, but it seems like that little kitty couldn't quite land on her own feet. After almost twenty years, Halle Berry's Catwoman venture still stands as one of the most laughable embarrassments of an ambitious experiment gone horribly wrong. Maybe one day, the cunning feline will get her chance to truly shine once more standing alone, but there's a reason why even die hard comic book fans don't like to look back on stuff like this. At least now we can remember Halle Berry as the ultimate dual Oscar and Razzie owner?

reviews.review_title: A lamentable production in every way. Spend 104 mins of your life doing something more positive!
reviews.content: Finally got around to watching Catwoman today, not that it was on my "must-see" list, but it was a rainy Saturday afternoon, and it was showing on TV in the correct widescreen format, and after hearing such negative reports I thought it couldn't be that bad surely? So I took the plunge.Everything you've heard is true.I wasted 104 minutes of my life on a really lamentable production, and despite the lacklustre FX and neurotic editing, I lay the blame fair and square at the feet of French director Pitof. Trust me, I have high regard for French directors and French cinema, but this incompetent imbecile shouldn't be allowed anywhere near a director's chair again. Does this idiot have any concept of pacing, characterisation, drama, even within the fantasy realm? It's true I'm not an out and out comic book fan, but I did enjoy the Spiderman films and the first hour of the Hulk.This however is just dire, dire, dire, from start to finish. Halle Berry, Benjamin Bratt, I've seen you do so much better, I hope your paycheques paid a few bills.

reviews.review_title: I really don't see why most people hate this movie...
reviews.content: For years I have wondered why this movie gets such bar reviews everywhere, I remember I watched it 3 or 4 times in the cinema when it came out and I honestly like to watch it over and over again to this day. I mean what did you all expect? Yeah, they could've made it serious like the new Batman movies and it would've probably been even better that way, but they decided to make it more fun and cheesy like this and it worked out great in my opinion. Halle is one sexy cat, the other characters are likable, the story isn't anything out of it's world, but it certainly ain't boring, come on now... I really like the soundtrack, visuals (Remember that club with all the lights?) and the action scenes are pretty mighty. I would feel very cool if I could do those things, and isn't that the point of action movies? The special effects are veeery well done, they really surprise me to this day... I like the main character Patience a lot, she is a little like me, simple, shy and doesn't really express herself through clothing and a sexy style, but rather through her personality and talents. But her beauty still does shine through and the movie teaches us that we do have to let go sometimes and not be our usual selves to be even more attractive. We need to have some fun! No one is just one-sided! Even the movie itself has kind of earned that title, not very respected and loved in general, but there are people like me who find it to me damn good and that's all that matters! Go watch this movie and appreciate it for what it is and not for what you expected it to be, I myself really like it!

Usually, when you watch a movie with a bad reputation, you're pleasantly surprised. Or else, that means the movie is VERY bad (Judge Dredd, for example). Don't worry, unlike IMDb's infame-ous troll (I won't say his name but his initials are SV), I won't try to pretend Catwoman is the best superhero movie on the market. That would be a lie. But at least, it's watchable. I found myself watching it from the beginning to the end without feeling bored, despite the many plot holes and continuity errors.So, what are Catwoman good parts? 1-The opening credits, with clippings and articles about cats and the previous Catwomen (I don't think Pitof directed it, since there's a similar scene in the movie which is poorly edited). 2-There are a few beautiful shots: the very first scene, an underwater shot of Patience, alas spoiled by a stupid voice-over; or the two shots of Catwoman in front of the moon. 3-The first Catwoman costume. The one she's wearing during the jewelry's heist. How come they thought the atrocious second costume was better? 4-Halle Berry. Like Helen Slater for Supergirl, Halle was blamed for Catwoman's failure while she was the only actress who took the project seriously and gave us a convincing acting, both as Patience and as Catwoman. She did the best she could with the script and truly didn't deserved her razzie.The bad parts? 1-Pitof! He's unquestionably the worst director on the market! This man knows nothing about storytelling, using a dozen of shots when one would be sufficient, and sometimes filming everything except what is happening. Most of the fighting scenes are confusing since it's hard to figure what's going on. 2-The CGIs! As someone already noted, the best CGis are on par with Spider-Man's worst. Worst of all, they were used for scenes that would have looked better with trained animals, animatronics, stunt women and wire works. 3-The promotion. First, they pretended Catwoman was a serious movie with a message about female empowerment. When the movie bombed at the US box office but was about to be released in other countries, they said it was an humorous, tongue-in-check movie, not to be taken seriously (And note how Pitof, after telling everyone he had never read anything about the comic's Catwoman, was then pretending he has been a fan of the comic for years!). Unfortunately, Catwoman was none of both, so the spectators were disappointed in both cases. Not to mention the trailers only used the corniest scenes and dialogs of the movie. 4-The main villain. It would have been a great plot twist if Laurel was first shown as a likable allie for Catwoman, while her husband looked like the real villain (according to earlier Sharon's interviews, it seems it was the original intent). Unfortunately, she's immediately revealed as the main villain. Another problem is the villain in a good superhero movie must be a) someone with powers or abilities that made him equal or superior to the main character (Zord, Joker, Selena, Magneto, Green Goblin, Dr Octopus), b) someone smart enough to find the main character's weaknesses and use them to get the upper hand on him (Lex Luthor, Top Dollar); in both case: someone that can be a match for the hero(in). What are Laurel's powers? She can't be wounded. That's all. She get her indestructible ass kicked for about 3 minutes, get the upper hand for a few second, then get her ass kicked again and die. What a looser! I think it would have been better if the writers had made her a former Catwoman gone bad, with the same powers than Patience.All in all, it's a movie that is watchable... on TV! This way, you don't get your guilty pleasure spoiled by the thought that you gave money for seeing this.

Users here laud the comic book faithful Spidermen yet lambast this flick. I did not find any of these blockbusters to have uncrapful stories and characters, but Catwoman's visual styling outmatches its Raimi-directed rival.No, I'm not talking about how "realistic" the CGI is, or any other oxymoronic geek rhetoric; I'm praising the photography and editing and color and metropolis design and, and, well, the great art direction. Add to this the non-dull-Joe-Blow-50s-americana-characters-(witty, sexy) and you have a delicious pulp feature, at least not the "total disaster" other high-minded described.

Though there was never any great public outcry for it, the idea of producing a Catwoman movie had been in one stage of planning or another ever since 1992, when Michelle Pfeiffer memorably brought the character to the big screen in BATMAN RETURNS. I'm not sure why. Certainly Pfieffer's sensual interpretation of the character was one of the few pleasures to be had in that woeful sequel to Tim Burton's equally bleak and depressing original: but even so, Catwoman, in and of herself, is not really all that interesting as a character. Without Batman, there is no point to Catwoman -- just as there would be no point in making a movie about Prof. Moriarty without Sherlock Holmes or about Ernst Blofeld without James Bond. Catwoman's allure -- cheesy sexual fantasies aside -- exists solely as part of the Batman mystique. Even going back to Julie Newmar's purrrfect incarnation of the role in the 60's TV serial, Catwoman never stood out as a criminal mastermind or a colorful adventure figure, but rather as one of Batman's more memorable props, the one criminal who might seduce Batman into being bad, or at least naughty. Like all the other cartoonish villains in the series, Catwoman is a gimmick -- a clever gimmick, in that her black cat imagery is both a counterpart and a contrast to Batman's dark, yet heroic, persona -- but a prop nonetheless. Like the Batmobile or the Utility Belt, she is just another part of the Batman play set. Thus, it is curious that not only does the CATWOMAN movie have no Batman, or even a reference to his existence, but apparently this isn't even the same "catwoman." As played by Halle Berry with a strange sense of desperation, this Catwoman is Patience Phillips, not Selina Kyle. So, even though the character is credited to Batman creator Bob Kane, the film really isn't even a sequel or a spin off of the Batman franchise, making it even more perplexing as to why it exists at all. Unlike her original incarnation, this Catwoman is more than a glorified cat burglar with a cat fetish and a delightfully eccentric sense of style. Patience is murdered and -- for mystical, ancient Egyptian reasons the aren't made a bit clear -- she is instantly reborn with cat-like superpowers. Which probably explains just why the film finally got made; it has more in common with the freshly released SPIDER-MAN than with anything in the Batman universe. Like Spider-Man, Patience finds herself with a batch of superhuman skills; unlike Spidey, she can't decide whether to use them for good or evil. That's intriguing. But what shows promise as a quasi-feminist lesson in female self-empowerment, quickly falls back on predictable sexist stereotyping. Instead of becoming a super criminal or super crimefighter, Patience spends most of the movie confused and indecisive. Though it is clear that her newfound skills make her a match to any man, the lame plot pits her against a female adversary, and not a particularly threatening one either. Sharon Stone does the "special guest villainess" bit as Laurel Hedare, a cosmetics titan who wants to flood the market with addictive face cream that ultimately destroys the wearer's face. That's just dumb; the potential lawsuits would negate any profits. And Catwoman ends up being little more than a consumer advocate. Besides, dropping a dime to the FDA would accomplish the same thing as all of Catwoman's rooftop hopping.The film plays like an unsold pilot for a TV series, or worse, a Lifetime TV movie. The director, Pitof (never trust a director with only one name), is addicted to clumsy, excessive editing and the film has the hollow, pretentious feel of one of those artsy TV commercials that tries to sell an attitude, rather than a product. Wearing what must be the most god-awful, ugliest superhero costume ever, Berry looks more slutty than slinky, more trailer-trash tacky than comicbook cool. Compared to Newmar's classic leather jump suit (less skin, more style), Berry looks like a parody of a low rent hooker. But, at least, she tries to give a performance which is preferable to when the character is taken over by the CGI guys; it is always painfully obvious when Catwoman switches from being human to being cartoon, the latter never looking real or even surreal, just fake.CATWOMAN is one of those projects that gets kicked around so much and by so many over the years that by the time it gets to the screen it is clearly damaged goods. Yet, it's hard to be forgiving; despite its pedigree (pre-sold concept, Oscar-winning star and all the time, money and talent that Hollywood can afford to waste), CATWOMAN ends up being just a disagreeable alley cat, a stray that has lived one too many lives.

So while the plot wasn't the best, it wasn't awful. I thought Halle was as good as could be expected from a B-rated script, and she looked gorgeous. I don't think it's anywhere near the worst movie to be rated, so I am surprised by the votes that this has received. I think there are things that could be been better (supporting cast, Ben Bratt taking his shirt off more, a more believable evil plot than cosmetics) but for what I paid, it was fun and campy. I think that for the camp value alone of Sharon Stone, this should be seen. Also, I loved Mo Collins - she was the perfect best friend for this movie!

This is beyond what we need right now and forever. Listen to what's being said and what's being shown on the screen and you'll understand. Soundtrack is *chef's kiss*...cinematography is *my kiss*. Let the oversaturated colors hydrate your eyeballs you creep. Remember when she went in between the jail cell bars, that was so believable. This film is criminally underrated. It's phenomenally well shot with an incredible score and one of the funnest storylines of the ages. Halle berry is as hot as can be, despite that tragic hair cut.It's an of-it's-time superhero movie to rival the likes of modern-day Marvel bull crap. Why don't more people rave about this film? It's a feminist masterpiece, an action-packed adventure, a sultry romance, and a testament to true friendship.From gravity-defying basketball games to Egyptian mythology, this film is a ten out of ten.The only problem with this movie? I wanted more. (And that haircut)

reviews.review_title: Every bit as bad as everybody claims it is
reviews.content: "Catwoman" is one of those movies that you actually watch with a couple of friends and a lot of beer, just to laugh about how bad it is. At least, that was the intention. Unfortunately, while "Catwoman" is bad, it's no so bad that it actually becomes funny again. Instead, it's the incredibly boring, lame, and predictable kind of "bad".This is one of those rare movies where nothing seems to work. First of all, the plot is awful. It's silly beyond belief, lacks any kind of tension, and is so predictable that you can pretty much guess it all after having seen the first five minutes of the movie.Next, there just aren't any good action sequences. Granted, there are a couple of sequences in which Halle Berry runs around in a silly leather costume (or should that be "lack of costume"?) and does some supposedly sexy stuff with a whip, but with no memorable villains or situations to speak of, the most likely reaction these scenes will invoke is tedium.Furthermore, I often found this movie quite embarrassing. Halle Berry's transformation from super-shy nobody to scantily clad feline, and her subsequent flirting with Benjamin Bratt are supposedly meant to be sexy and erotic, but everything is so obvious, lame, poorly acted, and unconvincing that watching all of it becomes a chore.Finally, there's just nothing else the movie has going for it, from the soundtrack that consists mainly of girly R&B, which is unlikely to appeal to super hero movie fans (or anybody above the age of 14 for that matter), to the overuse of barely competent CGI.I've once heard that cats sleep about eighty percent of their lives. If Berry had done the same in this movie, it couldn't possibly have been any more boring than it is now.* out of *****

reviews.review_title: This Film is Better Than Most Critics Gave It But Not great
reviews.content: CATWOMAN or Patience who is her new alter ego in this version has a decent storyline, better than some other recent films I have seen. It is not a fair comparison given between this version Ms. Berry does versus Michelle Pfeiffer, Eartha Kitt, or the others. She does it different & is painted as a different kitten.Halle Berry would have been better suited if she had been given more acting in the way of scripting. What she gets she brings out well but the problem she is lack of scripting she needs to bring her talents out. She does not get enough to do & Halle is capable of so much more.Computerization of special effects is ruining a lot of newer films and it gets hokey in this one. Why is it that in some films, computer effects can be made to look real & in others, it isn't? Sometimes I think the film makers are playing to a video game audience in live action films. That doesn't work for me.Sharon Stone as an evil femme fatal gets a gold star for her performance in this. She gets more script to work with in her role & it shows as she steals the acting in this film. Even her evil husband is totally upstaged. Only problem with Sharon is the poorly staged final battle with Catwoman where the woeful staging makes the battle laughable though the barbs her and Catwoman throw back & forth during the battle are not bad at all.This film is worth viewing, & the DVD features a special about all the Catwomen hosted by Eartha Kitt & featuring all of them in interviews. This special is a real bonus. If Halle Berry & I were alone & she had Eartha's sexy voice too, she'd melt my socks!

There have been a lot of bad press and even worse reviews about this movie. I liked it. Why did I like it? I found it to be one of the most unique and visually entertaining movie I have ever seen. Most of the people who are giving this movie bad ratings are people who went into it with bad blood for it, so they looked for anything they could to rip it apart.That had to be the case, because the movie that I saw was amazing. It was NOT Batman & Robin, like a lot of people are saying. It takes a simple concept and does so much with it. The creators of this film do so much with what they are given. The characters, unlike what previous posters have said, are very well developed, and there is much raw emotion displayed, especially between Halle and Benjamin, who fit together in this movie like hand in glove. And Sharon plays the baddest b-word you've ever seen!Over all, this movie is a weird but creative combination between Ready to Wear, Spider-Man 2, Batman Returns, The Matrix, Batman Forever, City of Lost Children, Batman, and The Crow. Everything is satisfying in this film, even the music. I can't describe what a treat this film was, just because it was so unique. My advice is to go see it yourself. You may like it, you may not. But please give this movie a chance. Don't let other people decide for you.

Superheroes have always been the object of a systematic cult in the USA. So sooner or later a woman had to come into the picture and since Supergirl never satisfied anyone, they had to look for someone else, someone a little bit more attractive. And since Spiderman had many long legs and arms blocking the way they had to look somewhere else farther out of the way. They looked in Egypt, they looked in China, they looked in the Middle Ages for an animal connected to women and who was both satanic and in relation with freedom, liberty and freewheeling. That's how the cat came out of the wizard's hat or bonnet. Catwoman was thus saved from the water of the river, which is absolutely accurate, and brought back to life in the human world of the night. She became the queen of the roofs. Then add a dishonest but successful industrialist exploiting women with beauty products that you must definitely not stop if you don't want to develop some strange Karposi syndrome or cancer. Then add his wife, an old belle who has aged faster than necessary and who wants to get rid of her husband and put her hands on the golden goose and the bank reserves before he finally realizes he does not need her anymore. And then you have the perfect thriller. A little bit of romance between the cop who is supposed to arrest Catwoman and the woman she is supposed to be and you have a heartbreaking story. But the poor Catwoman cannot stay because she is nothing but a living dead. So sadness takes over and she can only exist at night and on the roofs of the city. And there you have some kind of a myth of the cat seen as a symbol of  what have I said already? But what's the meaning of this fable? Nothing is crystal clear in this tale, or if it is clear it is just as clear as black pudding juice at the bottom of a completely opaque wooden bottle. Only a cat can see anything in there. God bless the child.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris Dauphine, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne & University Versailles Saint Quentin en Yvelines

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies ever!
reviews.content: Well, you may be thinking "why this guy is writing a review of this crap after 7 years?"... well, maybe because I finally watched it on TV and asked myself why I lost my precious time seeing it.This is a crap. There's no other perfect word to describe it.After Batman Returns (1993) there's no way to not compare this movie to the awesome and amazing work Tim Burton and Michelle Pfeiffer did about this so amazing comic book character. Also, after Batman Returns, the idea of a movie about Catwoman was in talks for years and Michelle Pfeiffer always turned off the possibility maybe because what was shown in Batman Returns was the necessary to maintain all the secrets and mysteries around the character. If you want to know how to destroy an amazing character just watch Batman Returns and then Catwoman and you will know perfectly what I'm talking about. Hale Barry did a terrible choice that just jeopardized her career after an Oscar wining. Sharon Stone... pff... well, she's in a constant decay.Really... I have no words to express how horrible this one is.

reviews.review_title: Is this really as bad as it is made out to be?
reviews.content: I watched this because I was curious to know whether it was really as bad as it was made out be. At the end, I found myself puzzled. Sure, it's not the greatest ever - there are obvious problems with plotting and characterisation, and Catwoman's outfit is clearly absurd. But, I wasn't bored by it - in fact I quite enjoyed it. If people really think that this is one of the worst movies ever, then all I can say is that they have been fortunate enough to avoid seeing a lot of really bad movies. Over the years, I have seen some excruciatingly bad films, but this isn't one of them. In fact it is well above that level. It does not set out to be anything profound. It is simply a lightweight fun movie.

It amazes me that with such a wealth of source material laying out a beloved a complex character, someone is given the power to decide to throw it all away and keep only "cat" and "woman." I've heard the excuse that they didn't want to be tied to the Batman stories, but does that require tossing away everything? Clearly, however, the bad decisions didn't stop with the first, and the horror continues all throughout the movie. The writing is painful and the acting even worse. One can only wonder why Halle Berry is being treated better that Affleck and Lopez, since this bomb surely cost significantly more than its mentor, Gigli.

reviews.review_title: Rapid action sequences make this a cool film. But the heteronormative propaganda was tiresome
reviews.content: I want to start off by saying I've never read the Catwoman comic books, or watched Batman (the show from the 1960s is too goofy for my taste), but I found this movie intriguing. I think Halle Berry is more than just a beautiful face, as she is a talented actress as well. Her character's name is Patience Philips. She's an artist who is employed at a cosmetics company, Hedare Beauty. They're planning to ship a new skin cream, Beau-line, that promises to reverse the effects of aging. During a visit to the R&D laboratory facility, Patience overhears Dr. Ivan Slavicky (Peter Wingfield) telling Laurel Hedare (Sharon Stone), who is the wife of the owner, George Hedare (Lambert Wilson), about the cream's harsh side effects if used for a prolonged amount of time. Laurel's guards spot Patience, chase her, and as she is running through a conduit pipe, she's flushed out of it, subsequently drowning. When she is washed up onshore, an Egyptian Mau cat revives her, turning her into Catwoman. During the day she's polite, soft-spoken, and somewhat of a doormat. But at night she becomes a hardcore, sharp tongued vixen.I thought Sharon Stone was cast perfectly as the villain (or rather villain-ness I should say). Although I enjoyed the movie, I found the romance junk to be annoying. I'm straight and I even get annoyed by the heteronormativity that is so prevalent in the media. It was also sexist at times. I did tell myself okay, this was 2004, but I'm sure even back then, society was more progressive than what was spoken by Patience's coworker and friend, Sally (Alex Borstein). Before Patience even became Catwoman she encounters Detective Tom Lone (Benjamin Bratt), who discovers her out on her apartment ledge. He thinks she's suicidal (she was trying to coax the cat who would end up being the one turning her into Catwoman to come down), so he tries to save her. Afterwards he comes to her job to return something to her that she had dropped as she was rushing off to work. This is when the audience is introduced to Sally, who, must I say, is so pushy in trying to get Patience to go on a date (well, let's be honest, sleep with) Detective Lone. If she was my coworker, she would get on my nerves. Good grief, there's more to life than sex! She definitely wouldn't be a person who I'd be friends with outside of work. She's too intrusive. I also thought the basketball scene was pretty weird. Patience and Detective Lone cross paths again when she goes to an elementary school where he's giving a presentation to a class. They all go out to a basketball court, and thanks to her cat like abilities, Patience runs up a wall, impressing Detective Lone. The two of them play with each other. Based on their one on one game, there was obviously sexual tension. It was bizarre how they were lusting after each other in front of the kids. He was even checking out her butt while she was dribbling! Having kids be in a scene that implied erotic feelings between adults was just wrong. When she's telling Sally about the game, Sally tells her to never beat a man in sports. What kind of bullcrap is that??? I'm sure that line wouldn't be in a movie nowadays, but for the early 2000s it was highly outdated. Once you get past the beginning portion, it's a really cool film. I loved the action sequences. Even for people who aren't superhero fans, this movie is still enjoyable.

Talk about a love hate relationship when it comes to the reviews!
I saw this movie a few odd years after it came out, and I've seen it a few times after that. And sure, the older I got the more things I could point out was wrong with the film. Yet I wouldn't change the rating, because at the end of the day the movie is entertaining and definitely fun to watch.
It's a pity that there are so many hate comments and 1/10 ratings. It sure as hell isn't that bad.
I'll give it to you, it isn't up there with Batman and those DC classics, but it wasn't meant to be compared to those movies! It even says so in the beginning!
It's not CATWOMAN per say, it's BASED OFF OF catwoman. It's a unique version of the story. Interpreted in a different way from the comics.
So there! I had my point made. Hate all you, want it's still an decent movie.
I'd give it a 6/10 maybe even a 7/10. But I'm posting a 10/10 just to up the ratings a smidge higher. It deserves it.

This movie was one the critics totally blew on. They focused do hard on the fact that this movie didn't have the "Batman" theme in it. This is why I do not think they saw the movie before commenting. If they had seen it they would have seen the beginning where it gave a little history of Catwomen. Plus they would have seen how well acted this movie was. The drama, the superb action and the super comedy in the right places were things that made this an extremely entertaining movie. And isn't that what movies are supposed to be! I think we need more people to criticize the critics so that they will actually watch movies for entertainment not for what they think they should be. I loved this movie and saw it 4 times opening weekend and now have it on DVD.

Catwoman is not a film that is out to change the world or send any kind of a message. I was expecting a HORRIBLE film when I went to see this based on the reviews I have read on IMDb but I was pleasantly surprised. Halle Berry makes a fantastic Catwoman. No not as good as Michelle Pffiefer but good nonetheless. Benjamin Bratt and Halle have a fun chemistry. The weak point in this film is in my opinion the villain or lack there of. Sharon Stone is simply not good in this and she brings the movie down. So yes Sharon sucks but stop the Halle bashing as she does just fine in her role. They should have created a more dynamic more threatening villain than a superficial cosmetics diva whose hubby is stepping out. Could have been better but not "awful".

Talk about a bad career move; this is the pinnacle. Halle Berry is Patience Phillips, a graphic designer working for a cosmetics company with a new cream with botox like properties to reverse aging. The bad news is that it has dangerous side effects. Patience hears a scientist and the company's wife discussing the problem. They have her chased by bad guys and she attempts to escape through a pipe which they seal off. She drowns and washes ashore. A very special Egyptian cat with Jesus like powers restores our heroine back to life, much like Lazarus; come forth Halle. Patience awakens with cat like abilities and begins her quest for truth, justice and the American way. The only redeeming feature of this horrible movie is the black leather body suit worn by Ms. Berry, an off the rack number from dominatrix, Inc.In the pursuit of the evil doers she encounter her boss's wife, who has killed her hubby for cheating on her and frames the kitten with a whip. The villain is the one and only Sharon Stone, who is even worse than Berry. They have a "cat fight;" get it? Catwoman should have been made as a comedy, because it is a bad one, though unintentional. Avoid this Kitty litter like the plague.

Catwoman (2004) * (out of 4) Patience Phillips (Halle Berry) is a rather clumsy and socially awkward woman who is pushed around at her job. One day she witnesses something she shouldn't have and she's murdered. Before long she's brought back to life by a mysterious cat and soon after that she's fighting crime as the title character.CATWOMAN is a film that I've wanted to check out since its original release simply because the reviews were so bad and the film become somewhat notorious for how bad it is. It took me thirteen-years to finally see it and I wish I would have waited another thirteen. There are all sorts of issues with this film but I must start off by saying that Berry is a very beautiful woman and the film does a nice job at showing off her body. With that said, if there was ever a comic book movie screaming for a R-rating this was it.As I said, there are countless problems with this film but I guess we can start with Berry. As the Patience character I thought she was pretty good as she did a good job at playing the sillier side of the character. She was believable in the part but all of this changes when she became Catwoman. There are countless problems with the character itself including some really lame one-liners as well as Berry's delivery. The cat sounds she makes is just embarrassing and I couldn't help but feel bad for Berry because she's the one being embarrassed.Benjamin Bratt is okay in the role of the love interest but Sharon Stone is downright awful in her role. Again, perhaps I shouldn't blame the actress too much because the screenplay is very poor. With that said, there's no doubt that Stone's character is one of the worst villains in film history. Not just comic book film history but film history in general. Her entire scheme is just lame and it doesn't help that you're never threatened by her.The screenplay is full of issues but the direction by Pitof isn't any better. The wannabe fast, MTV-style editing is just lame and I'd argue that there's no one well-directed scene in the picture. Just take a look at the ferris wheel sequence or a really embarrassing basketball game. Two really awful scenes but there are more scattered throughout. CATWOMAN is a pretty darn embarrassing movie all around.

Though I must agree that not many people know the Catwoman story it wasn't an absolutely horrible film. I think that the film without question is flawed and never clarifies that this Catwoman is not the well-known Batman Catwoman (Selina Kyle). I do feel that Halle Berry did a beautiful job (much better than that of Michelle Pfiefer in Burton's far from decent film)portraying the sassy feline. And for the record, there is never a time when Halle is on screen that should be classified as being boring or UN-entertaining. Yes the story was weak and the other actors were not up to par, but Halle was not "awkwardly cast as the lead." I would go as far as to suggest that if Chris Nolan ever does a Batman film with Catwoman (which is inevitable) it would be imperative that Halle be cast as Selina Kyle/Catwoman.

Hilarious. If you can approach the movie in the right mind set, it can be one of the funniest movies you will ever see. And fun, too. However, there are a few scenes where the camera cuts get completely out of control. For example, a scene where two or three people are talking but the camera cuts twice per second between them and it becomes disorienting to the point of causing nausea. However there are only several scenes like that and most of the time the editing is good, and in some places even excellent.

reviews.review_title: Inane, Disjointed, and Flat Out Embarrassing Junk
reviews.content: There are two other words for "Catwoman" that make a world of sense (as this film lacks any): complete junk. It started off somewhat intriguing (if a little platitudinal), proceeded as disjointed, dizzying, and disturbingly futile, and ended up being complete "kitty litter" drek. How else could you describe a film that concludes with, "Purrfect" and equally inane quotes throughout including, "Cat got your tongue?" and "It's overtime!". What a pathetic disaster this film is, and a crime in ticket admission; nobody should have to pay two cents for this waste of time. The acting is mind-achingly terrible: I surely believed Sharon Stone had more class and talent than this. The direction is atrociously ill-focused and dizzying, never even bothering to concentrate on a scene for more than five seconds. This kind of technique might have worked for the web-spinning scenes in "Spider-Man" but prove miserably weak and futile in an already painfully bad film. Not that I was expecting too much out of "Catwoman", but just about the only positive feature for this outright disaster of a film was the dark, Gothic scenery, which I found to be quite befitting for the theme of the film: dark, empty, and intoxicatingly bleak. How this film was ever greenlighted as a major movie production is beyond me, but perhaps this atrocity will be justified by the time of the Razzies. Meowww...What a bad movie... 1/2 out of ****

I think that the movie is interesting. I'm I understand that all those comic-freaks cry out loud that the story doesn't take place in Gotham and so on, but normal people don't care about such small things.The film is fast, funny, nicely directed and Halle Berry is awesome. she is simply brilliant - beautiful, sexy and funny. Kudos for Halle!!! It's nice to see Lambert Wilson in an evil guy role again and Sharon stone finally plays good in this movie. Also I would like to stress out that the music is very good and catching.Summarizing Catwoman is a far better movie than Daredevil, Hulk, Batman Forever, Batman and Robin.I would love to see a sequel of that film.

reviews.review_title: An absolute mess made by people who don't trust or understand the character
reviews.content: This is what happens to a comic book movie when there is no central intelligence or guiding hand in control who understands and respects the character. It makes me doubly thankful for the Spider-Man and X-Men films, which could easily have had the same thing happen to them.The sad part is, there are flashes, here and there, of a much better movie which is hopelessly buried under the main portion of schlock.1) The opening credit sequence is interesting, and intriguing, with it's suggestion of a 'cat cult' that runs throughout human history. It's an element that never really gets touched on in the comics. It's just that Selina Kyle really likes cats, and the role suits her personality. 2) Catwoman's 'first' outfit, the black patent leather suit with the domino mask, is 100 times more convincing than the horrible thing she eventually ends up in.3) And the whole scene in which that she wears the black leather outfit,where she kicks the bejeezus out of the hoodlums in the jewelry store because she wants to rob it herself...THAT'S the movie they SHOULD have made.4) When Catwoman uses her 'feline' abilities to slither through the bars of her jail cell, that is pretty cool. It's something that a 'normal' person couldn't do, but something a lithe woman who was 'channeling' a cat might be able to pull off, and it is understated and quirky enough to make the viewer say, "Hey, that's an interesting ramification of being 'cat-like' that I hadn't thought of." It looks good.5) And even with all the stupid 'cat' jokes - the tuna consumption, hissing at dogs etc., Halle sometimes gets enough 'ooomph' into the character that you suspend disbelief for 3-4 seconds at a time. A lot of actresses wouldn't be able to pull it off in the middle of all the other stupidity ...even Michelle Pfeifer and Julie Newmar might not be able to make that stupid outfit work at all.6) In spite of the fact that Sharon Stone's villain has an extremely stupid superpower - skin turned to stone by her own product - and in spite of the fact that the character of the villain is a one-note caricature, she is a good choice for the role, and she actually sort-of makes the character work for about one scene in every 4-5.7) The final knock-down,drag-out between the heroine and the villain-ness doesn't succumb to most of the easy clichés movies used to fall into with girl fights (b*tch slapping contests or WWE cat fights.) They punch each other around pretty good, with a lot of energy and physicality, and leave most of the sleazy 'girl fight'/femdom porn aspects alone. 8) I have to grudgingly admit that the closing 'coda', where Berry voiceovers the character's mission and vision, while a great sexy "TLC" type song sets the mood and the character struts away from us into the moonlight...that was a great little movie moment. So that's maybe 30% of the movie that doesn't insult the character or goes for the cheesy cat jokes. The rest of it, while made in an ultra slick MTV video style, is a waste of time and money. It's pretty and shiny as hell, but has no guts or heart to it. I'm not saying that a movie about a superhero has to take itself ultra-seriously - see the humorous parts of the first two Superman movies, or either of the Spider-Man movies. Those movies made wry self-aware comments that were also loving tributes to the energy and vision of their creators. But while "Catwoman" (the character) is about an interesting, freebooting adventurer with her own standards and nobility...Catwoman (the movie) is about a bunch of Hollywood hacks spinning some kind of "Cosmo" girl/"I walk alone" fever dream. Oh, and I hope I never see Benjamin Bratt in another movie again, ever. Sorry, Ben.

reviews.review_title: Much better than you might be led to believe
reviews.content: Yes, it's true. I sat down to watch this movie with the enthusiasm I usually reserve for MST3K films, expecting nothing but the worst movie of the century. You can imagine how disappointed I was then, when the film actually turned out to be quite entertaining.Now, before you gasp in horror and wonder whether I've lost my scornful touch, I have to say the movie was far from perfect. But, compared to what I had been expecting, it was little short of amazing.OK, so the story is silly, but is the idea that a woman who dies and is revived by a mystical cat any less ridiculous than someone being bitten by a spider and developing super-powers? I think not. The plot is simple, which actually serves to help the story, rather than hinder it, since you don't waste time wondering what the hell is going on. And Halle Berry is likeable enough in the main role that you can believe in her as the titular character. The action is fairly well done (see below for further thought on it) and keeps things moving along at a brisk pace.Now the bad things.Firstly, and once again I have to bitch about this because it is becoming a festering epidemic in Hollywood that must be stamped out! Stamp it out I say! - the CGI effects. They suck, quite frankly. At no point in the movie are you ever in any doubt whatsoever which Catwoman is a real person and which is CGI. It's doubly irksome here because, in addition to being glaringly obvious, the CGI animators still haven't got to grip with basic physics concepts like mass and momentum. Catwoman (whom we can assume weighs at least 120lbs or so) leaps about more like a demented flea than a cat and lands from great heights without even the slightest noise. Anyone who's ever owned a cat should be able to attest to the fact that they're anything but silent when running and jumping around. In fact the based on the CGI alone it would probably be better to rename the movie Monkeywoman.Secondly, the action scene editing is just awful. I don't know who had the bright idea that, if you cut and chop scenes endlessly during an action set-piece it would make things look faster and more agile, but it don't work buddy! In several sequences - the basketball scene, the motorcycle ride and the "playing" with the cop above the theatre stage scenes the cutting and chopping is relentless. In most instances you get far less than a second to try and make sense of an image before it cuts to the next, then the next and so on. You must get thirty or forty cuts during a short scene. All it succeeds in doing is completely disorienting the viewer until they don't care what's going on, they just want it to be over. In fact, I actually felt a bit nauseous during the basketball scene (which is the first time you get the treatment). After that I got my spacelegs and could tough it out, though I still had a headache by the end.A third annoyance were the cat traits that Halle Berry's character developed after she became Catwoman. She became fond of fish for a start. Well, that's stereotyping cat behaviour if ever I saw it. My cat preferred cheese to anything else. Catwoman also preferred milk and hissed at dogs. These might seem little things, but they were somewhat silly and aimed at cheap laughs. However, despite my fervent hopes all through the film, not once did she lick her genitals. Nor apparently, did she develop six nipples, or I'm sure her boyfriend would have noticed. Or develop a foul cat-breath with all the fish she was eating. So it amused me that she was given some, but not all, of the traits that cats are famous for.Despite my lengthy gripes, the film was OK to watch and much better than I was fearing. If they'd have addressed the problems above, the film could really have been quite good. As it was, it was a harmless way to spend an hour and a half.
The basketball scene. That's all that needs to be said.

reviews.review_title: You'd be better off taking in a stray cat than watching this
reviews.content: This feline fiasco is so embarrassing, the average cat would commit suicide nine times after seeing it. Kitty litter jokes come to mind, but this thing smells even worse than that. Everything went wrong, starting with the script. It's hardly at a kindergarten level: some nobody at a cosmetic company comes upon a sinister plot by her greedy corporate superiors. Wow: corporate bad guys; creative, original, brilliant. The evil corporate baddies off the girl, who gets miraculously resurrected by a bunch of out-of-work alleycats. She then adapts a feline persona, and the inevitable vengeance rampage commences.It gets worse. What's with Halle Berry's bad hair day? It looks like a hundred cats buried rats and other stuff they had killed in her hair, then ripped some of her hair out by the roots. At least she wears a hood that covers that mess through most of the movie. It's ironic that the Catwoman was originally a campy satire of the femme fatale character type in movies, since this movie makes an attempt to reimagine the character as a serious figure. The ineptitude of the film makes Halle's Catwoman the lamest and campiest of them all. The director tells the story poorly, and Berry's acting is as dull as a de-clawed fang. Everyone in the cast looks embarrassed to be a part of this, and with good reason. As some of the previous actors to play the role might say: this movie is a complete cat-astrophe.

Every bit as bad as you've probably heard it is, Catwoman's primary selling point is Halle Berry's hot bod; with an awful story, dire direction and pretty lame CGI special effects, it's not surprising that the people behind this inept comic-based slice of drudgery decided to up the sex factor in order to sell their product to the horny teenage boy comic-book nerd audience.In this updating of the Catwoman legend, the character of Selina Kyle has been replaced by Patience Phillips (Ms. Berry, proving that even Oscar winners have off days), a talented artist who has reluctantly settled for a 9-to-5 job in the advertising department of Hedare, a large cosmetics company.Patience discovers that Hedare's latest productan anti-ageing creamis still being launched despite its dangerous side-effects, but she is bumped off before she can reveal the truth. Resurrected by a magical Egyptian cat (yes, you did read that right!), Patience is imbued with supernatural feline characteristics: incredible agility, fantastic vision, a love of catnip (yes, you read that right too!).After kitting herself out in a rather fetching black leather outfit complete with whip, she sets off into the night to get revenge on the evil Hedare head honchos and their henchmen.A mess of dreadful visual trickery, Catwoman is an embarrassment for all involved: the director (and I use that term loosely), Pitof, has no idea how to construct a movie, and a barrage of CGI replaces any attempt at decent storytelling (not that there is much of a story to tell since the plot is asinine to a degree that beggars belief); the acting is uniformly awful; and the special effects leave a lot to be desired, ranging from OK to downright dreadful.Deserved winner of multiple awards in the 2005 Razzies (awarded to the year's worst films), Catwoman is a stinker from start to finish.

Catwoman is the best movie you have yet to see! Halle Berry takes the role and makes it great where Michelle whats-her-name previous stunk it up. I know a lot of comic book nerds complained because that they changed the character but who cares! Comic books are for children and movies are for adults like me. Just had a thought: The trend lines are that comic books lagged behind movies for moral complexity and attention to moral detail. Comics are catching up. And Catwoman takes two steps backwards. But what action- filled and colorful steps those are!Catwoman is cheezy. It throws the cheese on the floor, ankle deep, and ROLLS in it! And what is the soul of cheese? The soul of cheese is that you took milk, inoculated it, then contained it. This film is peppered with little pockets of moral containment; places where certain "comic book" conceptions of how the world works come into fragrant cheezy bloom. From cheezy romantic office dialog, to cheezy stagings of big business boardroom presentation banter, to cheezy comic booky conceptions of the law enforcement process--up and down the line--the film is redolent.But: I like cheese! Don't you? I sort of enjoyed the way the film heads off the problem by going full-bore/headlong into that territory. That's actually sort of laudable. For my money, it does also feel like a case of taking a certain, limited storytelling aesthetic to a very high place. Monies were disbursed to screenwriter(s?) with an astounding ability to churn out this particular species of filmic cheese... and that's not altogether a bad thing, as long as you recognize it as such, and enjoy it on its terms. What these(?) screenwriter(s) did, they did with all their might. Show a little respect.In short, a whiffy cinematic snack. Don't be ashamed! Don't be a snob! Enjoy it!

reviews.review_title: A bit of explanation might help
reviews.content: The internet has brought all sorts of things, good and bad, into our lives. One such thing is the perfect expression to apply to the movie "Catwoman". It is "WTF?" DC Comics had a perfectly good character called Catwoman. She has been reinvented from time to time over the years, but you could usually reckon on her being a slinky femme fatale called Selina Kyle, usually clad in a cat-based sexy costume of some kind, and leaning towards crime but with a degree of moral conflict going on. Oh, and she fancied Batman.This character worked very well in the comics over the years. She was also successful in the 1960s TV series and movie, even though she had been played by a succession of actresses. And her incarnation in Tim Burton's second Batman movie, as played by Michelle Pfeiffer, was probably the most successful thing in that run of 4 Batman movies.So the movie made to cash on on that success starred Halle Berry, as a completely different character, in a completely different costume, in one of the worst scripts ever written, with Sharon Stone giving a career worst performance, and the stunt work rendered by CGI which would have given computer gamers in the 80s reason to weep.Like I said, WTF?
