The "villains" of the movie were boring & had an ugly relationship. It also started very slow, I understand it takes time to build a character, but it could have been some differently. The coolest scene was when she first dresses up and steals the motorcycle! I also liked the relationship between her and the officer. Halle Berry (as usual) played her roll well. I did also like the general aesthetics in the shots. It's disappointing to have an okay movie for such a cool character (like the Batman movies).

reviews.review_title: A mixed bag of kitty litter
reviews.content: Catwoman is not really a movie on its own, but parts of better comic book movies.  Moviegoers could enjoy themselves pointing out where a scene was riped off from another movie.  I saw scenes riped off from Batman, Batman Returns, Spiderman, and the TV show Birds of Prey.  As for this movie, it is really a mixed bag.  Halle Berry tries really hard to make the movie work, but the movie is all wrong. Her costume looks all wrong.  Plus, the villains in this movie are from a COSMETICS COMPANY!!!!  A COSMETICS COMPANY??!!! Are we going to be attacked by makeup?  A little silly, don't you think?  I certainly think so.  Since Sharon and Halle Berry are both very beautiful women, I would think there would be elements of satire here.  However, the movie is played straight.  Stone has given this performance before in Total Recall and Basic Instinct and has given it much better.  I think Stone is a one note actress and it shows.  Benjamin Bratt is just going through the motion as the cop/love interest for Catwoman. If you have a free ticket to go, like I did, see it.  Otherwise, wait for video. A generous 5/10.

reviews.review_title: I must confess that I enjoyed it
reviews.content: As soon as I saw that catsuit, I thought "This is going to be the camp classic of the year." Then as the reviews started pouring in and I heard things like "Halle slurps tuna out of cans," "Halle is given mouth-to-mouth by a cat," and "Halle says insipid lines like 'cat got your tongue?'" I knew I HAD to see this. I went on opening night for the express purpose of laughing at it, hoping that the entire audience would be with me. Imagine my shock and horror as I found myself actually enjoying it.Don't get me wrong, this is not a GOOD movie. The plot in particular hinges on one ludicrous conceit on top of another, and many developments don't stand up to the SLIGHTEST scruitny, but you know, the whole thing is just so over the top ridiculous that you stop caring after a while. Even all the ridiculous elements (i.e. tuna cans), in the context of the movie, don't stand out as glaringly, and since they play it off as Patience is in effect possessed by her cat side, all these compulsive things she's doing sort of work in that context. I didn't like the CONSTANTLY moving camera (and I was sitting in the 3rd row, so it really was nausea-inducing) and the CHEEEEEEEESY digital effects work, but I felt that his idea was to create this very pop comic book universe, so at least it was an IDEA. It didn't work that well, but it was an idea. I think it's clear that the Sharon Stone part of the storyline was inspired in large part by THE WASP WOMAN, a 50's horror film in which a woman is the owner of a cosmetics company, and was once the lead model, but is now growing older and has to step down as model. She experiments with wasp jelly in order to hold on to her youth... and of course it turns her into a vicious wasp woman!I can't say I recommend it, but I will say I had a MUCH better time watching this than I did at Hellboy, Chronicles of Riddick, or the Matrix sequels... You know, bad movies just aren't what they used to be.--- Check out website devoted to bad and cheesy movies: www.cinemademerde.com

This is truly the worst superhero film ever made and indeed one of the worst films of all time. It's a total mess from beginning to end, a misstep every way, featuring lousy cinematography, some of the worst special effects known to mankind, absolutely appalling acting from the entire cast and one of the most mundane and derivative scripts I've ever seen played out on camera. Yeah, I didn't like it much.From the beginning, when we meet dowdy Halle Berry and her insipid voice-overs, I just knew that the main inspiration for this film was going to be SPIDER-MAN. I was right. However, director 'Pitof' is no Sam Raimi; in fact, he's a French special effects man who seems to have virtually no idea how to make a movie. The scenes with CATWOMAN are excruciatingly painful, the most derivative and sanitised I've seen, while those with Berry as her human persona are dull and clichéd in the extreme. I despise that TV show Ugly Betty and this reminded me of that far too much.Meanwhile, stereotypes abound: the chubby best buddy, the flamboyant gay guy, etc. After Berry turns into Catwoman – in a scene that makes no sense – it becomes even worse, if that was possible. The fight scenes are over-edited monstrosities, and the CGI effects completely laughable. Berry herself – well, I won't ever be able to forget just how bad she is in this film. Her Catwoman looks like some S&M fan's dream, and every single damn scene has some kind of sassy black woman's music playing over the sound track; I can just imagine some audience member jumping up in her seat in a key scene and thumping the air, shouting "You go, girl!". At least, that's the intent. The supporting cast are also poor, with a charisma-free Benjamin Bratt perhaps better renamed as Benjamin Prat, and Sharon Stone's villainess – well, let's just say she's now repulsive and unable to make a good film.Previously, I thought BATMAN & ROBIN was the dumbest superhero film out there, but that's a masterpiece in comparison to this mess. What a crock!

reviews.review_title: "What a puuuuuurfect idea!" I'm sorry, come again?
reviews.content: It's got to take a lot of cheese for DC Comics to discreetly distance itself from one of its if not main then certainly most iconic characters. It took Michelle Pfeiffer's equally iconic portrayal of the Selina Kyle/Cat Woman character in Tim Burton's excellent "Batman Returns" to bring the idea of a Cat Woman film to the forefront. What might have sound like an appealing proposition back in 1992 somehow didn't feel as relevant more than a decade later. And for good reason...The shy Patience Phillips stumbles upon the dirty secrets of her employer and gets killed for it. Not to worry though since she's brought back to life by some cat/deity of some kind and is reborn as the ballsy Catwoman so she can get an hair do, go shopping, do a bit of clubbing and incidentally find out who killed her and why... Oh and then she meets some generically good looking cop along the way... Vengeance and impossible love story ensues. The end. No, I mean it: the end.Everything about "Catwoman" smells like left overs, the remains of a Sunday dinner stretched into a Monday casserole, exhausted from having been tried and done so many times before and bloated out of all proportions with stupidity and pointlessness so the script would be slightly thicker than a RSPCA leaflet. It would be very difficult to single out one particularly bad aspect of "Catwoman" from another as they are effectively interwoven into a complete disaster. This is such a formulaic Hollywood product that everything about its story (or lack of thereof) mired with plot holes the size of Australia is already known to whoever has ever watched a film before. Worse of all, it is so stereotypically marketed (even through its soundtrack) that all that was missing was Halle Berry snapping her fingers while saying to Sharon Stone "huh huh! No you don't girlfriend!". The performances of its cast is made of sheer non-commitment, an acute disaffection that is both understandable judging by the overall bêtise of the piece and insulting considering that people had to pay to see it. Last but certainly not least, the faux gloss of its CGI effects and the posturing of most of its camera works all conspire to hide the general lack of depth but actually manage to raise the bar of ugliness to brand new heights. So much so that it would be difficult to believe that it was all accidental.It boggles the mind to think that Halle Berry could have ever thought "Catwoman" to be a good career move. Witnessing her, dressed for the oldest profession, struggling to act through this aimless debacle, the word "trapped" springs to mind. Was this some contractual obligations? What is certain here is that artistic integrity took a back seat after enough zeros were laid down on a cheque.

As of the day I'm typing this, imdb rates "Catwoman" 3.3 out of 10. Let's put this in perspective. "Electrocuting an Elephant", a 1903 film starring an arrogant, smiling Thomas Edison as he cooks a 13,000 lb elephant to death to show of the power of "his" new invention electricity, rates 2.9. This means audiences are just slightly more inclined to watch "Catwoman" than graphic animal torture.If you can get past that, knowing that this film probably isn't Citizen Kane (or even Citizen Stupid), you can still enjoy this horrible flick. Why is it horrible? I'm sure imdb has a 1,000,000,000 word limit to these reviews so I won't go into it. But all sarcasm aside, I still had fun watching this movie, and in case you decide to watch it (rather than watching pachydermal persecution) here are some tips.1. The first 30 minutes of this flick is a romcom. Seriously. We are introduced to the character "Patience Phillips" (Halle Berry) who is a clumsy, somewhat neurotic loon who looks like she failed the audition to be on the HBO series "Girls". Believe it or not, I thought this was a great angle. For real, who has ever blended action-crime-adventure with romcom? Love it or hate it, props for the attempt.2. Utterly wtf plot elements. Be prepared for scenes that are so incongruous and absurd that you wonder if the screenplay was written by an ex porn screenwriter. For example, Catwoman decides to go window shopping and happens to visit the same building where a totally random jewelry heist is taking place. Another example: Catwoman decides to ride on a ferris wheel (don't ask. part of the romcom) and suddenly the ferris wheel has a random malfunction, turning it into a spinning vortex of death. Other examples: every fight/chase scene is set in a cool, stylish, abandoned industrial manufacturing plant (even if they're in downtown Soho?). It's like the director insisted on having big generators, turbines and swinging metal things in every scene. Alice in Wonderland meets Repo Man.At times the dialogue is so bizarre that, midway through the flick, I started imagining what the movie would be like if it starred Leslie Nielsen from Airplane ("Surely you can't be serious!" "I am serious, and don't call me Shirley."). Deadpan comedy gold. It was around that point that I realized, possibly in a mind-numbed delirium, that Catwoman is a work of utter genius. All of these insane "plot holes" were deliberate, and this has to be the cheekiest, most satirical outright parody of the superhero genre since the original 1960s Batman tv show.I really think that's the case. I really do.Then again, an argument can be made that this film damaged so many of my brain cells that I've lost the ability to reason.

reviews.review_title: Like Its Subject, the Movie Is Somewhat Misunderstood.
reviews.content: First of all "Catwoman" is far from a cinematic masterpiece, but then again it is really not much further off from being a classic than most other flicks of the genre (sorry, "Spider-Man" fans). A shy graphic designer (Halle Berry) for an anti-aging skin corporation unintentionally overhears a deviant scheme perpetrated by the company's power players (Lambert Wilson and still erotic wife Sharon Stone) to corner the market on its product. Berry's bad luck leads to her murder, but her life does not end. Instead she is reincarnated by cats and becomes the titled character, a super-sexy woman that toes the line between good and evil. Berry's new persona makes her both a mystery and an enigma not only to Stone and company, but also police detective Benjamin Bratt (who has eyes for Berry). French director Pitof (a nickname from his childhood that he still uses)  actually shows quite a lot of potential here. "Catwoman" appropriately has that spooky look of the two modern "Batman" installments that Tim Burton worked on. The cinematography, art direction, editing and of course Berry's costume designer (how could you not like how Berry looks in this picture?) are all impressive. The key performers (Berry and Stone in particular) are believable and well-developed. The big problem with this film is the script as it staggers most of the time and just never quite meets its potential. Berry also adds much complexity to an already rich role as she outdoes all other ladies who ever played the role. Still not a great movie, but for the genre it is not as bad as many think. 2.5 out of 5 stars.

reviews.review_title: I expected nothing, yet I'm still let down...
reviews.content: I just finished reviewing three Ingmar Bergman movies and now I have to write about "Catwoman". Gee, I feel like stepping on an ant-hill after climbing Kilimandjaro. Now, where do I start? (since the question is not whether the movie is good or bad, but how bad it is). Well, there is this quote from the TV show "Malcolm in the Middle" that had me laughing to tears and I've got to hand it to the writers for coming with such a fine and brilliance piece of cleverness. After they finished celebrating his birthday, a cone-wearing Dewey is asked if he liked the party, his comment is implacable : "I expected nothing, yet I'm still let down" Now this is how I feel about "Catwoman".I won't throw more rotten tomatoes at "Catwoman" because I didn't expect much to begin with. I registered on IMDb the same year as the film's release, I had all the time to know about its reputation, its flop at the box-office and unanimously disastrous reception, so there was nothing to heighten my expectations except the slightest hope that the film would belong to the 'so bad, it's good' category... but even then, there should have to be a good reason for me to watch it instead of a film that just happens to be 'genuinely good'. It took 10 years but between two remote control's clicks, I caught the movie right in the beginning, and I decided to give it a chance.By chance, I meant the benefit of the doubt. And it didn't last, Halle Berry portrayed a woman who, for some no other reasons than plot requirements, became a cat after the opening scenes showed her in every possibly kitty-like situation (almost) in case we forgot. Why all the rush? You've got an A-actress like Halle Berry (well, that's what she used to be anyway), she had just won an Oscar, she could have put some three-dimensionality within her character so how about sitting on a lonely place and trying to give her more substance and not just turn the woman into a cat-like creature right on our nose.I have a confession to make, I haven't seen Christopher Nolan's 'Batman' movies yet, yeah, yeah, shame on me, "booo!", I know. But I'm going to say something positive: from what I understood, his movies did well because the scripts didn't rely on special effects, but on characters' development. This is not character study or some kind of intellectual stuff, but just a way to inject some humanity, anything to enhance our empathetic process. Instead of that, the French director Pitoff, who lacks both talent and a first name, focuses on an unpredictably bad and basic antagonism between Patience Philips (Catwoman's real identity) and a big cosmetics corporation selling an eternal beauty-cream, whose only secondary effect is to burn the skin when they stop to use it.And I thought the whole fiscal subplot in "Star Wars Episode I" was pointless, how about that? What kind of vileness is supposed to come out of such a plot? Or is it supposed to fit the casting of Sharon Stone as Catwoman's nemesis and Lambert Wilson who does nothing else than embarrassing himself. All these actors proved to be capable when given a good script, I don't know who wrote "Catwoman" but I'm an aspiring screenwriter, I'm not 100% sure about my talents, but that a script like that got a shot sure gives me hopes.And I'm also a feet-fetishist, and as much as I love the toes sticking out Berry's boots, damn, even I knew it was aesthetically wrong, unless it proved the movie's real intention which was to appeal on the lowest levels. After all, Catwoman is too sexy a character not to have her sensual savagery been exploited, but then how about injecting some sensuality and make the film a bit more adult, instead of just some paws's traces in her friend's back. I don't remember the name of the actor, but I'm sure I'm doing him a favor by not trying to.Catwoman's outfits were probably designed to inspire the lustiest appetites, but if it failed as a superhero film, it did as well as a soft porn spin-off, while in both ways, it could have been interesting. And all the attempts to make Halle more feline... meeooo... ouch! I wish I could find one thing to appreciate, but it's as if Pitoff deliberately sabotages his own film, by inserting some stupid random basketball scenes or some cringe-worthy CGI effects, and don't get me started on the whole Egyptian mythology, Alex Borstein and... did I mention the basket-ball scene? Is making a good film that complicated? Sometimes, all you have to do is write one great scene with two characters sitting in front of each other, and it can provide something interesting. Nope, Pitoff wanted his "Catwoman" so badly it ended among the movies considered the worst of all time. As an aspiring filmmaker, a film like "Catwoman" is the kind of nightmare that makes me wonder if I shouldn't also shorten my name just in case.A wasted use of talents because of a lack of direction, too much CGI, a lack of script, too many hackneyed situations, a career-ruiner move, definitely. Do actors read the script, I don't know. Proof is that script is the movie's spine. Indeed, as I started this review with, I just watched three Ingmar Bergman movies recently and I have no doubts that even someone like Pitoff can recreate the same shots, so technically speaking, he's got it. Just learn to use some close-up, one good script, and even the crappiest thing can redeem itself.Why am I talking about Bergman anyway? Well, sometimes it's the plain that give its emphasis to the mountain.

Patience Phillips (Halle Berry) works as a meek graphic designer for a giant cosmetics company. Laurel (Sharon Stone) and George Hedare (Lambert Wilson) are about to launch a new product. Only there is something wrong. Police detective Tom Lone (Benjamin Bratt) is the love interest.Sometimes there are bad scenes, bad story, bad action, or bad CGI. This movie has all of them. Some of it is embarrassingly bad. But it's not the type that makes you laugh. It's more the type that makes you cringe. Halle Berry is trying so hard to be cat like. It looks very awkward. The story is just so shallow. Of course, a female superhero has to battle a cosmetic company. The basketball pick up game with the kids is horrendous, and it actually hurts my eyes to watch it. It's good that they attempted a female superhero movie. They come so rarely. But it's a real shame that it's such a bad movie.

All those 1-ratings does smell of a smear campaign. Or is it just that a lot of people have no independent capacity for thought and just jumps on the band-wagon, uncritically agreeing with the apparent consensus about a movie's quality?This movie doesn't have a great story, but it does have great style, and it should score some points for that. Halle Berry looks amazing (and when I say "amazing" I mean drop-dead spectacularly gorgeous), and although I'm not a big fan of the ripped leather costume, I have to say the camera-work that films it is pretty damn good; in fact it's bloody excellent. There is great style in the moves, the design, the attitude. The whole cat-like thing with the independence, impulsiveness and irreverence - coupled, to boot, with the desire for greater female liberation - is translated really well from the idea to the celluloid.On the down-side, the story is pretty dull. It's one more run-of-the-mill Hollywood movie with cool production values and lots of flashiness and glitter, but hardly any actual substance.6 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: "Halle delivered the Best, Viewers accepted the Worst"
reviews.content: When I first heard about this movie I was in a great doubt, how they going to do this, a character from Batman movie placed separately without Batman and also hiring another actress for Michelle Pfeiffer's acclaimed character Selina Kyle, I was confused. But when I see the movie and saw Halle's performance my doubts were all gone.Catwoman (Spoilers******) For those People who came late, Catwoman is a character from Batman comics created by late Bob Kane. Her true name is Selina Kyle who gets some mysterious animal abilities after an accident and became Catwoman. She is an anti-heroine, not exactly a villain and often romantic interest of Batman. Selina Kyle's/Catwoman's first silver screen debut was in 1992 block buster sequel 'Batman Returns' portrayed marvelously by Michelle Pfeiffer. In this movie everything changes, there is no single resemblance to that previous world except in name, which I think is good but also bad in certain aspects.Director Pitof tells the new tale set in a new surroundings called Lake City ie, not Gotham City, this is the story of Patience Philips (Halle Berry), a graphic artist who is murdered or nearly died when she finds out a dark secret about the cosmetics company Avenal Beauty she works for, which is a front for criminal exploits of Laurel Hedare (Sharon Stone). However Patience is brought back to life, by an Egyptian Mao cat that is indebted to Patience for saving its life once. Reborn with a new attitude, Patience Price becomes a new Catwoman and takes a different path for avenging her sufferings.Written by Theresa Rebeck, John Rogers and John Brancato & Michael Ferris (the sucking duo I hated the most, only because they wrote Terminator 3!) tells the reinventing story of Catwoman. The fancy screenplay failed to give proper rhythm to the story telling, even though it showed Patience Philips's pre-Catwoman and post-Catwoman life in an interesting manner. Absence of a great negative character for Catwoman made the movie unappealing. Sinking actress Sharon Stone sucked in her role, she should at least see Demi Moore's performance in Charlie's Angle 2. Plus incorporating myth to Bob Kane's saga, by telling Catwoman was born after one's death makes twisting. (Boy, does Batman make love to a Zombie Selina.) I am sure it must be from the stupid minds of John Brancato and Michael Ferris, really they have sucking thoughts. Or did they copied Brandon Lee's Crow.The soul for Catwoman was from Klaus Badelt, Blake Neely and Geoff Zanelli. The score didn't emotionalize the story, it's merely bulge up the tensions when it comes to unrealistic action/chasing scenes. Plus adding unwanted CGI compositions to unwanted scenes makes the movie laming, all the blame goes to director Pitof.Anything good in this movie is Halle Berry, I was blown away by her performance, I didn't expect such cat like mannerisms from her, she was truly great. She simply broke Michelle Pfeiffer's definition in every means. I wish she should have played original Selina Kyle in 'Batman Returns'. Those looks, those walks, those reflexes and that back ROCKS.All in all it could have been a great movie if the studio hired good writers and a good director. Instead their attention was to bring a good actress for the title role. That's way the movie got so much negative judgment from viewers and critics. And I am very upset to hear that Halle Berry got Worst actress award for her Performance in this movie. It deserved to all other people cooperated with this movie, instead of Berry. And also, Razzie award critics SUCKS! Catwoman = James O'Barr's CROW + Bob Kane's Batman.

A shy woman, endowed with the speed, reflexes, and senses of a cat, walks a thin line between criminal and hero, even as a detective doggedly pursues her, fascinated by both of her personas. I could've cared less what happened to these characters because there was no depth to them and I didn't feel attached to them at all. Comic book fans will like it, but we've seen these clichéd characters a hundred times. The directing, music, editing, etc. are not very focused on at all here. Overall, the film was, I would say, "eh". I was bored through most of it and I left the theater with no intentions to ever see it again. Which is too bad, since my girlfriends and I were so excited to see this movie, thinking it was going to be a fun one. I give it 7 out of 10.

This film is one of the most awful superhero films I have ever seen. The protagonist is an unengaging ball of clichéd one-liners, the plot is ludicrous and the camerawork is too jumpy to follow. There is nothing to recommend here.

reviews.review_title: She may have been Catwoman but the film is more 'kitten' than 'tiger'.
reviews.content: Although the Batman films from the last two decades have not 'wooed' me as much they have other people, I must say that 1992's Batman Returns did, for me, stick out as an entertaining and well shot film with essence of noir that just worked on my level  interesting then, that I recently saw this film: Catwoman; whom just happens to be one of the 'baddies' from Batman Returns. However, this 'spin-off' or prequel or whatever you want to call it, really didn't work.To say that this is a horrible, horrible film and is one of the worst ever made is being a little too cruel. Overall, what I think the main problem is with Catwoman, is that it just didn't seem that dark. The violence was tame, there was no bad language, most of the stunts didn't impress me and even Halle Berry's catsuit just seemed to be 'censored' for some reason. So, from the beginning; the flaws are there regarding getting the film's priorities right and the main character correct.My first suspicion that Catwoman was going to end up being a little disappointing was the first scene that we see Halle Berry's Catwoman (A character called Patience Phillips) and Tom Lone (Bratt) interact. Phillips is out on a ledge bizarrely attempting to save a stray cat in an unsafe place (something Lone then questions the sanity of) but Lone thinks she's attempting suicide so he tries to save her. The fact he manages to cover something like three floors in under ten seconds and then the fact we are presented with Philips realising she's late, not even offering an excuse, not even coming to terms with what it is she just did before literally grabbing her gear and leaving Lone there by himself; exclaiming 'Sorry, gotta go. I'm late(!)' was enough to have me praying it wasn't going to do this for the rest of the film.Fortunately; or maybe mercifully, the film doesn't really have too much of a script so there isn't much dialogue once Phillips becomes Catwoman. There are some excruciatingly bad exchanges between Phillips and her co-worker Sally (Borstein) about finding the perfect man, etc. and the scenes with Lone, the love interest, aren't as awful as they could've been. So instead of shoddy dialogue writing, we are presented with action sequences the bulk of which fall flat for a few reasons. To say Catwoman moves like a cat would actually be a bit of a lie as she moves around more like a flea or a squirrel. She can run up walls, jump from building to building and basically defy psychics as much as she wants. I read after the film that some scenes were inspired by Spider Man  he's a spider with artificial webbing  a cat and a spider are two very different things. Apart from anything else, the scenes weren't even that entertaining in a 'guilty' sort of way.I think that when Bob Kane thought up Catwoman, he was thinking along the lines of: femme fatale, Bruce Wayne's female foil, a dominant woman amongst the crime and male run corruption of Gotham City. In Catwoman, she is as shallow as she should be deep; Catwoman is relegated to being a fetishistic object of desire who can do you damage but only because she's able to, not because she's forced to. This is hammered home during a fight scene in and outside a night club whilst a song is playing; the lyrics seem stuck on: "I'm ready to make you mine". Catwoman in Batman Returns was very different to this and this only makes Catwoman (2004) look more like Batman Forever or Batman & Robin rather than Batman Returns.With the film already failed, the final nail in the coffin is the horrid finale fight sequence where two dominant female characters are bashing each other with poles and whips and through glass yet no broken bones or blood ever seem to show themselves. By this point, Catwoman has come close to relegating itself to B-movie status and thus is a film to ultimately avoid.If you're thinking of watching it with the idea that possibly, you might see Halle Berry as a dominatrix type figure then even then you're going to be disappointed as she isn't even that alluring in the film  how they even got that wrong, I'll never know.

reviews.review_title: A Super Hero For The Female Crowd.
reviews.content: Catwoman is about a shy and timid woman named Patience Phillips who, after discovering something horrible about a product called "Beau-line", is killed by their henchman before she can make her escape. From there, a magical cat named Midnight breathes onto her dead face and is brought back to life, with a few feline characteristics. After her resurrection, she makes a decision to repay those who killed her and along the way, she will stop the contamination of beauty products by Beau-line. By the way, I liked Catwoman's outfit, minus the mask, shoes and gloves.So much for the plot. To be honest, it was not anything more outrageous than plots for Spider-Man, Batman, etc., but it seemed to be a hybrid of a super hero movie and a chick flick. While the movie did have some interesting aspects to it, such as nice camera views and a few scenes with the whip, the CGI was pretty bad and that interfered with the movie for me. I thought the special effects were on par or worse than Hulk's (I liked Hulk better). But I did like Catwoman's suit.I thought the whole cat thing was WAY too forced. Purring loudly, hissing at dogs and the whole catty attitude. I thought the scenes where she was performing various balance acts in her apartment while discovering her new abilities were more than enough to get the point that she was cat-like.Overall, the movie was pretty bad for what it was. Comparing it to Spider-Man, Punisher, X-Men and the like makes it look far worse than it is. I'd say this movie is pretty much middle of the road, around a 5.5 - 6.5 of 10. It was better than the old Spider-Man movies from the 70's. If you want to see some real trash that deserves a 1 rating or lower, see Savage Roses or Plump Fiction. Did I mention I like the outfit?

When I tell my friends my opinion of the movie, Catwoman, even before I get the first sentence out of my mouth I can hear the counter argument already. "Lighten up. This is a movie where you turn off your brain and just have fun with and enjoy Halle Berry in scantily clad attire." The frightening thing about this review is that that *was* my attitude when I first rented it and I still hated it for reasons to follow.According to Jean Luc Godard, "Film is truth at 24 frames per second" and "every cut is a lie." Catwoman is a compulsive liar.I don't believe I've ever felt so annoyed with a film's editing and photography style--More specifically: the camera movement. I actually enjoyed the colorful nature of the photography. And, unfortunately, editing and cinematography can do more to make or break a film than the actors and writing involved.For example, I really did not care about the plot, the characters, Halle, the score or anything in this film due to the screwed up (not to mention distracting) rhythm set up by the, you guessed it, editing. So now that director Pitof has lost my enthusiasm and interest in the first five minutes, the crucial suspension of disbelief that all movie rely so heavily on, will never come. I'd talk about the plot and characters, but honestly, I'm sure I've praised the plots of movies with better editors on staff for plot devices equally as stupid as Catwoman.For those who haven't made the connection yet--the constant movement of the camera and constant cuts reminds me of a cosmetics commercial. What a clever coincidence that the plot just so happens to center around a cosmetics conspiracy (gasp)! Granted the idea and approach is interesting enough to warrant a screen test or two after which it should become apparent that it does not work for a feature length film. Something is drastically wrong when the viewer feels like they can call now and get free shipping and handling when ordering their very own Halle Berry! And granted, the film aims for a certain cartoony feel (after all, Catwoman is a comic book character), but the scales have been tipped too heavily into the land of disbelief. I sense the filmmakers were shooting for Catwoman to be a sexy, sympathetic, and over-the-top bad ass; instead she's just over-the-top and goofy. Again, this is not necessarily a reflection of Halle's performance since the presentation of said performance irritated me so much.And once again just to re-emphasize a point that probably gets lost in a lengthy review: yes, I did grade this film on the no-brainer, drinking-game-worthy, free-rental popcorn flick scale. If you wanted me to grade it on the Casablanca scale, I'd probably laugh at you.

Catwoman is a movie that has been universally panned and so I had not bought the DVD or rented the DVD, instead I waited for it to come on television. I watched cat woman the other night and I was pleasantly surprised and by the time I was a quarter into its length I knew that I wanted to own the DVD of it. With all super hero movies a good writer must give the audience the background into how the 'superhero' came into being. So to the less cultured audience this may make the film appear to be slow. However I appreciated this story buildup. Halle Berry! What can you say, as a woman it is hard to understand why some men could not be content with her. What a BOD!! As an actress I think she realistically went from a dowdy miss to a sex bomb. The 'CGI' was quite obvious in places but the story was believable and I was glued to my TV. I disagree most strongly that this is a bad movie I believe it can stand proudly next to all the other superhero movies and I for one would love a sequel however thanks to the critics this will never happen.

In light of my readings of other peoples' comments on Catwoman, I thought that I was prepared for the worst. Though a few people did note that the movie wasn't actually that bad. I can only assume that these are the cousins and uncles of Halle Berry, the producer and the rest of the crew's ilk, trying to pull a vicious joke on my behalf! The reason for the movie's score being so horrendous is VERY justified! To put it mildly.Halle Berry is supposed to be a frightened little girl without style, and in becoming Catwoman, she suddenly gets "balls" and style. Overnight! Wow! I loved what Tim Burton did in Batman with the Joker and his evil regime, this worked perfectly because the world surrounding the evil empire that the Joker built, matched. But HOW THE HELL DID anybody get the idea that An Evil Empire of Cosmetics, producing addictive and acid-like creams and potions, would ever seem remotely credible.Basically, just see the beginning and when she "dies" the mish-mash animated cats bringing Halle Berry back to life, sets the setting for the rest of the movie. And the amazing thing is that it is running on my TV right now, and I some horrified that I needed to post this for you. Now I will turn it off and NOT SEE the remaining 45 minutes, because I have some trash to take down, clothes to wash and other daily chores that suddenly have become violently important.

People aren't understanding that this isn't a "DC" based movie. It clearly has its own background of origin. Dedicated to the Egyptian goddess Bastet hence the reason for adding the Egyptian hieroglyphics In the intro. It has a woman empowerment feeling from the sex appeal to the music

So the studio that green lighted this extremely high profile and big budgeted summer blockbuster that stars an Academy Award winning actress decided to hire a guy with one name who had very little directing experience. Maybe someone should lose their job! Story is about Patience Phillips (Halle Berry) who works for a high profile cosmetics company but while at home in her apartment she notices a cat hanging around her window. One night when Patience delivers her ad campaign she overhears the owner George Hedare (Lambert Wilson) and his wife and former model Laurel (Sharon Stone) discussing that their new brand of cosmetics will make users sick but dependent on their brand and if they stop using it their skin changes back to it's original state. They chase Patience and she's flushed out of a pipe and perceived as dead but she's awakened by cats and with new found powers that are like a cat.*****SPOILER ALERT*****Patience dresses up in a skimpy leather outfit and seeks to get revenge on those that tried to kill her and stop the cosmetics firm from distributing their deadly make-up. Laurel decides to combat Catwoman by framing her for a murder that she didn't commit and Patience must be careful since her new boyfriend Tom Lone (Benjamin Bratt) is a cop.This misfire is directed by someone named Pitof who is making only his second attempt at directing and he's known mainly for visual effects which is also surprising because the special effects are terrible. Where do you begin with the problems? The effects are terrible and when Catwoman is jumping around she looks like a cartoon character and this is the same complaint I had with "Van Helsing". It doesn't look remotely real and it's eons away from great special effects like "Jurassic Park". Catwoman's outfit while very sexy is ridiculous in it's purpose. Batman's outfit served a purpose with a cape that helps him glide and deflect things and his utility belt has saved his life countless times. Besides making a fashion statement I don't know what else to say except that Catwoman has open-toed shoes and shows off her belly and wears a mask that barely hides her face. Couldn't her boyfriend Tom see that it's obviously her? Not to mention the fact that their both black! The film is also badly edited in that god awful music video style where if you blink you miss three scenes! Berry supposedly trained a long time to master the whip which is a waste because in practically every scene we see it's a CGI effect and looks completely phony. Catwoman actually scales walls and circles the room sideways and I have to ask if she's suppose to be like a cat or a jumping lizard? You can't blame Berry for trying to cash in on her Oscar win but every indication said that this film was in deep trouble and you have to wonder why a studio didn't get a competent director for such an ambitious project.

reviews.review_title: Take it for what it is, BUT....
reviews.content:
It's just fun fluff, jeez every critic out there, those reviewers that are expecting Casablanca...... go watch Casablanca! This is guilty pleasure watching. But it has a definite plot and it played out, the execution of that plot is to be debated.
The CGI is bad, it's certainly not the Catwoman from the Batman universe. Halle looks insanely hot, weather as Patience in plain clothes ( purposely bohemian, and ragged) or scantily clad and golden in her full blown CW outfit, that's undeniable. And to note she always does a lot of work to get in shape and train for roles... ( CW - whip action, Die another Day - fighting, John Wick 3 - gun play) Here's my disappointment in Halle- She had just won an oscar, she was in a Bond movie, she had a blockbuster or 2 in the X men movies. She shud have flexed a bit of actor muscle and told the director, - No Way !!! i'm not doing this! - on the catnip scene, the sushi scene, the hissing sounds. And they could have deleted the entire basketball scene .... and the dumb unattractive sidekick friend, that makes an absurd sexual reference every time she opens her mouth. A good second fiddle to HB could have made a huge difference - like Giovanni Ribisi did for her in "Perfect Stranger" ( HB's best movie, imho) .
If the CGI was a bit more realistic and the absurdity of what this wacky director had Halle do, this movie had a chance to make it as an alternate universe ( non Batman) Catwoman, they obviously intended to make more of them.Bottom line-
good plot, Halle was smoking, and her acting was fine - keep in mind, actors normally do what the director tells them to do, but again, she shud have spoke up, she got paid a ton and again, she must have had some power at this point. i don't see Meryl Streep or even Michelle Phiffer doing what they made HB do. But it's a visually exiting, very colorful film and u can get lost for 2 hours and escape reality with this film.... isn't that what it's all about?

reviews.review_title: Wow! This film isn't bad; it's positively putrid
reviews.content: [WARNING: CONTAINS SPOILERS, ONLY SO OTHERS WON'T HAVE TO ENDURE THIS FILM.]Earlier this year, I was certain I wouldn't see another film to rival "Connie and Carla" as the worst film of 2004. Little did I know "Catwoman" awaited me. Irritatingly directed by Frenchman Pitof (aka Jean-Christophe Comar), this turgid mess begins with a dreadfully dull prologue and only gets worse once our heroine metamorphoses into Catwoman. The film explains why Catwoman is mousy artist Patience Phillips and not Selina Kyle - apparently there've been numerous Catwomen through the ages and a mysterious academic Ophelia (Frances Conroy - what's this fine actress doing in this film?) shows Patience photos of the other Catwomen. I'm certain one photo was of Michelle Pfeiffer, but that only reminded me of her delightfully inspired turn in "Batman Returns" (1992) and that Halle Berry pales by comparison. "Catwoman" plays like a horrid mix between a video game and music video. Did Pitof learn nothing about storytelling working for directors Marc Caro and Jean-Pierre Jeunet? In "Catwoman," shots last just three or four seconds, and Pitof doesn't know where to place the camera, what to do with it or how to shoot fast-paced scenes. Instead of being graceful, fluid and exciting, a one-on-one basketball game between Patience and her object of desire, Detective Tom Lone, becomes dizzyingly confusing. Fight sequences, too, end up choppy, distracting and annoying.Three writers - John Brancato, Michael Ferris and John Rogers - claim credit for an appalling script that's devoid of a vibrant story, captivating characters or good dialogue. Superhero films need lively villains. Here, the bad guys are vapid cosmetics moguls and it's awfully hard to imagine mankind being threatened by facial cream. And their villainy seems like an offshoot of the Joker's plan.Any irony is unintentional - for instance, Sharon Stone's villainous Laurel quipping, "I'm doing all kinds of things I don't want to do." Her scenes with Catwoman should be delicious battles; instead, the writers saddle the actors with embarrassing one-liners, such as Catwoman's "It's overtime," when Laurel points out the game's over. Patience's workplace scenes are mediocre sitcom stuff, and her friend Sally remarks Lone's name rhymes with "Cone, phone, bone." Later, Catwoman actually grabs a man's tongue and quips, "Cat got your tongue?" This is what these writers consider clever dialogue.We can only wonder what Nicole Kidman or Ashley Judd, who were both once rumored to play the title role, might have done as Catwoman. Because as appealing as Berry is, she's horribly miscast. She's atrocious, hasn't a clue how to approach this role. She takes Catwoman too seriously; she's not playing Cordelia, after all. There's nothing gleeful about Berry's performance. She doesn't so much act as model her revealing outfit. Instead of giving us several close-ups of her derriere, Pitof should've given Berry some direction.Benjamin Bratt, playing quite possibly the world's dimmest cop, proves he might be better off sticking to TV. An emotionless actor, Bratt's apparently of the David Duchovny School of Wooden Acting. Wiping his brow is about as expressive as Lone gets. Superhero films require tremendous chemistry between the stars. The Flintstones generate more fire than Bratt and Berry. Hollywood, however, sees a future in this coupling because Brattberry will next appear in a remake of Robert Wise's 1949 boxing noir, "The Set-Up." Just what cinema needs."Catwoman" ends with Patience's voice-over telling us her journey's just begun. It's the promise of a sequel. After sitting through this mind-numbingly boring film, it sounds more like a threat.

I'll admit, this movie wasn't the greatest blockbuster, but I didn't leave the theater feeling cheated either.  I enjoyed watching Halle's transformation in to a more action packed role; she is brilliant and beautiful, to say the least.  However, I'll have to agree with almost everyone who said they hated the cliche-like cheesy one liners like "Cat got your tongue?" and all of that.  Those could've certainly been ommited. 
The whole tyranny of the story is the battle of the distribution of harmful skin cream.  This did weaken the plot, I must say, they should have thought of something with a little more depth.  Sharon Stone's character was a bit weak and dull as well; by her usage of the cream, she was able to obtain "marble" like skin, thus, making her flesh as hard as stone.  I did think that part was a bit lame.The only thing that makes the movie interesting is the beautiful Halle in her revealing catsuit.  I'm a straight woman myself, but I'll admit, she was absolutely riveting!  I don't think it's fair for critics to slam the movie so hard and compare the character to Batman's catwoman.  Clearly, this is another catwoman on a different level.  If you are a Halle fan, then it is worth seeing..otherwise, catch it on cable when it comes out.

"Catwoman" isn't good as a superhero movie and most certainly also isn't much good as an action movie. The story and the main villains plot is beyond silly and for that reason alone this movie is already a waste of time.But there is more wrong with this movie. First of all this movie has almost nothing to do with the Catwoman who we all knew from the Batman franchise. The makers have taken lots of liberties and changed the character and settings entirely. Why? Whatever their intention was, they failed terribly with it. The character isn't interesting and the story also doesn't make her always understandable. One time she has a sort of amnesia and she doesn't remember what happened when she Catwoman and vice versa when she was Patience Phillips and then at other points of the movie she remembers everything perfectly. It makes the movie confusing at times and the main character a totally unbelievable one.Disappointing was also the main villain(s) who are perhaps always the most important element of a superhero movie. Like I mentioned before, the villain(s) intention were totally lame and not likely, even by comic-book-movie standards.The movie features some at times horrible (and pointless) CGI-effects. Also the action sequences weren't much good, this is due to the absolutely horrible and just totally wrong action editing.Quite honestly, Halle Berry isn't horrible as Patience Phillips although she isn't great as Catwoman. Please give the Razzie's to really bad actors and not to good actors who play in bad movies. Her Catwoman costume was however quite ridicules to look at. Does she has no self respect as an actress? There are some other good and well known actors in this movie but the script doesn't provide them with anything good or interesting to do on screen.Yes, the movie does have some entertainment value but the silly story and the way it is told make this movie nothing more than a poor superhero movie wannabe.4/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

Bad... just bad... to the point that it couldn't even be considered remotely sexy or even remotely empowering for females...And Sharon Stone looks funny in a jumpsuit these days.At the very least, this movie reminded me of why MST3K should still exist. My friends and I had a blast.And another thing:Why bother with CG cats??? They're relatively easy to train and oh-so-cuddly.Did anyone else notice that 15.7% of the people who rated this movie gave it a 10?I challenge anyone to redeem this movie for me. Please. Do it for the kitties.That's all.

I finally watched this movie last night and found it poor rather then completely awful. I certainly can't understand all the ratings of 1 and 10 here since this obviously doesn't deserve either rating.Some praise/criticise this for being camp. Well it is a bit, but it's no Rocky Horror Picture Show or 60s Batman.This is a movie that doesn't do anything particularly well, but is brought down by doing some things particularly badly. For me the vocals on the soundtrack is the worst aspect of this movie, rather than sing the vocalist makes annoying moaning noises that at times sound like she's either in pain or having an orgasm.

As an amateur reviewer here on IMDb; I have something of a duty to be honest, and say what I think... There's no smoke without fire, right? Thousands of people can't have banded together to trash this movie as part of a giant vendetta conspiracy? There has to be SOME reasonable grounds for this film to have attained its status as a byword for awfulness, doesn't there?! Well... yeah. The reason to hate this movie is its CGI. It's extremely poor in several instances, and it could well spoil your enjoyment of the movie, and deter you from having anything nice to say about it at all. Dare I say it though; but if you think you can stomach glaringly obvious 'effects', "Catwoman" turns out to be a more than bearable experience - at least for me; who doesn't mind if things look a bit 'wobbly' every now and again...SFX aside; the movie's greatest flaw lies in failing to keep pace with the current trends that go along with handling such material. "Batman Forever" was the last movie to get away with opting for the 'campy' approach; and "Catwoman" is VERY campy - so if you like your superhero exploits served deadpan and with a realistic coating, forget it, because "Catwoman" is not for you. Myself, I don't mind either route; but what we have here certainly contrasts with the brooding intensity that lately seems customary from similar types of movie.I was disappointed to see Halle Berry siding with the critics, and not even attempting to defend the film. If Jennifer Garner has the strength of will not to badmouth "Daredevil", then "Catwoman" deserves at least SOME props, too...There's a playful tone to the movie; and in keeping with that, it's inspired casting to mark Sharon Stone as the female antagonist - complete with barbed comments on how nobody seems to want you after you turn 40. Ouch, Hollywood! Not slow to seize an opportunity; the film of course culminates in the cat-fight to end all cat-fights...There will be many whose biggest axe to grind is that it's not at all faithful to the comics. True though this is; advance publicity for the film made such details common knowledge. The script also points out that there are several incarnations in this constructed universe. Links to other franchises are severed, and not exploited. To complain about something that has never been advertised in the first place strikes me as pretty foolish.If your ears are pricked enough to pick up on it, there's a healthy dose of fun to be had here. There's motivation to be especially catty only if you like fish in a barrel. Meow.

I have owned this movie for six years, and I finally watched it last night. I honestly don't understand all the low ratings. She is murdered and reborn after a cat with supernatural abilities breathes new life inside her. Soon, Patience slowly transforms into Catwoman, and tries to bring her killer to justice. I highly recommend CATWOMAN!!!

There has been a massive downpour of superhero movies. X-Men and Spider-Man have done great as far as box office and DVD sales go, which has influenced several other comic book hero based movies to be made, such as Hellboy, The Punisher, Batman, and Superman is also coming. So, hell, with all of these superhero movies coming out at once, at least one of them has got to be utterly terrible.I'm afraid Catwoman is that movie. Not only is it bad in the sense that it's not really that close in resemblance to the Catwoman in the comic books, it's just horrible in every aspect, period.First of all, I had a difficult time determining why this schlock got the green light in the first place. The plot premise is that Catwoman must stop a certain beauty cream from hitting the shelves. What a stupid idea. Superheros are supposed to fight super villains, or at least powerful opponents of some sort. In this movie, the people Catwoman brawls with (the fight scenes strangely making up about three total minutes in this superhero movie) are ordinary humans, who, of course, easily get their asses quickly kicked.At first, I thought they were just shooting this movie as a petty excuse to show off Halle Berry's "sexiness", but after seeing several pointless scenes of her scarfing down large amounts of tuna and salmon, I was more disgusted than aroused. I don't want to see some crackwh*re stuffing her face in tuna cans, especially when it serves no real purpose for the movie. So, she has the powers of a cat now, does it mean she has to eat like one too? Hell, Peter Parker can gain a spider's powers without craving flies or insects.It's insulting to our intelligence when some people label this movie as an 'action' because it's not at all. It's a lame romantic-comedy featuring rare action, Halle Berry shoving fish in her face, people dry-humping on a basketball court in front of elementary school children, poorly animated CGI, a decrepit Sharon Stone attempting to be beautiful, and the most moronic superhero movie premise that I've ever seen. There is not one thing about this movie that is good, so my personal advice is to just settle for the X-Men movies or Spider-Man 2, instead.0 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Obviously bad, but Halle Berry looks good.
reviews.content: Catwoman is an obviously terrible film. It's absolutely ridiculous and I feel sorry for the people who are in it. I like Halle Berry, Benjamin Bratt,and that's about it. I was never really fond of Sharon Stone, and she is ridiculous in this movie. I'll admit that the old bag looks good for her age, but she's terrible in this film. I think there is only a total of two amusing things in Catwoman. Before I list them, I want to add something about the film. Halle Berry is pretty amusing to look at in the Catwoman suit. it's not even Halle Berry's fault that the movie is so bad, it's just a terrible film. Halle Berry sexiness tries to keep the film together, fails, but somehow amuses. 2.I always like Benjamin Bratt. Bratt is one of those co-star savers. Not that Miss Congeniality was a bad film, but i think Bratt sort of saved that movie too. No, he didn't save it. But if you are making a terrible movie and need someone to keep it together, look for Benjamin Bratt. Bratt and Berry try to keep the film going. Catwoman is an obviously bad film. But because Halle Berry looks so damn good in that suit and Benjamin Bratt is in it, Catwoman is a solid 2. A shy woman, endowed with the speed, reflexes, and senses of a cat, walks a thin line between criminal and hero, even as a detective doggedly pursues her, fascinated by both of her personas.The film appeared on the list of Roger Ebert's most hated films. He criticized the filmmakers for giving little thought to providing Berry "with a strong character, story, supporting characters or action sequences," but his primary criticism came from the failure of the film to give the audience a sense of what her character experienced as she was transformed into Catwoman. He rather referred to it as being a movie "about Halle Berry's beauty, sex appeal, figure, eyes, lips and costume design. It gets those right." Um, Ebert, are you saying they got the costume design right? Because this is definitely one of the things that went very wrong. Not only does the film completely miss the tone of what a Batman or Gotham City film should be, it also does some very strange things with Catwoman. I appreciate their trying to go in anew direction, but it was the wrong direction.

The plot is poor, the directing is poor, the special are sometimes laughable and all the one liners are extra mature cheddar cheesy.I've given it 2 stars for having the 2 sexy main casts of Halle Berry and Sharon Stone but that's all it's worth.Avoid seriously even if you are a Halle Berry fan. For kicks, I decided to watch the brilliant misunderstood masterpiece, Catwoman. I actually gave it a chance too. But, I can't force myself to say anything that great about it. Seriously.Yes, Halle Berry is a fox. But can she act? Not a chance.The plot of the movie is alright, nothing too original. The backstory with other "Catwomen" is also kinda cool, as it explains why there's a random black Catwoman all of a sudden.But seriously now. Everyone in this movie has some sort of super power, not just Berry. Sharon Stone is flying around, getting the crap beaten out of her. "I can't feel a thing." What the hell! Benjamin Bratt is prancing around, hopping off scaffolds, and shimmying off the top of a broken ferris wheel. And he's a Detective. Whate the hell! And of course, there's Halle Berry. Who can fly, and generally act like a cat. But she's supposed to do that, she's Catwoman! And then of course, there's the awful casting of Alex Borstein as comic relief (read "waste time in this piece of garbage movie, make the audience laugh because they probably want to stab themselves for ever purchasing tickets"). And then, the abysmal special effects. I've played video games with better CGI than this. And then, the usual sex scene and clichéd romance. And then, the horrendous dialog. Sin City was fantastic, and had bad dialog. But it didn't take itself seriously.This does.And of course, the fast paced cutting. You can barely see the action on screen. And it shows just how fake it actually is. One moment they're here, 2 seconds later, another place. And the fighting just looks fake. It's awful. It's as if they knew they were done for, but wanted to keep throwing salt on the wound.Oh well, can't say I'm the least bit surprised.1.5/10.

"Catwoman" has become one of the most reviled movies to come out recently. One theory is that it strays too far from the original character known as Selina Kyle from the "Batman" comics, as well as Michelle Pfeiffer's character from "Batman Returns."  That was one aspect that bothered me. Indeed, the opening credits said the movie was "based on characters created by Bob Kane and DC Comics."  Personally, I didn't think that was very accurate.  Halle Berry's character of Patience Philips seems to me as a "re-imagining" of the original Catwoman.  Apart from this, the movie has its good points and bad points.  Among the things I liked was the art direction, and the fast-paced fights.  But there were still things done wrong, like the dialogue, and the imperfect CGI action.  I wouldn't say this movie was the worst ever made, but it just wasn't what it should have been.

Ok, first off.. this film has absolutely nothing to do with the DC Comics character of the same name, or the character from the "Batman" movies.. and this is a problem I have with the general concept of the film... but besides that quibble.. the movie is really quite terrible. Halle Berry seems to be having a blast playing the mild mannered girl who dies, gets brought back to life by a group of cats, and suddenly is a sexy cat burgler/revenge vigilante.. Still, we dont get to know enough of her before she is murdered to really care too much for her or notice the differences upon her transformation. Benjamin Bratt, who seems to be making a career out of playing cop boyfriends here is the police detective who becomes involved with her.. of course since there is absolutely zero chemistry between Berry and Bratt the romance doesnt work at all.. in fact very little in this film works. Sharon Stone as the egomaniacal villain just makes you feel sorry for the state of her career.. the action sequences are weak and the CG Catwoman animation is just terrible and looks like a video game. Really one of the worst films of the year. GRADE: F

reviews.review_title: A very decent movie though under-appreciated...
reviews.content: For the most part, I found this to be a very satisfying movie. People are way too hard on this movie, and they have improper insight about it. This film was good, and Halle Berry was a much better Catwoman than Michelle Pfeiffer. The only reason why many people liked Pfeiffer better is because she was a backed by a certain dark knight that couldn't have possibly been in the new movie. To begin with, Catwoman is supposed to stand alone in this movie. That's why her name has been changed from Selina Kyle to Patience Phillips. That's also why her costume is completely different and why the story has nothing to do with the original Catwoman. Also, of course she isn't going to look like Michelle Pfeiffer's character. This isn't supposed to be Batman Returns 2! It's not even a spin off. Elektra is a spin off to Daredevil, but this was supposed to shine more light on a not so popular character in the DC Comics series. Patience Phillips is not supposed to be the new version of Selina Kyle. Patience is a new Catwoman. As the movie explains, there have been many Catwomen, and Selina Kyle was one of the previous ones. That's another point that I feel necessary to express, because that is something that I've heard many people criticize the movie over, as it was a completely new character that had nothing to do with Selina Kyle. It's not supposed to!Another major problem with this movie is that there was another certain comic book flick that sparked new light on the box office ratings for that time frame that was released only weeks before. Yes, I am specifically referring to Spider-man 2. Almost everyone that saw Spider-man 2 loved it, and it was a smash hit movie the summer that it was released, which was the same summer that Catwoman was released. I think that everyone that saw Spider-man 2 and loved it expected Catwoman to be just as good, or close, because it was two comic book films that were released around the same time, and that's what disappointed them. Catwoman is not nearly as good as Spider-man 2, so if you haven't seen it yet, and you're expecting it to be as good as Spider-man 2, I hate to be the messenger to tell you that that's not what you're going to get, but apparently, it seems to be I have to be the one to deliver the bad news.The only complaint that I had about the movie was that Sharon Stone bombed as an actress, and that affected Laurel Hedare's potential charisma. She was a terrible actress in this movie, as you could tell she was saying a line when she spoke, but it barely affected my overall opinion of the movie, because it's not even noticeable unless you pay the attention that it takes to notice. In other words, you have to know that that's what you're looking for. This is a good movie, and I strongly disagree with the complaints that many people had about it in past reviews. I believe that they were just looking for things to find wrong with the movie, because they expected another Spider-man 2, and with my regards to the many who agree with me, this isn't nearly as good, but it's still a very good adventurous ride that will cause you to think differently of Halle Berry if you always thought ill of her before.8/10!

reviews.review_title: Halle Berry is beautiful, the film disappoints
reviews.content: Pitof, the director of this movie comes from the world of visual effects. He was in charge with the visual effects of several success movies, including one of the later 'Alien' films. 'Catwoman' is only his second film, and his first in the US. The story brings the comics female cat-hero into a rather banal bad-corporate-America plot. Nothing too special, nothing we have not yet seen in many similar films already. A feeling of deja-vu (and too often!) comes also from the hero - just-a-human duality of the character that was inserted here as in many such films to achieve some effect of deepness. Unfortunately, Pitof has nothing new to say as a director, and even not too much to say as a visual effects expert either, at least not in this film. The set and the effects looked too cartoonish to me, and the graphic approach intentionally cartoonish probably, seemed to be simplistic. For a film made the same year as 'Spiderman 2' this is not enough. The relationship between the girl/cat hero and the police inspector lacked any tension, and did not fit too well in a film that targets the whole family, unless you accept that it's aimed rather for adults with kid mindset. Sure, Halle Berry is beautiful, she fits well in the catwoman outfit and seems to enjoy what she is doing, but this is not enough. It's fair entertainment, but still 'Catwoman' is not even a good film in the comics movies genre. 5 out of 10 on my personal scale.

reviews.review_title: Just doesn't live up to it's reputation
reviews.content: ...and by reputation I mean the crappiest film ever created. How much joking, and slamming, and insulting, and constant nattering about how crappy this movie is did I hear before sitting down to actually watch it. I don't know what you folks, including critics have been watching this was SO FAR from the worst movie. Was it bad?? Yeah a little, was it campy, oh hell yes!! Bad acting...yeah sometimes....worst movie ever NO!!! Catwoman was loosely ripped from the DC Comics character of Batman's arch nemesis. Patience Phillips is the meek and quiet artist wannabe who is working for a cosmetics company on the verge of releasing the world's most ground breaking age defying cream. While delivering an ad layout to her boss she stumbles upon the secret of this cream that if a person stops using it, it makes them deathly ill. She is chased down by her bosses henchman and before they can discover who she is they flush her out an enormous drain pipe to her death. Fortunately for her a mysterious Egyptian cat has been sizing her up for some unmatchable powers. The cat, named Midnight, resurrects Patience and passes onto her amazing catlike abilities. At first she grips with trying to control both sides of her personality but gradually becomes comfortable balancing both. She sets her sights on her boss and discovering why she was killed and then realizes she must stop the release of this cosmetic cream to save the world. Catwoman is also framed for two murders she must allude her love interest and prove she is not guilty while stopping the mastermind behind it all.Halle Berry I must admit has never impressed me. I have never seen her do anything of any enormous quality so therefore she is adequate as Catwoman. I blame more the film making and the writing for the downfall of this film than her. She is not the problem. The problem started the moment Batman Returns ended. This film has been in the works since day one. It's gone through numerous casting changes, constant rewrites and even a re-shooting after test screens went horribly bad. If you have to change something that much...chances are it's not worth being made. The obvious removal from the Batman storyline is a mistake in my opinion although it can be linked to that story. Also apparently there is a picture of Michelle Pfeiffer's Catwoman shown with many other Catwomen that have existed. As with many action films you have to let go of a certain amount of reality and ignore some plot holes and sensible information in order to enjoy it and that is a possibility assuming it's not overwhelming and unfortunately for Catwoman it is indeed overwhelming. Why does a woman bestowed with the abilities of a cat also become a martial arts expert, motorcycle riding, whip master?? I've never seen any cat do that?? And despite the name and point of the film the constant cat references are just too much. The story is just...BLAH...it just doesn't get you going and the action doesn't exist. Love Interest in the film, Benjamin Bratt does a fair job, and actually Berry and himself have good charisma but the writing never lets anything flourish. Director Pitof is just a bad director and tries to make a comic book like feel to the film but it just leaves an emptiness that is too much to bear.Despite all this the film IS watchable. It's worth a rental and could be completely retooled for a sequel but it would have to be COMPLETELY retooled...bring in Bob Kane, get rid of directors, writers, anyone behind the scenes who didn't do a good job on the first. It's doable. There are some genuinely cool scenes, the basketball scene is fun, and the final battle between Berry and evil villain Sharon Stone is also well choreographed. And they didn't overdo the CGI, one of my grandest film Pet Peeves for this century. It's not by far the worse hour and 45 minutes you'll spend at the movies. Don't listen to everything you hear, check it out for yourself. 6/10

Otherwise I was hugely disappointed.

When Batman Returns premiered in the summer of 1992, it wasn't greeted too warmly.  Viewed as too dark and disturbing to appeal to children, which since it was based on a comic book was one of it's intended audiences, and not good enough to appeal to adults, the one element that stood out was the character of Catwoman.  Portrayed by Michelle Pfeifer, it was an impressive turn, a buttoned-up,mousy secretary set loose by a near death experience, she donned skin-tight vinyl, brandished a whip and vowed to take revenge against those who had attempted to take her life.  Catwoman, and Pfeifer, impressed enough to begin rumors of the possibility that Pfeifer and Batman Returns director Tim Burton would turn the character into it's own franchise.  It wasn't long before Pfeiffer and Burton were unattached, but Warner Bros. kept pushing the project along, until it finally attached recent red-hot Academy Award winner Halle Berry to the role and put the film in production.  Unfortunately, what has emerged is one of the weakest comic-book adaptations in some time and what may have seemed like a good idea originally now looks misguided.With Pfeiffer gone, the decision was made to push the reset button on this character and remove her entirely from the Batman universe, giving us a new, separate Catwoman.  Berry plays Patience Phillips, again, a mousy, buttoned-up ad designer working for cosmetics giant Hedare.  She is working on the ad campaign for Hedare's new superproduct that will reverse the aging process, and being berated by her boss, George Hedare (Lambert Wilson). Working late one night, she discovered that the cream has some rather serious side-effects and ends up being left for dead by thugs working for George's wife, Laurel (Sharon Stone), who appears to be the brains behind the outfit.  Patience is then resurrected by a group of cats that surround her, and, in the films most laughable and embarrassing scene, breathe some kind of rejuvenating breath onto her, bringing her back to life and imbuing her with an essence of a cat (or something). Suddenly, Patience develops a love for tuna, some rather impressive reflexes and the ability to jump from the street to balconies and an aversion to dogs.  Meanwhile, she has fallen for detective Tom Lone (Benjamin Bratt), who ends up investigating various strange happenings around town that turns out to be Patience trying out her newfound abilities and beginning a campaign to take revenge on those who tried to kill her. The film's first major problem is that there is hardly an once of originality on display here.  Every element is recycled from countless other comic-book origin stories, and the setup of the film is lifted beat for beat from Batman Returns.  Most of the scenes where Patience discovers her powers feels lifted from Spider-Man, where they were more entertaining.  Another scene where Tom and Patience face off on the basketball court is just a rewritten version of the showdown between Matt Murdock and Elektra from Daredevil with a different setting.  There is almost nothing to catch our attention here that hasn't been done before. Fans of the Batman comic books will find the only things in common between this incarnation of Catwoman and the one made famous over the years to be her name, her skill with a whip, and her preference for wearing leather S & M garb with cat ears glued to the top.  There is supposed to be some kind of message here about female empowerment, I guess, but it is given just the barest of lip-service over the course of the film.  Instead, Catwoman seems to be about taking every opportunity to display as much of Halle Berry's skin as possible. Berry seems to relish these opportunities, but they don't amount to much throughout the course of the film, and Berry has used other opportunities to display herself in previous films, so it's not like we are seeing anything we haven't seen before.  And I am certain I am not the first person who thinks that a plot involving destructive beauty cream to be rather lackluster. What this leaves us with is a rather monotonous experience, proving to be not the least bit entertaining for very long.In the acting department, it's a mixed bag.  Halle Berry and Benjamin Bratt are both okay, but they won't win a significant notice from this film. Lambert Wilson and Sharon Stone are both mostly phoning in their performances, and neither George or Laurel make much of an impression as villains.  If there is no one to root against, Catwoman becomes an exercise in futility.  Catwoman's one diverting aspect is it's visual side.  Directed by Pitof, a French visual artist, Catwoman is pretty to look at from time to time, but, given that, it is still not much different from what has been on display in most other comic book movies to date.What we are left with, when the smoke clears, is an attempt to mine the rather successful world of comic book adaptations with material that just isn't strong enough to sustain a franchise.  Do yourself a favor and go catch Spider-Man 2 again and send this cat straight to the video pound.

reviews.review_title: Better than critics (and some IMDb voters) would have you believe.
reviews.content: Halle Barry is excellent as Catwoman, especially in the difficult Patience/Catwoman transition. As Patience she is convincingly innocent, self-effacing and awkward; as Catwoman she is sexy, graceful, lithe and powerful. I can't find a thing to fault in Halle's performance, especially her amazing stunt work and extraordinary physical conditioning. She clearly put a lot of effort into preparing for this role and learning to move in a convincingly cat-like manner. I particularly like the way she handles her whip, which is reminiscent of the languid motion of a cat's tail or the quick strike of a paw.As good as Halle is, overall the movie is very disappointing, a victim of both lack of imagination and heightened expectations. In fact, the only aspect of the movie that works is Catwoman herself. Her costume and diamond claws are wonderfully done, but she's all dressed up with nothing to do. While her backstory is well done, everything else seems like an afterthought. A comic book character needs a world of mystery, intrigue, danger and romance to inhabit. The story and setting need to take the viewer beyond the mundane. It needs to be larger than life, and that starts with imagining something extraordinary. The writers and director fail completely in this regard.The contradictions inherent in a character of dual nature offer ample opportunity for dramatic tension, but the story fails to take any advantage of this, either. Nor does it bother to really explore Catwoman's danger-loving bad girl side. The director, Pitof, is listed as an effects director on a number of French films and the last (and worst) of the "Alien" series. Clearly, he's not ready for prime time. Does an effects director even work with live actors? To judge by this effort you wouldn't think so. The difference between a blockbuster success and a complete flop can come down to hiring an inexperienced director to head an $85 million dollar project. The bottom line: this is a watchable and entertaining film. Halle Berry's performance certainly makes it worth watching. I think anyone coming to it without high expectations will enjoy it. An observation about votes and User Ratings: I noticed in the User Ratings that over 40% of voters gave this movie a "1". What's up with that? Considering how many genuinely crummy movies there are out there, the worst that can be said of Catwoman is that it could have been a lot better. I mean, really, you have to wonder how many of those votes are due to a herd-mentality "piling on". It's sad to think that this might be motivated in part by the star's race and gender.

reviews.review_title: Not Nearly as Bad as Some Have Suggested
reviews.content: "Patience Phillips" (Halle Berry) is a young woman who works in marketing for a cosmetics company which has just invented a new facial cream that they are planning to unveil soon. As a result she is under a lot of pressure and those in charge are willing to do anything in order to increase their profit margins. So when Patience accidentally walks into a secret meeting where they are discussing the harmful benefits of their new product she is shot at and subsequently dies in an attempt to escape. However, she is magically resurrected by some extremely unique Egyptian cats with incredible mystical powers. Not only that but she also inherits certain feline attributes which enhance her physical abilities as well. And part of her is tired of being pushed around. Now rather than reveal any more I will just say that this movie definitely had its faults and deserves some of the criticism that has come its way. However, I do not think that Halle Berry deserved a Razzie Award for "Worst Actress". Quite the contrary. Although Julie Newmar essentially holds the patent for that particular role, it should also be noted that Halle Berry brought a good deal of sex appeal to her performance as well. That being said, the problems with this film centered more on the awful CGI and the overall plot than Halle Berry's performance. At least that is my opinion. In any case, while this movie wasn't nearly as good as it could have been, I don't believe it was nearly as bad as some have suggested and I have rated it accordingly. Slightly below average.
