This leads to a game of basketball with Benjamin Bratt, who plays a cop.This movie cleaned up at the 2005 Golden Raspberry Awards, winning worst picture, worst screenplay, worst director and worst actress, which Berry picked up herself, showing that she has a sense of humor. In her acceptance speech, she said, "I'd like to thank Warner Brothers, for making me do this godawful, piece of **** movie!"Sadly, someone out there has to develop and maintain the web page for the movie at Warner Brothers. If you think your career is rough, you never had to redesign and keep the web page current for Catwoman.Is that job any worse than the food artist who had to mold fruit into fake sushi for the date scene between Berry and Bratt? Why did it have to be sushi? Why couldn't they just use sushi? Why did they even need to see the food? Instead, someone had to spend hours painstakingly making fruit look like sushimi.It took fourteen writers to make this movie, a story that is supposedly about Catwoman but just rips off The Crow without the emotion. Pure junk on celluloid, this movie is a reminder that at one point, studios paid big money to make comic book movies and never once thought that the source material was worthwhile.

reviews.review_title: Catwoman makes coughing up a hairball more enticing.
reviews.content: I have no words. I heard the chitter and the chatter, with many deeming this superhero disaster to be one of the worst films of all time. To say I agree would be an understatement. Holy leather catnip! This was torturous! Patience, a designer for a cosmetic company, is killed after witnessing the side-effects of their product. She is then (stay with me now) brought back to life by a cat who breathes on her corpse, granting her agile abilities of a cat. Thus becoming Catwoman. Completely disregarding its source material, Pitof's adaptation is "Purrfectly" terrible in every way. The story is quite simply nonsensical. A cat foresees the fate of Patience and decides to "test her" before choosing her to hone the powers of Catwoman. The eponymous anti-hero is not just the nickname for a jewellery thief. Oh no no! Pitof has better ideas! Catwoman is actually an entity of some kind that has been passed down since the Egyptians, bestowing the user the ability to climb walls, leap gracefully, devour fish and cat food, rub their nose in catnip and hiss at dogs. Quite literally embodying a cat (giving Patience a complete personality change). Why? Who actually thought this was a good idea!? Was it Halle Berry who nearly destroyed her career the same year as winning her coveted Oscar? Nope. Was it Sharon Stone who, much like her character, attempts to stay relevant and youthful? Perhaps. What about the overuse of horrific human visual effects that caused me to hiss at the screen? Nearly. The dull story that thinks it metaphorically showcases the negative connotations of using makeup? "Purrrhaps". Was it Pitof? Oh, definitely. The clichéd romance, plot conveniences and unusual addition of an R&B pop soundtrack made for an already outdated experience. But the sheer amount of quick cuts during the action sequences were unforgivable. Physically making me feel nauseous. To be honest with you I could go on and on and on, but you don't want to hear me drone on about how bad this disaster is. Everyone involved should be ashamed. Who even says "meowww!" after a fight?

I sat down in 2022 to watch the 2004 movie "Catwoman" for the second time since it was released. Why? Well, because I only vaguely remembered the movie, well honestly, I remembered Halle Berry as the Catwoman character, and that was about it.The storyline in "Catwoman", as written by Theresa Rebeck, John Brancato, Michael Ferris and John Rogers, is sort of a mixed bags of nuts. If you sit down to watch "Catwoman" with the notion of it being a DC movie with the Selina Kyle character and watching a movie tied in with the "Batman" universe, then you will be sorely disappointed. Because that just simply isn't what director Pitof delivered with this 2004 movie. If you, however, sit down to watch "Catwoman" with the notion of it being a somewhat cringeworthy movie based very loosely on the DC character of the same name, then you might actually find a shred of enjoyment in this movie.I have to admit that I had expected it to be a DC-based movie, so I found the movie somewhat of a swing and a miss. But if you step back and look at it objectively, and forget all about DC and Selina Kyle, then "Catwoman" is a decent enough movie. Sure, it had flaws and such, but it does make for some cheesy enough entertainment.Personally I didn't care much for the costume that they opted to strut Halle Berry around in here. The costume was way too revealing and made very little sense for someone to wear, especially for someone on the edge of the law, as in doing robberies, fighting criminals and such. Sure, I can see that there is some appeal to a certain demographic audience by having Halle Berry running around scantily clad, but it just was too tacky.The acting performances in the movie were fair enough. I know that the acting performances have been disliked broadly. But I actually found them to be adequate enough when you take into consideration the shortcomings of an improperly written script and storyline. The movie has some good talents on the cast list actually, with the likes of Halle Berry, Sharon Stone, Benjamin Bratt, Lambert Wilson, Frances Conroy and Byron Mann.Visually, then I found "Catwoman" a bit too gritty and dark, and the underlaying references to matters of an adult content was just growing tired really quickly. Again, not the best of choices for the movie. The special effects in the movie were okay, not great though, but passable enough to make the movie watchable.While the 2004 movie "Catwoman" is not a particular great cinematic gem, then it actually makes for an adequate enough, although somewhat corny and cheesy, viewing pleasure. I have, after all, seen the movie twice now since 2004.My rating of "Catwoman" lands on a bland five out of ten stars.

It's arguably enjoyable simply to laugh at how bad and misguided it is but Catwoman is still a terrible film that's extremely dumb. It's poorly filmed, especially in the action sequences. The CG is terrible and Pitof's direction is bad. Halle Berry is unfortunately awful in the lead role and everyone else gives weak performances. The basketball scene in particular is truly awful.

How to describe Catwoman? Well I think my one line summary is fairly to the point. There was nothing horrifically bad about the film, it just wasn't any good. The storyline to begin with was slightly nicked from Batman Returns where a mousy woman finds out her bosses secret, is killed, brought back to life by moggies, wears leather. I guess the whole back story of catwomen covered that one up a bit, but still they could have come up with something a little better. It would be unfair to compare Halle Berry to Michelle Pfeiffer because the characters are actually different in the way they react to the fact that they have these new powers. Selina was more hell bent on eliminating her killer and went quite nuts because of it. Patience seemed more determined to just bring down the empire of Hedare. Her revenge just didn't seem as believable. The action sequences where real people were involved were fairly OK but the computer generated ones were distracting because it was so easy to tell when they actually occurred. I'm beginning to get slightly annoyed with film makers constant reliance on computers to have action sequences. I know in some cases it would be physically impossible to have any stunt person perform what is required, but they should limit the amount of times that impossible stunts need to be performed. Trouble is in catwoman when Halle Berry was performing her own stunts she was slow and jerky. The final fight at the end was a fine example of this. It almost seemed like they were just fighting in a set patten, following the rehearsals slowly and methodically. Now on to the acting ability of the lead characters. Halle Berry can be quite good when she knows the film is going to be successful, there was nothing wrong with her performances in both X-men films and Die Another Day, but she just seemed so wooden in Catwoman. But if it was possible Sharon Stone actually lived up to her name and had about as many facial expressions as a granite statue. Maybe that was part of the character who was wearing so much of that face cream that she couldn't actually move her face, we will never know. Benjamin Bratt seemed almost non-existent in this, just really going along with everything and not really having much to do with anything at all. In summary, this film had so much potential to be a great action comedy that didn't have to take itself seriously like the Charlie's Angels films have managed to succeed in doing. But with a thin plot and terrible acting it was never going to be. Basically this is just a film centred on Halle Berry and the fact that she is hot property. She had better watch it though, she has done a couple of turkeys since winning that Oscar and with 6 films lined up between now and next year we could become so saturated with her that we will eventually tire.

reviews.review_title: Misguided adaptation of an already-established character
reviews.content: First, let me say the movie is not as bad as its reputation suggests. Second, I must say it is not good either. Too much time is spent setting up the ridiculous story, creating a character that is too far removed from the comics. Halle Berry is decent enough, but plays the part a little too ditzy. Sharon Stone hams it up, but that is probably the best part of the movie. The plot, centering on a beauty cream that stops aging but destroys the skin if you stop using it, is beyond stupid. The meeting of cop Benjamin Bratt and Berry is ignorant. If I had to rescue a woman who was trying to save a cat, I think I would have her committed instead of buy her a drink. But, all of this could have been campy fun. Unfortunately, director Pitof actually believes he is making a good movie. I find it more than a little sad that no one realized this kind of film-making is only good in cheap TV-movies. The real killer of the movie is it's reliance on bad computer effects. I've never been a fan of them in general (I think it takes more creativity to mold the effects out of real objects than to punch keys); I really hate bad effects. The one's here are the worst I have ever seen in such a high-profile, expensive movie.

reviews.review_title: Halle Berry Makes a Good Catwoman and this movie is OK
reviews.content: One of the real drawbacks of reading these comments is when you come across one of those negative people who give everything a big thumbs down and think that their personal impressions are absolutely the last word. Such is the case with "Catwoman." The snippy little nerds simply must check in with what they've heard they are supposed to feel and there they are, as expected, dutifully panning this interesting movie. Having also heard that this one is a stinker, I was pleasantly surprised. "Catwoman," with Halle Berry, ain't bad at all. Certainly, it has its flaws, most mentionable among them is its slavish loyalty to political correctness. This is a very feminist movie in which men, particularly white men, are beaten up regularly because all the bad people in the flick just happen to be white men, save one, who is a white woman (Sharon Stone). If you can get past that, Halle Berry makes a good Catwoman -- beautiful, sexy, animalistic, and fierce. The effects are well done, particularly her very cat-like movements. The plot is rather thin, but it's a comic book story, these are comic book characters, and it is reasonably entertaining, nonetheless. If you go into this movie not expecting too much, you will appreciate it more, because it's really not a bad effort. If you are in the mood for cinematic excellence, put on HUD or something like that.

reviews.review_title: The most underrated film of all time.
reviews.content: I can't understand why reviews for this film have been so bad. OK it was hardly fantastic, but but the "Razzie" was harsh. I thought the special effects were good, and despite a slightly dodgy script it was a generally good film. I thought there were very dramatic scenes. When Patience discovered her company was corrupt and "killed" by her bosses, I thought it was very atmospheric. Halle Berry played the part well, people need to accept that the wonderful performances of Julie Newmar and Eartha Kitt are in the past. It's a shame that Halle Berry may never play Catwoman again. She made the part her own and was brave enough not to be too much like previous versions of the character. With Tim Burton as director and a revamped script, Catwoman would have been a lot better and there could have been sequels.

reviews.review_title: What is wrong with you people?!
reviews.content: Why everyone hates this movie so much is really beyond me. And not just any common movie-goers, the glorified critics as well! When I first heard that Halle Berry was given a Razzie for "Catwoman", I finally admitted to myself that there is no justice in this world. If anything, Halle should have won a Golden Globe for her fantastic, charismatic role of Patience Phillips.How can you people be such hypocrites?! You all praise ridiculous superhero movies like "Hulk", "Iron Man" and "Fantastic Four", but when a strong, leading FEMALE character appears, you s*it all over it! Honestly!!!I was never a big fan of Catwoman's character, but Halle Berry has made me into one. The acting in this movie was superb, better than some of the acting that has gotten some actors their phony Oscars (isn't that right, Nicole Kidman?).The plot was not very original, I'll give you that, and there ARE some occasional clichés (toxic beauty cream being one of them), but all that falls under the amazing Halle Berry. What an actress! I've never seen an actress being so dedicated, and so comfortable in her role like she has. Halle was BORN for this role, ignore what everyone else says! Halle, honey, don't ever, EVER feel ashamed because some fat, geeky, short-sided idiots have decided to give you a Razzie! Remember, they SUCK, you ROCK!The soundtrack of this movie was also incredible! The late Natasha Schneider did a marvelous job with her song "Who's In Control?". All the other song were great too, and were the perfect choice to follow Catwoman's journey through self discovery.All in all, GREAT acting, GREAT music, SUPERB movie! Ignore every single bad review, they don't know what the f**k they are talking about!

reviews.review_title: My Eyes Won't Stop Bleeding: An Objective Review of CINO
reviews.content: Objective? Most of you who know me question how it is possible to analyze the movie objectively, considering I'm among the most vocal objectors toward the movie. Well, this is objective. I checked my brain at the door...of my room...and decided to go in ignoring the campy dialogue and the gaping plot holes. I decided to look for the good parts of the movie and gain from there my opinion of the movie.Unfortunately, there were no good parts, and my eyes bled no less than thrice per minute of mind-numbingly trite cinematic abortion. It would've hurt less to sit and watch MTV for the same length of time. At least MTV doesn't try to pretend to be some feminist statement.Anyway, for those who have only read the comics and have no clue about the movie, here's a list of things the movie has in common with the comic...and any other incarnation of the character ever to exist...:* the title.The movie opens with an ancient Egyptian map, strangely in English, followed by a quick succession of random clips of WAY MORE THAN NINE (can't even keep their own story straight) "Catwomen," with no mention of Selina at all, which is both a praiseworthy thing and a slap in the face.Patience is one of the most exaggerated, unrealistic characters I've ever had the displeasure of viewing. Nobody is that shy. Nobody is that meek. Nobody is that annoyingly stumbly, frumpy, and clutzy. And this is coming from a guy who just came back from nerd camp.And don't get me started on that gay coworker.The only believable characters in this whole mess were Benjamin Bratt as Det. Tom Lone (where do these people come up with this?) and Sharon Stone as Laurel Hedare. When I say believable, I don't mean well-acted. I mean that I could believe that I could believe that Ben Bratt was a cop and that Sharon Stone was an ex-model with a bad husband.The heavy reshoots shone through. The "HELL NO!" scene was replaced, the "Bast is hard to pronounce" and costume-making scenes were cut, and the "pussy...cats" line was cut. Unfortunately, that made about as big of a difference to the finished product as it would have to remove one hair from Halle Berry's head in a scene.Alex Borstein's character was also extremely annoying. I love the woman dearly, but she needs to make better career decisions.The camera work was excellent...for about the first four or five minutes. Then it was all over the place. I felt like an ADD kid after chugging a half-gallon of Red Bull laced with LSD. The colors were garish and the camera wouldn't stay in the same place for more than about half a second. During parts of the film, I was nauseous because the camera moved around too much. Whoever decided on that jumpy sh*t should never be allowed to work on a film again. In fact, everyone involved in the production should be forced to work the cash register at a redneck trucker stop in the middle of nowhere for the rest of their lives, except for Klaus Badelt, who is an amazing composer, Alex Borstein, who needs to go back to Family Guy NOW, Ben Bratt, who needs to go back to Law & Order NOW, and Lambert Wilson, who just needs to find a better obnoxious Frenchman part like he had in the Matrix sequels.In conclusion, it was extremely difficult not to kill myself in the face at any given point during the movie. Resisting the temptation to leap from my window when a car speeds by as to be knocked through the woods onto the highway and have my head crushed to a peaceful pulp as to rid my senses from the absolute nightmare that is Catwoman In Name Only was one of the hardest things I've ever had to do. And this is coming from the guy who laughed at the Exorcist. Whatever you do, don't see Catwoman unless you're prepared for the mental equivalent of an anal probing. And remember kids: if you go see CINO, you may be maced, by the police if not by me personally.(-27 out of 5)

Patience Philips, is a graphic designer for Hedare Beauty, a mammoth cosmetics company on the verge of releasing a revolutionary anti-ageing product. When Patience inadvertently happens upon a dark secret her employer is hiding, she finds herself in the middle of a corporate conspiracy. What happens next changes Patience forever. In a mystical twist of fate, she is transformed into a woman with the strength, speed, agility and ultra-keen senses of a cat. With her newfound prowess and feline intuition, Patience becomes Catwoman, a sleek and stealthy creature balancing on the thin line between good and bad. Like any wildcat, she's dangerous, elusive and untamed. Her adventures are complicated by a burgeoning relationship with Tom Lone, a cop who has fallen for Patience but cannot shake his fascination with the mysterious Catwoman, who appears to be responsible for a string of crime sprees plaguing the city.....Yes, catwoman is possibly one of the worst comic book movies, but it's certainly not boring, like Man Thing.Berry has slated this film on many occasion, but to be fair, Monsters Ball aside, has she really been in many great films? She is fine as the titular character, all cat like to the extreme, one minute CGI the next, a male Ballet dancer, but when it's Berry in the full get up, one cannot deny that the film is at its most watchable.But the film belongs to Stone and the Merovingian. As the main bad guys, they are absurd, one with a face like marble, one with a sneer that would make Rickman proud, but both delivering on the ham side.All in all it's a bad movie, the script Is bad, it makes no sense what so ever, and the CGI is bad, and at sometimes pointless, but it's a fun movie, with some really silly, set pieces, that make the film worthy of its camp trophy.If you want a film to laugh at, this is the one.

Warning lots of spoilers! Complete discussion of the movie ahead.For a movie about a woman that is 'tough' and 'independent' it's surprisingly sexist.Before this woman becomes catwoman she is walked all over, abused, yelled at, etc... Now, correct me if I'm wrong, in order to have such a high paying job in such a cut-throat competitive business as design you HAVE to be strong. So how did she even get the job in the first place? They explain this in the movie by saying "she just that good."OK, so basically she gets killed and magical Egyptian cats bring her back to life....so who does she fight with her new abilities? Rapists? Murders? Child molesters? No, she fights a makeup company! Oh wow, because that is all women are concerned about - make-up! Wow how sexist.Now it turns out that the wife of the head of the makeup company is covering up the whole 'this new makeup is toxic' thing. And had to kill Patience Phillips/Catwoman since she found out about it. IF the guy switched roles with his wife, this movie would have been much improved.At this point it would have been a STRONG feminist statement about how men pressure women into looking good. But when it's the woman who is the bad guy it sort of makes no sense. I did like the statement she said in the movie though "I'm a woman I'm used to doing things I don't want to do."But why would she not just tell the media about the fact that the make-up is toxic and that she needs to use it to stay alive. I'm sure they would allow it. This makes women seem stupid, selfish, vain, etc. Also the fact that she confessed to the cop was rather silly, again making women look stupid.Another sexist thing about the movie was catwoman herself. She basically was not independent at all as the movie stated. If anything she was helping the cop the whole time to crack the case. She was ANSWERING TO A MAN! Sexist....Also how can you fight in such an outfit? Most women wear more than that and are afraid of a 'wardrobe malfunction.' Also her shoes were open toe! And they were flimsy heels. The outfit simply objectified her. Sad that she seemed to be more empowered before she became catwoman, she wore what she pleased.Michelle Pfeiffer as catwoman in Batman Returns (1992) did a better job. Since SHE was in control of what SHE wanted and did not let MEN boss her around. In addition she was in control of her own sexuality. Since SHE came onto batman. Whereas with this catwoman the guy makes the first move, and she is all fawning over him. Wow very sexist....Oh, her friend is ALSO shown as vein. As she wears that toxic make-up that is causing her to be sick. And every other minute she is trying to make men fall for her. There are literally NO positive representations of females in a movie apparently about women 'taking charge'! Sharon Stone's character is shown as a vain, greedy, lying, selfish, stupid. Alex Borstein's character is shown as a dumb, man-obsessed doofus. Halle Berry's character is shown as a male puppet/play thing. And Frances Conroy plays a crazy cat lady! While all the men are totally innocent, calm, cool, and collected. Wow, just wow.

reviews.review_title: Great ideas but too little value to outweigh such blunt tactlessness
reviews.content: There comes a point where simply reading about cinematic infamy isn't enough, and you have to see it for yourself. 'Ishtar,' 'North,' and 'Showgirls' are all sad examples, and Pitof's much-maligned adaptation of a beloved comic book character is another. Before even watching the movie proper there's a lot to think about, and setting aside the end result, I appreciate the thought and effort that went into this. Myths, legends, and folklore from across all eras and cultures have centered around that truly superior terrestrial life form, the cat; this character is nothing if not an easy symbol for female empowerment, individuality, and a fight against oppressive systems. The writers try to play with these ideas in part, and also weave in themes of extreme corporate and capitalist malfeasance, and sexism. I admire the notion of protagonist Patience being effectively transformed as she takes on a new persona, going from meek and nervous to confident and brash; I take no issue with the way this rendition of a classic character is separated from the wider lore in which she's otherwise based - I see no reason why such a figure couldn't be treated as her very own person. Angus Strathie's guiding tack behind the infamous costume makes perfect sense to me. All this is well and good. And none of it saves 'Catwoman' from the significant problems that weigh it down and have helped it to earn a label as one of the worst films ever made.There is a tawdry, dire, overbearing, excruciating lack of tact or nuance characterizing this feature. There's a false, waxy sheen layered over the fundamental image; every instance of CGI is simply unbearable, including not least that first moment when our protagonist has her "awakening," and too many illustrations of her "powers." That CGI, the cinematography, the editing, and a great deal of the writing and direction - dialogue, scenes, characters, plot development, and so on - are forthright, over the top, and even overzealous to the point of being not fun, but hopelessly tacky. This also applies to any action sequences, filled with zip, zest, bombast, style, and a transparent intended "cool factor," but also invariably tiresome for lack of any dynamics or subtlety. There are actually some really terrific ideas here, including the concept of Patience taking on feline traits and behavior, and these lend themselves to genuine delight and laughter at times. The fact that such wit and humor feels kind of out of place in an action flick, well, that's highly unfortunate. I like that Catwoman's fighting style is informed by capoeira, seen far too little in film or TV, but again the issue of how action sequences are orchestrated. I don't think Strathie's costume design or the work of the hair and makeup artists are inherently bad; I think their contributions, like all else here, were guided to the seediest, most blunt, most kitschy, and irritating ends they could be. Even the music, both Klaus Badelt's score and select songs on the soundtrack, are fine in and of themselves, but employed to ends that are actively irritating and far too on the nose.The production design and art direction range from earnestly fetching to excessive. For the most part I think the cast is fine, and in the very least they try to imbue their performances with sincerity that is generally far too lacking in the proceedings. All the same, there's a tinge of inauthenticity in the acting, even from the likes of Frances Conroy, Lambert Wilson, or Sharon Stone, that I can only assume is owed to the senseless overcooked ethos that defines every last element. And as for Halle Berry, well... In some moments we see the refined personality, range, and otherwise skills that we know she possesses and has demonstrated elsewhere to great success. In some moments she's at least clearly having a good time. In too many others, however, Berry is overacting with a frenetic, overcharged bluster that's just plain outrageous. Sure, we can chalk this up in part to the way Catwoman is written in the first place, and above all Pitof's direction and the overall slant of the production are a predominant factor. Still, she leans so hard into the dishonest swagger that she becomes a controlling focal point of it - its victim, to some extent, but just as surely its driving force in some measure. Golly, is this regrettable.Have I mentioned the picture's embrace of forensic pseudoscience, the favored instrument of crime shows on TV and untrustworthy state agents in real life? Have I mentioned the significant practice here of the male gaze at every opportunity - never sexy, only ever sleazy - into which the final look of Strathie's design directly feeds? The root concept of every component part is at least baseline suitable, if not also inventive, clever, and or smart. For lack of mindful care, however, or perspective, there is glaringly, appallingly little about this that actually comes off well. Through to the very end this is too often altogether boorish or obnoxious, and far too little entertaining. What kernels of value it can claim aren't nearly enough to rise above the overwhelming crudeness and bawdiness of what it ultimately represents. It turns out that 2004's 'Catwoman' really is That Bad.I see what it could have been. That is it not what it is. I'm glad for those who do get more out of this than me or many others. Unless you have a special reason to watch, however, then Pitof's 'Catwoman' is a feature that's best left to that wing of the vaults that no one talks about.

reviews.review_title: Flawed but very enjoyable none the less
reviews.content: I really enjoyed Catwoman, I think Haley did a great job with what she was given. She was completely believable and I thought she played the emotions perfectly. Haley is totally sexy and does her best with every role she plays. Unfortunately it's the lack of quality material given to her that makes her seem less than perfect. I totally blame the writers of the movie for not realizing the potential of what this movie could have been. I was disappointed with the many goofs that were so completely obvious. Every time I've watched the movie and with different people, someone always seems to point out the obvious goofs. It's a shame that more care wasn't put into the writing, filming and editing of the movie. Still I love watching Catwoman just to see Haley play a such a vixen.

Before viewing this film I noticed a one (1) star next to the listing of Catwoman and I immediately realized I was in for a big disappointment. However, this is an entertaining film and I was completely surprised at seeing Sharon Stone, (Laurel Hedare) appearing in this film and I was not quite sure if this was really her because she looked entirely different in appearance. Halle Berry, (Patience Phillips/Catwoman) did a great job of trying to perform her role as a cat and I must say a very sexy, hot, naughty pussy cat. If you like cats you just might enjoy this film and finding out some of the deep dark story's concerning how the cats were worshiped years ago in Eygpt.

There's really not much to say. everything in this movie is bad. including one of the worst lines in movie history:bad guy: "game over"
catwoman: "guess what? it's overtime"ROFLthis movie is not difficult to watch. i had a great time with it. laughed hysterically in multiple scenes. 8/10 on the hilariocity scale (2 viewings, 6/5/2020)

reviews.review_title: I Really Wish This Was Better
reviews.content: Big Batman fan, and comic book movie fan in general. Also, Helle Berry is so hot, how could you go wrong with a movie like this? Well, somehow they found a way. The story and acting were pretty bad. Overall, not a horrible movie, definitely watchable for Halle alone. If they put some more money and effort into this, it could have been one of my favorites.This movie was pretty close to being a good story. It's just barely good enough that you will get disappointed when it turns bad. If a movie doesn't try to have a good story in the first place, then it doesn't leave you disappointed like this one.They should have just given up trying to make this a respectable movie, and focused more on giving us some sweet screenshots of Halle doing her thing, whatever that might be.

I wasn't expecting much out of Catwoman, having heard it was abysmal. I only decided to watch it because I was recovering from surgery and needed something mindless. Perhaps that's why I was able to enjoy it. I mean, it is a terrible movie, the script is somewhat incoherent, the dialog is ludicrous and the special effects are silly rather than cool. But it is also a movie that is rather amusing, sometimes on purpose, more often by accident, and it moves pretty quickly. It's certainly more entertaining than The Incredible Hulk, which is an example of a bad movie that doesn't even manage to be any fun.The general incompetence of almost every aspect of the film can at times bring it close to the level of an Ed Wood movie, but alas the film lacks Wood's pretensions to greatness, and rarely is so bad as to be laugh out loud funny (although it does happen a couple of times). The movie also manages a few legitimate laughs. So all in all, while I wouldn't want to watch it again, I don't regret watching it once.Still, this must be the worst portrayal of Cat Woman. The most interesting conceptually was probably Michelle Pfeiffer in Batman Returns, even though I didn't think much of the movie, but for me catwoman will always be the fabulous Julie Newmar from the TV series.

OK, so it's not Oscar material, and it won't be a landmark among superhero movies either, and yes the story was pretty lame. That said I see people pouring stars out over crappy movies all the time, so why hate this one so much ? Hell, I just spent 1 1/2 hour watching Halle Berry jumping around in sexy leathers looking hot and kicking butt. And while i agree that it was a complete waste of her talent, even talented actors need to make a living, and she probably got paid well. I sometimes wonder what exactly people expect from these movies. When i go to see a superhero Flick I rarely have any expectations at all, except hoping to be entertained, and this one passed the time nicely. Meaning that i didn't feel the urge to leave at any point. I've wasted time on much worse than this, And Halle, you're one damn hot feline !

I love it when a Hollywood studio makes a flick based on a comic/novel then hires writers who not only are completely void of talent but also completely ignorant of the character they are writing about. I can almost see how you could have a Catwoman movie w/o the Batman but to completely ignore 95% of the canon from the comics is just amazing. I can't believe Hollywood makes dreck like this and then blames people not paying $10 a head to see it on internet piracy. The only reason I watched it was because I heard what a train wreck it was and it was showing on HBO. The costumes, writing, and of course the acting are all horrendous. I could just see Sharon and Halle balancing their checkbook in the back of their minds as they reeled off some of the most banal dialog ever to grace celluloid. Not really even entertaining as "Mystery Science Theater" fodder because although it's terrible, there was not as much unintentional comedy as I expected. Save your time, save your brain cells. Skip it!

Catwoman (2004) (Mild Spoilers)1: I actually saw the movie. 2: I do not hate nor do i love Halle Berry. 3: I don't care that Michelle Pfeiffer wasn't in this movie, although she is great, she is a bit long in the tooth now for the role. 3: I don't think it's necessary to have Batman in the movie. 4: I don't care that the movie doesn't follow the comic book. 5: I will judge this movie based on it's own merits and not from some prejudice for or against Halle Berry.I think the movie was very good and is what it should be, a fun summer action movie. Some say Halle Berry can't act, whatever the truth is, Halle is the Catwoman in this movie and plays her part very well. The same goes for Sharon Stone who has been leveled with the same criticism, Sharon is an evil villainess and her character is fun to hate.What i loved the best about this movie was the action. The action is beautifully choreographed, the fight scenes were energetic and exciting. I loved the little cat and mouse encounter between Catwoman and the detective Tom Lone (Benjamin Bratt) as he was trying to apprehend her. As well as the vicious encounter between Catwoman and Laurel Hedare (Sharon Stone).It is a revenge movie which is a favorite kind of movie for me. Halle Berry plays timid Patience Phillips who is murdered after hearing something she shouldn't have. After coming back to life with the aid of a cat, she seeks revenge.I love the assertive Catwoman in the sexy leather who doesn't take crap from people. And this Catwoman truly is a Catwoman. Unlike Pfeiffer who was a woman with catlike movements, Unlike Peter Parker who is a man with spider abilities, and unlike Batman who is a man in a bat costume, Halle is a blend between a cat and a woman.I like that this movie takes place in a normal looking modern city and not some plastic looking Gotham city. It made it easier for me to relate to and also easier for me to accept the fantasy aspects of the movie.I think the movie is getting an undeserved bad rap. I've read a lot of bad reviews/opinions from those who haven't seen the movie based on negative personal feelings they have against Halle. That's too bad.

I wasn't expecting a lot (especially since I saw some early reviews of it) but I didn't think the movie was that bad. In the back of my mind, I kept thinking about "Daredevil" and how parts of that movie just didn't work, didn't make sense, people didn't behave in that movie like people do. ("Hey, I'm hot, you're hot and we just met. Let's fight each other!") None of those flags came up during this movie.I thought Halle Berry did a fine job and that she was smokin' in that outfit. The CG didn't really bother me either; cats move very quickly and I thought they captured that.I did think the man-hungry girlfriend got a little tiresome after a while but she didn't bother me too much.Overall I would give it a 5 or a 6 out of 10.

Patience Phillips (Halle Berry) is a meek, mild-mannered woman working in the advertising department of a cosmetics firm. One night, she sees and overhears something she wasn't meant to. The company's new line causes horrible scarring after extended use. Patience is killed because of what she learned. However, she is brought back to life by an Egyptian cat and granted many cat-like powers. She decides to use these powers to discover who killed her and put a stop to the company she once worked for.I knew of Catwoman's horrible reputation, but didn't really believe it could be that bad. I mean, squeezing the gorgeous Halle Berry into skin-tight leather should set you up for some thrills. Unfortunately, there's not a costume on Earth that could have saved this mess of a movie. Almost everything (the lone exception being some scenes with Halle Berry and Benjamin Bratt - I enjoyed the chemistry) is a disaster. The plot is paper thin, the baddies are weak, the acting is poor, the attempts at comedy are cringey, and the dialogue is silly. But as bad as all that is, nothing compares with the wretched special effects. I thought the CG cat looked horrible (and why use a CG cat anyway?), but then i saw the CG Halle Berry. I'm sure a small fortune was spent on these effects. What a waste! The shots of Adam West "climbing" buildings in the 1960s-era Batman TV show are more believable. It's just pathetic.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as critics would lead you to believe!
reviews.content: After reading so many horrendous reviews, both here on this website and in various newspapers, I had decided to pass on watching this film. However, a friend lent it to me, so I decided to take a peek. You know, this film is not bad at all! Halle Berry plays Patience Phillips, a shy, quiet girl who works in advertising for a large cosmetics company. One night, she stumbles upon some shocking news about her employers, who rid of her by murder. However, the cats of the city breathe new life into Patience, making her into Catwoman. Now, Patience/Catwoman prowls the city, looking for the people that killed her.Sure, the story is thin, plus, some of the lines are total cheese. Also, some of the special effects are way too CGI and are extremely laughable. Even though there are these faults, the film is still a fun time waster! It is not an Academy Award winner by any means, but in my humble opinion, is a great way to waste away an hour and forty minutes.The last few Batman films were awful, this film is much better than those. If you are a fan of comic book style action, do not let this one pass you by! It is one fun ride! Plus, Halle Berry looks simply purr-fect in those leather pants.

I was looking forward to watching this movie precisely because of bad critics and ratings. Pretty often I find myself enjoying movies that are bashed by majority. Especially when it comes to superhero movies, because, although I love superheroes, I find the way they make movies about them incredibly stupid. The biggest blockbusters of this genre were lame to me, so I honestly expected to enjoy the movie that is hated by the people who love movies I hate. It's hard to describe my disappointment. If I start analyzing everything wrong with this movie it would last longer than movie itself, so it's much more efficient if I simply make a list of things that are not bad and you can assume everything else is bad. Here's the list:1. Movie is not boring.End of the list.4,5/10I'm fascinated by the list of it's awards and nominations:Dallas-Fort Worth Film Critics Association - Worst Film
