reviews.review_title: This film is not that bad
reviews.content: Enjoyment can be had when watching this film. Its often very funny, possibly when it isn't supposed to be funny, but who cares where the humour stems from at least its there. If this film had been done more as a pastiche than a serious superhero film, it may have survived a little better. Shot like an extra long music video, the film does have some decent directorial ideas, but they just don't come through. Pitof puts some great angles in, and often has some flair for imagination, but to often the film chops and changes set pieces and moves at such a pace that you have no time to take in the fact that the film is actually quite pretty.The script and storyline are just terrible. Whoever is responsible should never write ever again. Killer face cream... enough said. Sharon Stone and Halle Berry do well with the little characterisation they're given. Had this been a showdown between Michelle Pfeiffers Catwoman and Sharon Stones Katherine Tramell I can't help think this film may have been a hit.Its a real shame that this film just didn't go correctly. It is my belief that Catwoman is a great Superhero/Villain and I think if done correctly it could be great, but until then sit back, relax and take in this Catwomans absurdities. It's not good, however it is watchable.Halle Berrys Razzie win does seem a little extreme, though her acceptance speech is brilliant.

reviews.review_title: An attempt to sink Halle Berry's career
reviews.content: It's defined as a star vehicle. If you really like the star, you'll somehow watch most, or all of it. Bad script that is hard to hear at times. Banter that makes Hollywood irritating. But it's a dc comic and I like watching Halle Berry. She is unofficially assigned to de-corrupt a cosmetics company she works for. If you know the dc legend comic, you know how she gets started. Hollywood pretty much leans lazily upon the comics, here. If it wasn't for Halle's performance, I wouldn't be able to watch half of it. It's not fair to compare this to Pfeiffer's because she did no stand-alone. But you know hollywood. If Berry was in the Batman with Keaton, it would have been Star Wars 4. They don't try to give good scripts to Berry. But they always give good scripts to Pfeiffer. Also spoiled by the emotional romance of the first part of the 1987 cbs tv Beauty and The Beast series, I'm jolted back into reality, by the usual stalker-ish sex lust chase that most men writers admit they are into as the detective gets an attempt at an escape from his wham bam, mam, with Patience, through a phone call to her, while she looks for him. This movie would have gotten a zero rating, here, if Halle wasn't in it- a one, because of the rules. This movie doesn't use a sledgehammer but does effectively truth about unfair treatment of women, (in the justice system and society at large, and the propensity for both to lean on circumstantial evidence, more than hard evidence), with Halle and Stone, leading the charge.When this movie was released in 2004, the majority of the official reviewers were men. It was a tough time for Janet Jackson, and a lot of the reviews seemed to be of a sexual nature because of Berry's outfits. Objectivity was lacking and this script made it all too easy for that combination to result in disrespect in official reviews. Negative reviews are expected with a mostly bad script but this was another level. They seemed eager to give her a razzie. This reviewer was ashamedly influenced by the bad press but didn't know about the razzie. 2022 was the first viewing and razzie knowledge. Good thing there is streaming. The carry of Halle outweighs the script cringe and it's closer to catching up to Spider man 2 by Raimi, than official critics would like to admit.

Catwoman is based on the DC comics and is a villain in Batman and tells the tale of a young woman named Patience Philips(yeah what a name eh)played by Halle Berry(from X Men fame)who is a timid introverted designer who works in a beauty company owned by Sharon Stone who finds a secret revolving on a new make up brand that is an anti ageing cream. But when Patience finds out about the hidden secrets in the new cream she ends up getting murdered and is brought back to life by cats....YES CGI cats that scrap her and she turns into Catwoman. With her new persona she fights crime and falls for a detective played by Benjamin Bratt(from Miss Congenailty).Overall this film isn't that good. It won a Razzie Award for worst film and part of me actually enjoyed it but its no Spiderman 2 or X Men 2.3/10D+

I will not lie and say this was the best film ever. It certainly has its flaws, and it is not for the comic book purist who wishes to see a film about Selina Kyle, the Catwoman we all know and love (or hate.) However, Batman Returns was not true to Selina's origin, either, yet people loved it. Catwoman tells the story of the NEXT woman to wear the mantle, the next to be revived from death by a feline friend. While in Batman Returns, it was made to seem strange but semi-mundane, in Catwoman, it is purely mystical. In effect, Catwoman is the semi-sequel they promised us way back in 1992.I promised myself, when I heard the plot, heard what was being done with the Catwoman franchise, that I would not watch this movie... But, being incredibly bored and at a video store at 11pm causes lots of strange things. For that reason, I purchased this movie.If you can separate that this is not about the comic character, has NOTHING to do with her any more than the mousy blonde Selina Kyle of Batman Returns has to do with the vivacious green eyed brunette that normally goes by that name, you're on the first step to enjoying the movie.I won't lie. It certainly has many flaws, including the incessant need to include a love interest, some mediocre acting on the part of Halle's fellow cast members... and a REALLY bad mask/design for the costume.The plot is mediocre. Art designer goes to deliver latest layout for her ads, stumbles upon big corporate secret, is chased around scary warehouse, only to be killed. Her body, washed up on a nearby shore after she drowns (in sewage, no less) is revived by a mystical messenger of the goddess Bast. Adjusting to her new powers, Patience has some adventures and some amusing scenes, in which Halle Berry shows off a decent understanding of cat behavior. (Owning four, I must say, she pulled it off pretty well, as I found myself thinking of mine.) She then goes after the people that 'killed' her (sound familiar?) and the movie continues in a rather cliché fashion.Despite this, I enjoyed it. It kept my attention, without keeping me glued to my seat (I have a bit of a short attention span, admittedly, and normally get up a LOT during movies. I only paused and got up twice.) If you like action films that are action films with only basic plot, this film's for you. If you like girl power films where women kick ass, this film's for you. If you like strange costumes that no sane woman would wear to kick ass IN? This film's for you. It's not a masterpiece, and they relied too much on CGI (specifically, around Sharon Stone, because she was injured on the set when a real whip was used) but no film is perfect. While I wouldn't say it ranks up with Spider-Man or X-Men, or any of the new hero movies, I would definitely rank it above Daredevil or either of the Tomb Raider films.To those who are comic purists (like myself) and resent the way that the movies have influenced the comics, remember that Catwoman is an Elseworlds story, and, if they had billed it as something else entirely, rather than Catwoman, it would have been a big comic book fan hit.All in all, it's not great, but it doesn't deserve the crap it's gotten for it, even from me, in the past.

I've always heard how bad this movie was. During the first few minutes, I was agreeing with that, but I was forgetting one thing. I knew it was possible to play an awkward, bumbling character and still be giving a good performance (since we're dealing with superheroes, look at Christopher Reeve's Clark Kent--NOT Dean Cain or Tom Welling). I just didn't think the Oscar-winning Halle Berry was giving us that. Well, I finally had to conclude she was.After all, look at what a fantastic job Berry did as Catwoman. So much more confident, so tough, a good fighter, and she moved so much like a cat. And ate like a cat. I wasn't quite satisfied with her Eartha Kitt impression, but only Eartha Kitt was PURRfect saying that word.So what else could have been wrong with the movie? Maybe it was trying to be a romantic comedy and an action adventure and failing at both? It was trying to be both, but that didn't bother me. I liked Benjamin Bratt and Halle Berry together. And what happened when he found out why she was behaving the way she was.It wasn't long before I realized the standout performer in this movie (at least before Catwoman) was Alex Borstein as Patience's friend Sally. If someone is that good, how can it be a bad movie?The cats were ... weird. But pretty. Particularly the one who made Patience's life change. It was obvious those weren't always real cats, but the animators or whoever they were did a good job. Crazy Cat Lady was also good. I don't remember her name now.Sharon Stone (who I didn't recognize) also did a good job. It helps if your character is also trying to convince people you are something you're not.One thing I didn't care for was the music. You have to figure either Berry liked this music or her fans did. The music at her neighbors' apartment wasn't good either. I did like seeing her finally resolve that problem.Yes, I've seen better action movies. Yes, this one could be silly. But it wasn't a bad movie.

reviews.review_title: Well it's been 16 years but hear we go
reviews.content: Have you ever seen I so bad it's good film....this isn't one of them this is better. Good for drinking games and that's about it. Or maybe..maybe when you have a really bad hangover and you need something easy to digest and maybe have a nap to. It's bad and has the brains of a Teletubby. But I've seen it twice and ill probably see it again in the next 20 years. If it's on the tv and I've got a hangover where I want to kill myself. And if you just wanna see Hallie berry in leather just watch swordfish it's probably just as bad but at least you see....well you know. Anyway give it a go if your the 1% that hasn't seen it. Hahahahahahahahahahahaha Hahahahahahahahahahaha. Hahahahahahaahhahahahaha lol lol lmao

So I went to see Catwoman on opening night with a friend and was so worried that we were about to walk into an empty theater.  After all, everyone has pretty much dissed the movie without even seeing it.  Havent we learned that trailers dont always tell us everything??  Well much to my surprise the theater was packed!  All ages in fact!  I was so excited to see there were others like me who were just as thrilled to finally see Catwoman on the screen!  I really enjoy the movie a lot.  Dont get me wrong, its no Batman but I thought it was a great new take on a classic DC comics character.  I do have to admit that it did have a slow start and there's way to many CG effects through out the film.   But other than that, Halle Berry did an awesome job as did Sharon Stone playing her nemesis.  I dont know if this film will produce any sequels but even if it doesnt, I still think its a great film that should be looked at with more of an open mind.  Even if you dont like it.... at least you can admit Halle looks great in leather! Overall, this is a fun and fast paced popcorn flick that leaves you wishing you could see more of her adventures...hopefully we will!!!

i hadn't seen catwoman until recently and the reason I avoided it like poison is because all the reviews I had read on it labelled it at a terrible film. Besides that I have a personal dislike for these comic-book based films, the only ones I like are the X-men films (whereas both Spider-man's bored me to death and the hulk made me lose faith in the way movies are written). However, boredom can drive people to doing strange and mysterious things, so when I was channel flicking, catwoman was just starting so I thought "what the heck!" and watched it.First of all, the acting in this film is very campy and over the top, but then it was much better than I expected! Halle Berry does what she can with her character, but Sharon Stone made the movie for me! Stone is deliciously bitchy and evil which just works for me. Benjamin Bratt also does well with what he is given (i.e playing possibly the worst detective in movie history). I think Laurel and Hardy would make better detectives! The story is your basic super-hero plot. Weak but generally nice person has some sort of accident and is fused with animal/mutant powers and thus decides that saving the world from evil is the best career choice from now on. However our intrepid hero is misunderstood by the general public (surprise surprise) and is labelled a criminal.Overall the film is silly but I rather enjoyed it! Who knows maybe you will too!!

Wow...Where to even start? I mean...I heard this movie was bad, but I heard the same thing about "Daredevil," and ended up thinking that movie wasn't so bad. I heard the same thing about "Surviving Christmas" and that it was actually pretty cute. Same with "The Punisher," but I think that movie was awesome. So...as a comic book movie lover...I took a chance and rented this last night.Whoa! Holy Awful!! lol...Horrible special effects in most places! Horrible plot filled with every cliché in the book...not to mention stupid one liners galore. I'll admit, there were a FEW creative shots, or ideas in this movie, but those are totally ruined by how bad it is! I wanted to shut it off, but sheer morbid curiosity kept me watching - just to see how bad it could get. I actually felt bad for Halley Barry...watching her act like a cat...smear catnip all over her face or eat with no table manners. Hahah...way to make the heroine into the biggest joke of all time! This movie is Mystery Science Theater 3000 bad. Watch at your own risk only when you've earned a free movie rental.

"Catwoman" is one of those movies which have such a bad reputation that you just have to watch them to see how bad they really are. To be honest I didn't find this "piece of cat litter" that horrible (After all, I gave it four out of ten), but it is very disappointing considering the people who worked on it."Vidocq", the previous film by Pitof, was quite a refreshing piece of old-fashioned mystery and thriller. Above all else, it was visually stunning and very vibrant. "Catwoman" also looks very sleek, but there just isn't enough substance. The whole plot is ridiculous and so simple it could've been written by school kids (Halle's transformation into Catwoman doesn't make much sense). On the performance side there's not much to say either. I think Halle is a fine actress, but here she just mews stupid one-liners like "Cat got your tongue?" (for some reason she reminds me of Arnold in "Batman & Robin"... weird, I know). And her controversial dress, well, let's just say Michelle Pfeiffer did it better in 1992. Sharon Stone, another okay actress when given proper material, goes totally over-the-top which is not a good thing, at least not in this case.I would say "Catwoman" is worth just a rental, it isn't the most horrible film in the world but it certainly isn't good either. For a better "Catwoman" experience get "Batman Returns" with Michelle Pfeiffer.

reviews.review_title: An Example of how to do it NOT
reviews.content: Films like these, made by advertisement specialists, live through their visuals, but in this case even the pictures don't succeed, let alone the story. The script, mainly mirroring Patience' (Halle Berrys) transition to the ultra cool superhero, is superficial to say the least. The characters come from the handbook "How to make film without lots of surprises", changing "without lots of" to "with no". It looks that no one in the production team cared about the quality of the movie as a whole. Some clichés are so predictable that it's hard to stand even for admirers of Berry (who is allowed to present her physical attributes, but even that doesn't save it). Catwoman is a film that, when accidentally stopped during the screening, would hardly leave anyone to beg for continuing. A film every future director should see  look it up under file "How to do it not".

Only thing to remember: Halle Berry got a Razzie for it, AND PICKED THAT ONE UP IN PERSON.This movie may be derided by critics, and those fancying themselves critics and comics- purists, but that showing of steel cojones on Miss Berry is a redemption on it's own!It's always a bit sad to see a movie becoming "the most hated" as a sort of trope, because tons of pretentious hipsters feel peer-pressure to fall in-line. And especially hating on Miss Berry seems to be the norm. Blame her interpretation of Storm/Ororo Munroe, I guess. I'm no fan of that too, to be frank.Back to Catwoman.This movie isn't half as bad as it may seem from the spitting-foaming-at-the-mouth-angry reviews here&there. It's no Citizen Cane, no doubt there, but it has a charming, campy over-acted quirky-ness far too often missing from the current glut of taking-themselves-far-too-serious Super Hero movies. In some instances I felt an undertone of the Batman series of the 60's. Shame that the filmmakers were a tad too fearful to go that way. It's unpretentious fun, a bit of an enjoyable power-trip where a meek, mousy girl/woman suddenly becomes this super-powered creature, oozing sensuality. Don't lie to me Ladies (and gents)! A lot of You have -secretly- dreamt of something like that happening to You.The sheer derision, and fulminating spit-attacks towards cat-woman are more telling of the type of people perpetrating them, than of the actual quality of this movie.Honesty forces me to admit that I wouldn't go to a theater for it, but as a Bargain-bin DVD, to be watched while enjoying a beer and the company of friends? Not bad, not bad at all.I'd classify it as an enjoyable made-for-TV type of flick. The CGI Is dated by now, true. Same goes for the way writers ignored the "pure" Catwoman canon, but it's 10 years old by now (!) and at that time the Super-Hero genre was not as established as it is nowadays.I feel that -would a comparable movie be made nowadays- the public and critics would be far more forgiving, no longer having the fear of being considered a freak for liking the whole crazy, odd Super Powered Super Hero genre.No, it stìll wouldn't be Citizen Kane, but it would not have been slammed with mud like it was in 2004.

reviews.review_title: A Great Comic Book Film Beyond Measure. *Extreme Sarcasm*
reviews.content: Catwoman is so poetic in its oblivious nature in that Halle Berry's nuanced performance has indescribable subtlety, like a train wreck. The plot is SO smart and the screenplay has great execution and it's full of intellectual subtext, like Battlefield Earth. The direction is perfectly done and has the depth and emotion of The Bold and the Beautiful. This movie is so self-indulgent and oblivious to the clichés spewing all around and WHAT WERE THEY THINKING?!?! This movie is to superhero films what Howard the Duck is to Marvel's Captain America: Civil War.So do yourself a favor and stay the hell away from this piece of sh!t.

And it sucks big time. Sorry...What should I begin with? I mean, I have to explain why is this movie such an awful piece of *censored*. Well...Let me start with the only good thing about the movie. It is Sharon Stone. I have never liked her but here she fits her role perfectly. It is not enough to make the movie watchable but still it made me rate it 2/10 rather than 1/10. I guess it is something...Now the bad things... Everything else... Halle Berry is an awful actress. I know, she won "Oscar" for some other role but, well, she is an awful actress. All she had to do is to look sexy and she failed miserably. She is a beautiful woman and yet she looks quite ugly here. It wasn't due to her make up or something, she just walks ugly and acts ugly. Her moves remind me more of an ill monkey than a cat or whatever animal she was supposed to look like. Her walk makes her look drunk constantly. I can't even remember the way she talked. I don't remember even the name of her character. Yes, she is THAT faceless.Pitof is an awful director. 'Vidocq' was one of the most painful movie experiences I have ever had and this movie is even worse. Pitof has no sense of pacing, he can't direct anything... He may be good at doing visual effects but that's not enough. You need a real directing talent to do a watchable action movie. If you don't have it...The stunts are awful. Badly shot and badly choreographed and it is quite obvious that Berry used a stunt double.The story is even worse than the stunts. I don't want to explain why, you just have to believe me.That is it.

This one tries extremely hard to be campy, but as it turns out it's just very bad and nothing more. I wanted to laugh, but I couldn't because it was all just so pathetic. The director is an easy target here, especially because for some reason he likes to call himself "Pitof", but really it's not all his fault. The action (the only thing directors with one name care about) is actually filmed rather competently, it's just everything in and around in that makes me cringe. Halle Berry's performance is just miserable. She's a good actress, she's great at emoting, she's great at portraying complex characters, too bad for her this movie doesn't require any of that. This movie requires someone that can make these one-liners sound cool, and that's really not Berry's cup of tea. It all just feels so extremely awkward. It's a bad sign when Sharon Stone's outplaying you. An even bigger thorn in the eye is the screenplay though because seriously, what is this crap? Even if you forget about the plot, these lines are just so incredibly bad. I can't believe they found actual people willing to say them. This movie has little redeeming qualities, and is in fact a total disaster.

For me the movie has a distinct charm. I love comic book characters, and I am not hung up on the villain or the story or anything else... this movie is more artistic than logical, just let it flow.I what I am hung up on though is the charisma of Catwoman and her journey becoming what she meant to be. I can't get enough, and Halle Berry delivers a stunning woman turned catwoman.Just let yourself enjoy the ride and enjoy the beautiful pictures and music.

reviews.review_title: Catwoman is actually a good movie
reviews.content: Of course, I am prejudiced, because I just love to see Halle Barry, but the movie is in fact good.The story was nice and the acting was also nice. If there's one thing that could have been better, than this was the CGI of the cat Midnight. There are some parts where it is clear to see that it is CGI. But that doesn't make the movie bad.In the past I have see many actresses playing Catwoman. Michelle Pfeiffer was good, but Halle barry is absolutely the best.The rating should definitely be a 6.5 or higher. Definitely not lower...

reviews.review_title: The Cinematic Equivalent of Cleaning A Cat's Litter Box
reviews.content: The year is 2004.Marvel has for the past few years at this point been carving a path in the live action sub-genre of superhero entertainment with X-Men, Spider-Man, and Hulk.DC, their eternal rival, decides its safe to try again with another live action outing after spending seven years in shameful hibernation following 1997's infamous Batman and Robin nearly putting the entire genre into a permanent ice age.Now, do they actually try and put their best foot forward this time around?No, instead of offering a healthy challenge to the likes of Spider-Man 2, (which coincidentally dropped nearly a month before Catwoman did in the 2004 summer blockbuster season) DC and Warner Bros instead don't even try to meet the already high bar set by the former and instead opt to wallow about in their messy putrid smelling litterbox content with waiting for relatively then unknown director Christopher Nolan to come through with a much needed palette cleanser the following summer called Batman Begins.From what I understand, a Catwoman movie idea had been shopped around since the mid 90's, but back then, nothing really came of it.A regrettable decision it was that DC and Warner Bros decided to quickly throw together what we would ultimately receive instead rather than cull the idea entirely since nothing good can come of impulsive decision making.The film begins in medias res with a zombified Halle Berry floating aimlessly underwater informing us that the day she died is the day she began to live.Actually scratch that, it actually begins with some shots of Egyptian art making sure to emphasize not only the importance of cats in the ancient civilization, but also women who looked like cats?Cut to Selina Ky- I mean "Patience Philips", a meek-hearted frumpy looking woman who works as a graphic designer for a make-up company who unsurprisingly turn out to be the villains of the movie and are working on a new skin foundation product that makes your face rot if you stop using it!Yeah, the FDA, FBI, and all the proper legal channels would immediately have pounced on the operation the moment the first lawsuit was filed!Therefore, Catwoman doesn't need even need to exist in this universe given the fact not even one Batman villain is so much as hinted throughout the film.Buuuuuttt...DC and Warner Bros clearly thought otherwise since Philips finds out what shady dealings her place of employment are up to and gets killed off for her troubles only to be revived by having CGI cats breath on her namely one of whom she attempted to rescue earlier.No, I'm not kitten you.This is even brought up later when Philips meets up with some nutty cat lady who explains her trying to rescue the aforementioned cat earlier was all a test to see if she were worthy of becoming the latest in a long line of Catwomen.Catwomen who...act like cats...*sigh*I'd watch Nyan Neko Sugar Girls if I wanted to see cat girls get in touch with their feline side.The rest of the movie doesn't fare much better between action scenes that have so many freaking cuts you'd think the director was a big stupid monkey smacking the "Cut" shortcut on the keyboard in frustration because nobody gave him a banana smoothie that day and dialogue so cliched and so corny, it makes the film feel like a spiritual successor to Batman and Robin!On a slightly positive note, Halle Berry does look attractive in this movie after she embraces her Catwoman identity though her choice of costume is questionable to say the least considering the fact earlier in the film, she wore something much closer to her comic book counterpart's outfit during a bank robbery scene before deciding afterwards that her character was apparently heading to an S and M themed costume night at the local club.And despite some chemistry cliched as it is between her and Not-Batman being built up throughout the film, Catwoman ultimately doesn't get with him instead choosing to further pursue being an anti heroine for...reasons?This film does have some merit in a So Bad, It's Good kind of way and is great fun watching it with like minded peers during a bad movie night.Still, it has its place in history as being so bad it was all DC and Warner Bros could do to let Christopher Nolan take the wheel for a while with his critically acclaimed Dark Knight Trilogy in addition to souring Hollywood on the idea of female led superhero flicks for a time until thirteen years later with the good enough Wonder Woman (2017) flick.

I thought this was a wonderful movie. I cried and just felt so much emotion as the movie went along. It was much better than I expected it to be. The cat suit was awesome. Halle Berry is beautiful. Benjamin Bratt is cute. The cats were adorable. Midnight was a darling little cat! The story was simple and easy for me to follow (which is often rare in thriller movies). I appreciate the simplicity of the story so much. I love to watch a movie that I understand! It was just a great movie. Although some of the CGI scenes made half of it look like a video game. That was the most cheesy part. Otherwise, I loved it!I also love the fact that her friend ended up with the cute doctor that she loved so much. That was cute. Finally a large woman gets a sexy man! YES! And I also appreciated the fact that the cute guy didn't end up with the girl this time. She knew that she could survive and be free and self-confidant without a man, and that was definitely a message that I needed to see.

A lot of negative press has surrounded this film since its release. So much so that even before i went to see it i kind of wanted to like it just to be different. There was no need in the end however as much like thunderbirds it isn't half as bad as people say.  Formulaic - certainly, Cheesy - tick the box, Average - most certainly. As a regular cinema goer i have seen a lot worse films this year, step forward 50 first dates and the ladykillers, and i am sure there are still bad ones to come. The biggest crime that i can find with catwoman is that its distinctly average and the hatred and bile directed at this movie seems wholly misplaced.

Oh goodness, I feel really terrible for giving Catwoman such a bad review for several reasons1. I love the Selina Kyle character, so I feel terrible for saying that catwoman was a terrible movie. Seeing that they completely scraped her identity for a new character (Patience Phillips) I guess that doesn't apply, but still the guilt is pretty bad2. I'm actually a big Halle Berry fan. She was great in X-Men and really everything else she's been in, so seeing her in such a bad movie does make me sad.Even though I really wanted to love Catwoman, I'm not a fan of the film. I think the reason why I'm so upset is because Catwoman is such a fascinating character! But then the creators decided to completely ignore the excellent character with a well developed background that was handed to them on a platter for someone else whose character was so under developed that I forgot what I was watching for a few minutes. Had they actually gone somewhere with Patience Phillips then I wouldn't have such a problem with this, but that was the definition of awful. I am actually ashamed to admit that sometimes this is a good movie to watch if you want something mind numbing. You know, just something to play if you've had a really bad day at work and just need something silly. However, it does look like they put in a lot of effort into prepping the actors for Catwoman. If I'm not mistaken, they hired someone to teach Halle Berry to walk like a cat would walk and all that jazz. I did like seeing that they tried. I applaud that.I'm not saying, "Don't see this movie!" but I do want to put my opinion out there. I read a few other reviews and some people loved Catwoman. You should just rent it yourself and come to your own conclusion, but let me warn you now, if you're looking for an intelligent film that's completely story driven then this isn't for you.

This movie is so much worse that I thought it would be! I made a list of all the things I hate about it. 1. The story. Horrible, ridiculous. 2. Terrible, headache-causing music. It was like I was watching five music videos instead of a movie. 3. Some of the worst dialogue I've EVER heard in a movie. 4. The director airbrushed Halle Berry and Sharon Stone in EVERY scene. They look so fake. It was freaking me out - their skin looked like it was painted on or something. I'm not even sure Halle Berry even starred in the movie: I think it may have been an entire computer generated person that looked like her. 5. The costumes. Even the normal clothes look terrible. And Sharon Stone in all white? She looks HIDEOUS! 6. Worst camera action sequences EVER. Even the part where Catwoman has the whip and is kicking some butt the director cuts the scene up so it's hard to tell what is going on. The good things? 1. I had a free movie ticket. 2. The real cats. And the CGI cat they have isn't so bad looking either. 3. The opening sequence with all kinds of cool pictures of cats and catwomen.   Not even campy fun like I had hoped.   Blech.

reviews.review_title: Not a bad movie at all
reviews.content: After seeing all the bad reviews, I almost didn't see this movie. However, I went ahead and gave it a try with a free movie rental, and found I liked it quite a bit. Though part of the reason I liked it may be that I've been a Catwoman fan ever since I was around 7, but if it were just that I would've probably given it a 5 or less and gotten mad because they did such a terrible job on it if I thought they had. But I think they did a good job with it. Sure, it's not an intellectual film, but most action films aren't. I don't watch action films in order to engage in deep thought; that's what the drama genre is for. Like everyone else I know, I watch movies of the action genre when I want to see some good old fashioned butt-kicking. So not only is there a new twist on a character I've liked ever since I was little, but there's also plenty of interesting fight scenes. The part where she used that guy in the jewelry store as a skateboard was just priceless.

reviews.review_title: Not bad... for an overly long, perverse music video
reviews.content: Catwoman tries its best to pull off a sleek, modern and corporate look, while presenting a vigilante who can break down doors, climb walls and get a drug high from catnip... honestly though, it tries too hard and fails miserably as a film.There were too many instances of obvious computer editing and CGI, to the point where it looked fake and cheesy. There were a number of instances where characters did nothing but jump around and move in action to bad autotuned soundtrack, and Catwoman is turned from cat burglar to a perverse, sexualized freak who goes so far as to wear a revealing costume and carry a whip with her. I don't recall anything of the sort in the Batman comics... this film looks more like a LaSenza Underwear commercial than an engaging and interesting movie.I was in the first grade when it was released in theaters, and it was incredibly stupid and boring. It was so predictable, nothing memorable happens in it and I could've done without the bad dance rave party songs popping up at random times and long sequences of Catwoman shaking her butt for no apparent reason. Why'd they have to go and corrupt one of the most far out characters in the Batman universe? Not to sound like a nerd or anything, but it's pathetic!

A lot of reviewers say this is a clear feminism movie. But what they fail to admit is how terrible it is. I'm a fan of the character Catwoman, I read her comics and would catch every episode of her on the 60s Batman show. I even watch Batman Returns for her. But this is not Catwoman. At least Halle Berry laughed this off, because if she didn't. I would cry for her right now.Halle Berry is literally but in a costume that reveals 95% of her body without showing the inappropriate parts of her body. (No offense, it's just there are MPAA ratings), and has to battle a former supermodel who sells bad moisturizer. They couldn't make her fight Black Mask? Or Harley Quinn? Seriously?The action scenes are very bad, and the CG just screams fake. Maybe there was a reason this movie bombed. Who am I kidding, there was a big reason! You can't even consider this a DC movie, because it's more about a woman cosplaying as Catwoman. And that awful basketball scene. Most people I know like that scene and the movie because it shows off Halle Berry's body. I admit, Halle Berry is a beautiful woman, but if you want a movie that shows her beauty, you're looking in the wrong place.So, doing a bunch of sexual moves on a basketball court in front of a bunch of kids is okay? Man, I must really need to observe human behavior more. Not! I wouldn't recommend anyone to see this movie, because it's not for anyone. But if you do. Just please be careful. It's a train wreck.

It wasn't as bad as people say. Hell, Halle Barry in tight leather was worth my $6.50 matinée price. The plot was fine. They stuck as close to the comic version of Catwoman as they could. Halle in tight leather. Good CGI action. Halle in tight leather. Hey, it wasn't as good as Halles performance in Xmen, but Catwoman was a DC comic after all! Can you tell I liked the tight leather outfit? Sharon Stone was a good choice for the protagonist, too bad she wasn't in tight leather outfits as well. The movie wasn't bad, the people who gave it 1's were expecting way too much from a comic book movie. They should go see movies like Ghandi or something. Schindlers list. A comic movie is purely for entertainment and good special effects. That's all you can ask for in a movie who's plot wasn't written to impress the damn Acadamy!

Overcooked is the only way I can describe this film.What's wrong with it? Not the plot. The plot is actually pretty interesting, but unfortunately, the makers of this film chose to take the most anachronistic, exaggerated, silly and least compelling aspects of the original catwoman story and to emphasize and even embellish them. Catwoman is, in one sense, the story of a woman who must die and be reborn as an embodiment of feline magic and physical prowess in order to free herself from what appears (in the film) to be imaginary social oppression. What can we make of this? Are we being told that the lot of women is so awful that death and potential spiritual and physical augmentation are the only ways to achieve feminine freedom? Are we being told that cats are good role models for would-be strong and independent women? These themes, though treated a bit more subtly in the normally more outrageous and fantastic medium of DC comics, are raised to the level of ambiguous, slightly offensive, and really bizarre social commentary in this film.The Script. The script is the primary problem with the plot. Combined with the editing and the director's overall (lack of?) vision concerning the story The love story could have been an important aspect of the story, but it is poorly developed and only really pays off in the last scene (possibly the best scene in the film). The flirty but unemotional script couldn't even be saved by the talented Berry and Bratt combination.... while I am at it...The Casting. Bratt and Berry, as pretty as they both are, and as talented, have NO CHEMISTRY in this film. As much as I like Haile Berry, this was not a good role for her. First, she's not a very physical actress. Second, she was apparently not appropriately inspired to internalize her character well enough to create consistent characterization. In the end, she was more likable before she actually became the Catwoman. Haile - stay away from sci fi, it's simply not your genre. Bratt is fine in his supporting role - playing a stereotype TV detective - as are Sharon Stone and Lambert Wilson - the heavies.The Cinematography and Camera-work. Were simply awful. The CGI sequences, which tend to dominate every action sequence, are neither believable nor artistically done. After seeing the CGI in LOTR, it astonishes me that anybody would think they could get away with what passed for action animation in thi film. I would have rather seen the film cut to a cartoon for the action sequences than to go where it went. The film also uses a lot short clips and cliché close-ups to grab the viewer's attention. these techniques have become such a standard approach that they no longer have any impact. Ho hum. The directing. See all of the above.Catwoman is not nearly as bad as many seem to think (the modal vote here on IMDb is 1). I can honestly say that the film really had good potential and occasionally made me think. I even liked some of the characters. Hopefully the next time somebody takes on this interesting tale (if that should ever happen again), they will learn from the plentiful mistakes this version supplies.

reviews.review_title: Definitely one of the inferior comic book movies of the decade
reviews.content: This Batman spin-off, as I'm sure you know, has been very poorly received in general. I missed its theatrical run back in 2004, but that's certainly NOT something I regret! I never even knew of the film's existence until sometime later. Now that I've seen it, unlike many others, I certainly don't hate it with a passion, so I can't join the many who have voted 1/10 for it. However, it's definitely a disgrace compared to several other comic book movies of the decade, and I can still pretty much understand all the hate.Patience Phillips is a shy woman, constantly down on herself, who works for Hedare Beauty as a graphic designer. One night, she happens to overhear a conversation, and learns the truth about the company's new anti-aging product, how it will have dire results if one stops using it! When they realize that she has found out their evil secret, they chase after her and try to kill her! Eventually, they succeed, but Patience is brought back to life by a cat! After this, however, her life is a lot different! The cat has given her new superpowers, and now she is not a hero, not a villain, but somewhere in between! She is now Catwoman, and she plans to find out who is responsible for her death so she can get her vengeance! Soon, she ends up causing a lot of trouble in the city, and may pay the price for it! I never expect the scripts of these comic book movies to be absolutely flawless, but do expect them to be at least half-decent, and the script for "Catwoman" isn't even that. It's a very juvenile one! Halle Berry certainly can act, but she puts on a poor performance in her starring role here, obviously because she didn't have a good script to work with. Her character does some pretty ridiculous things after being rescued, such as drawing a silly picture of her boss and eating cans of cat food. Clearly, Berry realizes how bad she is in this film, and how bad this film is, as she appeared to accept her Razzie "Award" for Worst Actress! The film is also rather poorly directed, with some rather cheesy action sequences, though you could probably find worse action sequences in "Power Rangers". Certain scenes in "Catwoman" may be so bad that they're almost amusing, but not quite.I'm sure pretty much everything I've said about this movie has been said before, but I really don't know what else there is to be said. Now, much worse excuses for movies have seen the light of day, and I may not agree 100% with the extremely low rating for this one, but since it is pretty bad overall, I can't complain too much about that rating. Changing Catwoman's name from Selina Kyle to Patience Phillips is not a big deal, but all the flaws that I've pointed out are. Unless you're really curious, there's probably no point in seeing this film, but even if you are curious, you might regret it! If you want a good comic book movie, I strongly suggest you look elsewhere. Fortunately, one good thing I can say is kudos to Halle Berry for taking her Razzie and giving a funny acceptance speech! I guess she has a good sense of humour.

I remember a few years ago I was flying back to LAX, and the in-flight movie was "Waterworld" starring Kevin Costner. I had read that it was one of the worst movies ever made, and wondered "How bad could it really be?" Well, after the first 10 minutes, it REALLY was that BAD. So I took a nap for while, then proceeded to watch the remainder of movie without the headset on. Amazingly, the movie was now watchable and somewhat entertaining. This anecdote is a long about way of saying that "Catwoman" will someday be a great airplane movie sans the audio headset. Yes, this is a glaring indictment of a totally inept movie that wasted 90 minutes of my life. Granted I did see the movie to kill some time. Stupid me. A dear bud, Bobby, pointed this out to me. This vacuum of redeeming quality is completely unexpected given that Halle Berry as Catwoman is one of the most stunningly beautiful women to watch on screen. Benjamin Bratt as her torn romantic interest Detective Tom Lone is a great looking leading man and solid actor. The very hot and steamy Sharon Stone plays her evil best as aging cosmetics baroness, Laurel Hedare. However, all their star power can not overcome the incoherent and incomprehensible storyline. The movie is a mess. Director Pitof has a cutting edge visual style, and provides a cool textured score. Ultimately, this does nothing. I do like stupid funny movies-- that would be intentionally stupid and funny movies. What I do find most annoying is unintentionally and ineptly stupid movies. This would be "Catwoman". It is a bad omen when the opening credits require an explanation later in the movie itself. The transformation of meek and mousy Patience Phillips (Berry) to the fierce Catwoman is plain dumb. Berry looks stunning in the costume, and obviously trained her body rigorously for this role, but this is all for not. Even if "Catwoman" had some quality gratuitous nudity, it would not have been able to salvage this train wreck. Don't see this horrible movie. It is a complete waste of time, even if you are looking to waste some time. Really.

reviews.review_title: Did I see the same movie?
reviews.content: This film has been almost universally panned by critics and viewers alike. But what did they expect for a story about a catwoman?  Ingmar Bergman? Subtle philosophical debates?  Profound insights?  Come on, get real!This is a tongue-in-cheek film that is excellent entertainment - it was never meant to change the world.  Halle Berry is sexy and sensual as Catwoman, the cityscape scenes are breathtaking, particularly the one from across the water at night when Patience is 'reborn', and there's a light-hearted and humorous touch that works well.OK, a few scenes are embarrassing, especially the dancefloor and the volleyball ones, the special effects could have been better, and there could have been a greater sense of urgency and threat.  And we could have seen a bit more of Halle Berry in that catsuit! But there's a brilliant scene where the handwriting analyst concludes that Patience and Catwoman aren't the same person, because Patience's handwriting signifies a shy person with low self-esteem, whereas Catwoman's is the opposite.  And overall the movie is FUN!!  Lighten up, people!

There's no doubt in anyone's mind that a Catwoman film in the early/mid- 1990s featuring Michelle Pfeiffer returning as Selina Kyle would've likely been captivating, mesmerizing, and a great movie. But through wasting time and ideas, we were eventually given this film, an inferior movie that squanders what could've revived a part of the Batman universe a year before Batman Begins. But is it all bad?The story has its issues. "Attack of the Killer Cosmetics!" It's laughable, but considering the target audience for this movie seemed to be girls and women familiar with society's emphasis on youth and physical beauty, it could've been a bit of a horror story for them.Sharon Stone has always been the least fun form of camp to cast in a movie. That alone should've told everything they wanted to know about it. Halle Berry's acting has its ups and downs, though I find her acting even harder to watch in any of the X-Men films. The rest of the cast does a decent job with what they're given. Benjamin Brat's on screen chemistry with Berry isn't as immediate as they wanted it to be, but it does build eventually and has some interesting moments. Frances Conroy delivers probably the most intriguing performance in the movie. It was off-kilter, a little bizarre, and definitely not human, which makes it an easy target for critics who flip flop between calling it "groundbreaking" and "horrible" with their inconsistent reviews. Alex Borstein delivers as always, bringing some natural comedy into the film that was sadly overlooked by critics in their determination not to mention anything positive about the film.So where did it go wrong? Camp acting and a somewhat silly story-line aren't what sink films based on comic book heroes(or in this case, antihero). My main problem, as I watched the film for the first time since 2005 today, was the direction. Strung throughout the film are some really interesting lighting ideas and commendable visuals leaning towards a very art-based film. Then the action shots happen. When a director doesn't seem to know how to capture them clearly, their first instinct is to use so many cut-shots and amp up the speed so high that it becomes a blurred, almost headache-inducing mess. The motorcycle scene, some of the fights, etc. The fight at the very end of the film and bits and pieces of the scene between Berry and Bratt behind the theater show were somewhat well done, but just couldn't make up for everything else.The CGI was also a huge problem. They either didn't have the budget or the technology to make Berry jumping around look realistic. The CGI Berry, I mean. It just seems odd that they wouldn't simply film stunts on wires and remove them digitally rather than create so many CGI animations that made me feel like half the film was a cartoon. Pixar this is not.Bigger than the bad CGI was... the soundtrack and score. There seemed to be some kind of battle between trying to make an epic hero film and an urban action-comedy. Every time the film would've benefited from a good string section, they placed in some teen-pop R&B song. It seems like they decided post-production that they needed to market it towards that group instead of toward the fan-base Catwoman already had and it hurts the film immensely.All of this said, there's a decent film hidden underneath all of these problems. There's a fun, campy little slice of cinema with the decent idea to make Catwoman an anthology of women discovering how to be confident, sexy, and uncompromising. It's just a shame that it's buried under so much of a mess.I could probably sit through this and not hate it, at least loving it's intentions. And I have to enjoy a good bit of it from time to time.Some people hate this film, some people love it. I don't think it's terrible, but it's definitely not that great. I'll probably just watch it every great once in awhile to admire a handful of good choices that really shine and lament that it could've been so much more.6/10 stars.

I sat through this trainwreck and watched with fascination as movie careers were ruined, right there, before my eyes. Think about it. Seen any new Sharon Stone movies lately? Have any of Halle's new films (following this one) done well? A definite career destroyer, Catwoman takes a comic legend and completely butchers it, alienating the one audience who would pay to see this debacle. The costume is weak, the story sucks, and why do female heroes always fight female villains? I'd like to see a Supergirl movie or something where she goes toe-to-toe with one nasty dude out to rule the world. Something like that. Guess I'll have to write that one up, myself.Stay away from Catwoman, unless you like wondering why nobody who'd waste millions on a film like this wouldn't give it to world hunger instead, or to your favorite charity (the "your_name_here" offshore bank account) and maybe save a few hot actresses film careers.

(Synopsis-Spoiler?) Patience Phillips (Halle Berry) is a timid woman who can't stand up for herself.  She lets people walk all over her, and has wasted her artistic talent working for a cosmetic company as a graphic designer.  George Hedare (Lambert Wilson) runs the company with his supermodel wife, Laurel (Sharon Stone).  The company is about to launch a new anti-aging product nationwide.  Patience must go to the production factory to deliver her artwork, and she accidentally hears that the product has unsafe health problems.  To keep the secret safe, she must to be eliminated.  Patience runs into a large waste water pipe, where she is trapped, and they flush her into the river, where she drowns.   An Egyptian Mau cat has been watching Patience for several days, knowing that she was about to die.  The cat has special powers that are given only to a few deserving women after they die.  Patience is reborn with new catlike powers. She now becomes Catwoman with the senses and agility of a cat.  Patience and Catwoman are two completely different people, yet they are one. Catwoman goes on the prowl, looking for the reason why she was murdered, and then for revenge.  A police detective, Tom Lone (Benjamin Bratt), who is investigating crimes, that he thinks Catwoman committed, meets Patience and asks her out for a date.   Catwoman's wild side begins to have more influence over Patience, and she begins to follow her own rules.   Of all the Catwomen I have seen, I think Halle Berry is the best. Of course, the others were on TV and this was the big screen.  Sharon Stone played a good villain, even thought it was a small part.  This movie was shown in digital format and the scenes were very clear and the sound was great.  (Warner Brothers Pictures, Run time 1:44, Rated PG-13)(7/10)

reviews.review_title: CatWoman, Pleasantly Surprised, Better Than Expected, Bashing The Film Is All About Flavor Of The Month Popularity
reviews.content: Its a miracle that Halle Berry's "Catwoman" ever got made when you consider how long it has been since Eartha Kitt played Catwoman in "Batman". Especially when you consider the interval between Eartha Kitt as Catwoman and the next person of color to play a comic book character, Micheal Jai White as "Spawn". Slap that evil Halle's wrist! How dare that uppity girl get above herself and think that she could possibly attempt to present a positive female role model/super heroine for little girls of color, much less to all the little girls of America. I went to see the film with abnormally low expectations. What with all the enormous negative hype about how terribly awful the film was, how could I have any other expectations? What I saw was an average comic book superhero film, better than some, but certainly no less, than any other comic book superhero film. It had a typical comic book superhero film plot (there is a bad guy/girl, there is a good guy/girl, the bad guy/girl kills, kills the loved ones of, or maims the innocent good guy/girl, the good guy/girl forms an alter-ego with super powers and uses them to destroy the guilty bad guy/girl), it had a positive message about female empowerment, finding your own voice, and a female who did not necessarily choose a male and a relationship with a male over her own independence (how dare Halle relate what she has learned from her own life experiences!), and my 5 year old niece understood and loved it. There was no sex, gratuitous nudity, or graphic violence that I felt would necessitate explanation. There was even a little anthropology lesson about Bast, an ancient Egyptian cat goddess. When I think of how dark, dingy, and disgusting all the "Batman" films were, how sappy and sickening the "Spiderman" films were, how unwatchable "Phantom", "The Shadow", "Unbreakable", "The Hulk", and "Daredevil" (need I go on?) were, I must say, I was pleasantly surprised by "Catwoman", it was better than expected. And what is wrong with marketing a comic book superhero movie for little girls? What is wrong with little girls having a comic book super heroine to look up to? Why does a comic book superhero film necessarily have to be marketed to adult comic book enthusiasts? Have we forgotten that most of us began reading comic books as children and that, except for a small counter-culture of adult enthusiasts, it really is a child's realm of imagination? I happen to like Halle Berry. When I look back at how far she has come with her acting career, from playing a stripper opposite Bruce Willis and Damon Wayans in "The Last Boy Scout" or a crack addict opposite Samuel L. Jackson and Wesley Snipes in "Jungle Fever" to producing and starring in "Introducing Dorothy Dandridge" (my own childhood heroine as well as hers)and standing on the Academy Awards stage accepting the Oscar for "Monster's Ball" with the most tear jerking speech I have every heard given at the Academy Awards, I am exceptionally proud.In an industry where a woman of color has never won "Best Actress" ever until 2001 and where there was an eleven year gap since the last woman of color won "Best Supporting Actress", Halle Berry is a small miracle. The reviews of "Catwoman" have nothing to do with how good or bad the film actually is and everything to do with who or what it is popular to bash at the moment. Its all about who is the flavor of the month.

Catwoman is a movie that has nothing to do whatsoever with the Batman universe. This stand alone movie could have easily been a contender to be decent and it was hyped to be one of the biggest movies of 2004, however the end result is an epic failure. Apart from the nonsensical plot, take away the dark themes of the movie and this could have easily been aimed at children.In this disaster of a movie, Halle Berry plays Patience Phillips (who has no place in the Catwoman/Batman universe), a meek and shy graphic designer for Hedare Beauty run by the husband and wife team George Hedare (Lambert Wilson) and Laurel Hedare (Sharon Stone). When Patience inadvertently stumbles upon a corporate conspiracy the company is hiding, Laurel Hedare order Patience killed. When she almost drowns in a drain, she is mysteriously brought back to life by a cat and Patience is transformed into an wild and untamed woman with cat like abilities. With her newfound transformation Patience becomes Catwoman, a sleek and stealthy creature balancing on the thin line between good and bad.Halle Berry was terrible in this movie. I was in disbelief that Halle Berry would appear in this rubbish. Catwoman also saw the beginning of the end of Halle Berry's career, particularly after she was riding high from the success of X Men (2000), Swordfish (2001) her landmark Academy Award winning role for best actress in Monster's Ball (2001), and the coveted role as a James Bond girl alongside Pierce Brosnan in Die Another Day (2002). Since the box office failure of Catwoman, Halle Berry's career has never recovered. And Sharon Stone as the lead villain could not even salvage her career with an awful performance. Sharon Stone's glory days are well and truly over and her performances in Total Recall (1990), Basic Instinct (1992) and Casino (1995) seems like a distant memory. I was shocked that screen writing team John Brancato and Michael Ferris were involved in this atrocity. They both certainly have done better work in their career with The Game (1997), Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines (2003), Terminator Salvation (2009) and Surrogates (2009). Director Pitof has also disappeared without a trace from Hollywood.When I will think of Catwoman/Selina Kyle I will always think of Michelle Pfeiffer who immortalised Catwoman in Batman Returns (1992). Recently Anne Hathaway turned in an excellent performance with her take on Catwoman/Selina Kyle in The Dark Knight Rises, and for TV audiences Camren Bicondova plays a young Selina Kyle in the 2014 television series Gotham. Rewinding to the Batman TV series (1966-1968) and the movie (1966) , Catwoman was played by Julie Newmar, Lee Meriwether and Eartha Kitt respectively. The 2004 version of Catwoman should be banished forever from existence.Catwoman is so bad it complements kitty litter. No wonder this deserved the title of being the worst movie of 2004.1/10.

reviews.review_title: A terrible movie... but not nearly so much as to make it more enjoyable.
reviews.content: A General Warning: Spoilers Ahead.This movie numbers among some of the worst I've seen. It is by no means a good movie, although it might by some means be considered somewhat entertaining. Had this movie been worse, it might actually have been better. There is a large list of "Awesomely Bad" movies, movies that were made so terribly, and yet so seriously, that they are more worthy to watch than most other movies because of how hilarious the creators' efforts are. Among the most notable of these movies are Killer Klowns from Outer Space (1988), They Live (1988), the animated version of Return of the King (1980) and Army of Darkness (1993). Catwoman, however, is just barely, just ever so slightly, better than they are, and subsequently made all the worse than they are.There are so many things wrong with this movie, although one this the vast majority of reviewers (ranging from those who gave this movie 10 stars to those who gave it only 1) agree upon, and that is that this is not Catwoman in the truest sense. This is not Selina Kyle, the aristocratic cat burglar. This is Patience What's-her-face, a wanna-be artist working for a cosmetics company who is killed, revived, and gains superpowers.The plot itself is absolutely ridiculous. An evil businesswoman gets superpowers from years of using a toxic face-cream, and wants to flood the market with it, that will cause women to deform. After all, what could possibly be worse than being ugly? At any rate, they say that the cream will only deform you if you stop using it, and if it works as well as it obviously does, then who would really stop using it, especially when they went through all of the trouble to explain that it's addictive? And, further, how'd this stuff ever pass the FDA? Seli---no---Patience's costume borders on ridiculous, being, from as far as I can tell, open-toed sandals, leather pants, an unflatteringly-cheap cat-mask and a bra. The effectiveness of the whip is somewhat laughable. It seems to move on its own whims, not taking into account the actions of Catwoman, and seems to change lengths as is convenient. I must admit, though, that the diamond-clawed gloves were a nice touch.The acting, honestly, wasn't really that bad. Bratt plays the same role, though, that I always see him in, a cop. He played it in Law & Order, he played it in Demolition man, and he played it in Miss Congeniality. He plays it well, as always, but he seriously lacks for role diversification. But that's another matter entirely. Halle Berry was probably the best choice for Catwoman, although her talents are wasted in the role (and she truly earned her Razzie in this role). The rest of the acting was standard.The romance was horribly contrived, clichéd and, I felt, insulting. We never get near enough to the characters to really care if they're together or not, and when they lead separate lives at the end of the movie in a way that was obviously intended to be sad and touching, I can't see many people caring, especially after we get the same situation better done in Spider-Man (2002). I felt that throughout the movie the writers were constantly trying to force the two together, with everything from a sensuous game of one-on-one, to huddling together in a conveniently-timed rain-shower to cornering each other in, ironically, a catwalk.The crazy-cat-lady was an obvious plot-device meant only to explain what had happened, and move Berry along on her way. The woman says as soon as Berry comes with the cat that she (the cat) had never brought anybody home before. And yet, in the next scene with her, she makes goes to great length to show that she was not the only one Midnight brought back and gave renewed life to.To be entirely honest, my dog seemed to like this movie better than I did. Whenever Catwoman would jump around on building tops my dog would run around the room and bark excitedly. Honestly, I thought that she was having a blast.This movie is a contrived train-wreck designed to cash-in on the recent successes of both the Spider-Man, Hulk and X-Men films. It's substandard and mediocre in every way, and I would only recommend it to people who have nothing to do late at night and don't mind (very) cheap entertainment. Although I do agree with the comment that this might eventually become a huge cult-film. Until then, however, I suggest that it be avoided if possible.

After 45 min of watching this "superhero-wanna-be-feminist" crap flick i had enough and walked out of the theater!!The screenplay and dialog were atrocious-I have no words for it..This is not the Catwoman i knew from the comic books of my youth. The reported budget of 85 million is way over the top, especially since special effects certainly DID NOT cost anywhere near that amount. Heh, i guess the cast got their pieces of the pie. You can't expect much from Halle Berry in this type of role but worn out Sharon Stone ( as a bad girl ) and Benjamin Bratt ( as Catwoman's/Patience's love interest ) are so bad that they don't even deserve words. Above all those "minor" flaws, we have director from France who signs his films as Pitof :). Man, even I wouldn't be so stupid to hand 85 million bucks into the hands of an anti talent whose only and greatest achievement prior to this was horrendous french movie Vidocq ( friendly advice : don't see it ). All in all, I wasn't expecting much from Catwoman but despite all the bad critics decided to see it. What a mistake that was...Halle, if you see this post, show compassion and return my $8.75. That's the least you can do because time cannot be reversed....:(

reviews.review_title: A bad idea gone horribly wrong
reviews.content: I think I know how this movie got into production. Somewhere in one of those Hollywood think tanks somebody must have suggested "Hey, lets put Halle Berry in tight shredded leather and make her crack a whip around like a dominatrix!" Gee, how could THAT idea have possibly backfired? This movie could be summed up in one phrase, worthless flesh fest. Everything from the acting, the story, the special effects, to some of the plot devices were so bad that they were just painful. Guess how Sharon Stone's character gets her super powers. Yup, anti-wrinkle cream that turns her into stone (pun intended).This movie was Catwoman in name only. There is absolutely no ties to its batman comics roots. You would think that X-Men gave us us fair warning not to cast Halle Berry in comic book based movies, but noooo!

Breaking with the traditions of the Batman/Superman genre, Catwoman does everything for drama that's never been done here before.It would have been so easy to let this one slip into blaxploitation and MTV rap and disco scenes but the makers of this movie evidently never fell for this temptation.And the lovely Halle - Oscar winning Halle - shows yet again what a talent she is. And those ugly curls she has on in the beginning are thankfully replaced by a tinted gangsta moll hairdo which is much more becoming.Of course this is sarcasm - and the presence of Benjamin Bratt who plays the foil? All one can say is he must be quite the sport.

reviews.review_title: Not bad enough to be interesting
reviews.content: It's not that bad... but it's not good either. It's mostly just boring. The villains are boring, corporate types, which are the least interesting sort of villain. Not a lot happens. There's an origin story, which is OK I guess. Catwoman beats up some people, with lots of CGI effects of her jumping around. Halle Berry goes on a couple of dates. There are a couple of corny one-liners, but not many. If you watch this expecting to laugh at some crazy "bad movie" antics, or be angry about how incompetently made a movie can be, you will be sorely disappointed. It looks fine. The actors are fine. But it's just not that interesting.

Technically, it looks good, there's a lot of interesting camera work and you can tell that everything you see has been carefully designed.The problem is the concept, for me, everything looks so fake, campy and teenager oriented that looks like a bad cheesy romantic comedy.It's just a really bad choice for a Batman character, Adam West era is long dead and Joel Schumacher take on these characters was pretty much like this and failed quite badly, so I don't know what they were thinking when they gave the ok to this concept and script. Warner directives, again, making the wrong choices.More specifically that is is a piece of cheese, is that they changed the character and environment way too much to make it appealing to a younger public, which is quite an insult to anyone else that actually knows and has follow the character through the years.Even more specifically, we have horrible dialogs, overuse of CGI, a very lousy and simplistic story, HORRIBLE costume design (not saying Halle Berry is not nice to look at, more if she's half naked, but this is quite a pathetic design, the mask is so big that I was wondering how she keeps the balance jumping around), two or three shameful, embarrassing scenes (specially the basketball one, I had to pause it because I couldn't take it in a single go, I almost vomit, seriously) and I'm probably missing some more bad aspects but this is definitely getting too long.Overall a so-bad-it's-hard-to-watch movie that, if it has ANY supporters, I'm pretty sure it's guys that like watching Halle Berry shaking her beauty, but for me, that doesn't even get close to make a good movie, not this kind of movie, at least.

I wish I could unwatch this movie, however sadly, the curiosity of wanting to see it would pester me all over again, which means this film does give some appropriate meaning to; Curiosity killed the cat.I don't want to "unwatch" this movie because it's bad though, rather because its not necessarily as bad as people made it out to be, but it is bad. As in, this movie shared some key qualities with quite a few CBM's, except, Catwoman is weirdly unfocused in many, if not all aspects, which makes it a some kind of quaint CBM, that was terribly handled.Yes, the cinematography, direction and acting was pretty horrible. The fight sequences and CGI were appalling. The physics in the combats were slothfully unfeasible, Halle Berry's illustration of Catwoman was cringey and a crime worse than burglary while the score, which was more like background music, was "OMG" horrendous. But still with all of that, hating this movie feels forced, though accepting it is terrible is effortless.Catwoman is an uncanny kind of bad. It's not a Fant4stic kind of bad. Somehow I understand those who dislike it, but still I envy those who do like it, however ultimately, this film should never have been made, and I mean that not as an insult, I mean it as a regretful truth. 4/10.P.S. Sally was pretty cool though.

reviews.review_title: Could have been better, but not as bad as the hype claims
reviews.content: In fact, the only objections I have with this film are that it focuses too much on Halle Berry's sculpted physique, and that it co-opts the character from the Batman comics and spins an entirely non-canon tale around it. That said, I greatly enjoyed yet another take on the classic underdog story, this time from the perspective of a woman who wants to devote her life to art. Instead, she must endure day after day of thankless work for those who reap millions in the business of artificially erasing the signs of age. When she stumbles upon a nasty secret (the company's latest product has the unfortunate side effects of being mortally addictive as well as causing gruesome disfigurement) she is summarily dispatched. That would be the end of the story except for the intervention of a mystical cat. The screenwriters deserve kudos from this cat-lover for introducing at this point elements of the myths of Bast, the Egyptian Goddess depicted in the form of a cat, and the tradition of the cats that made their homes in Her temples. Bast was and is often regarded as a protectress of women; it makes perfect sense that one of Her cats comes to the rescue of the protagonist and grants her both another shot at life and feline abilities such as surefootedness, elasticity, and a taste for bright baubles and tuna. While some may regard this material as not worthy of a movie starring an Academy Award winner, I am glad that big bucks were spent on a story that pays homage to a dear animal and Deity.

reviews.review_title: Is This Trying To Take Catwoman Seriously?
reviews.content: Catwoman is a both a disgraceful superhero movie and a complete insult to the character. As a huge Batman fan myself, this is completely unappealing and an absolute waste of space. Because the thing is there's nothing in this movie where it understands who Catwoman is. She just acts like a cat and does excruciating things. This would come from a director that would normally work as a visual supervisor. And just by watching this movie alone, I can see he's not ready to produce movies. And what proves all this is the stuff he can think of such as an unbearable written story. The action is dull and uninteresting to watch. The villain twist has no sense of surprises. The characters are all unlikable. And Halle Berry has given a really awkward performance. Along with low quality editing that feels out of place, like the CGI cats. Please if you're like me and truly a Batman fan, do not watch this film unless if you want to see what a train wreck in a superhero movie style looks like. Maybe one day we'll actually get a good movie about Catwoman. But this film is the complete opposite and is easily one of the biggest disasters to come out of DC.

reviews.review_title: This has nothing to do with Batman!!!! (Possible Spoilers)
reviews.content: This movie has nothing to do with Batman, and it isn't supposed to! This is not a Batman movie. People saying that they got Catwoman's name wrong, she's not black, doesn't have super powers etc. You are not catching the point of the movie! It's not the same character from Batman, it is a totally different woman named Catwoman. When reviewing this movie, wipe Batman completely from your mind. This has nothing to do with that, and it isn't supposed to have anything to do with that. All it is is a movie about a woman with the powers of a cat. Nothing to do with anything else. Just forget everything you know about the Catwoman from the Batman comics, because this isn't even supposed to be her. My score, 6 out of 10.

In the end i would like to say that Catwoman is very good movie,don't listen bad review first watch.10/10 GREAT

like many here, i watched the movie simply to see whether it was really as bad as everyone kept writing. however, there was also a chance i actually would like the movie; im a superhero fan, i like catwoman (the comic character), i love "girl kicks ass"-movies, and i enjoyed underworld and aeon flux, which both got trashed by the critics. so what about catwoman then? well, its a train wreck alright.the movie catwoman has nothing to do with the character she was based on, so you have to take this for what it is. and what it is is not very good. the plot is a boring anti-mystery, with the titular heroine spending most of the movie trying to figure out a secret that the audience already knows. it also includes ridiculous elements such as evil companies that sell addictive beauty products that also make you invulnerable, or magical cats that resurrect dead people and give them cat-related superpowers.the dialog and acting are below average. the characters are stiff, unconvincing and totally unsexy, most of all halle berry. it doesn't help that she is wearing a tasteless costume that manages to be absolutely slutty and totally unerotic at the same time.there is also a very questionable scene where berry is soooo skinny that she manages to slip through between the barrs of her jail. isn't catwoman supposed to be about empowering women, and not about supporting anorexia? catwoman doesn't have any saving graces, but it does have a few OK elements. the production is competent (berrys hilarious costume aside) and the movie is visually glossy and nice, if not exactly distinctive or tasteful. also, as ridiculous and boring the plot may be, it at least got some internal logic and is easily comprehensible (unlike other movies that make no sense at all).there are worse movies (really! go and try ultraviolet!). but catwoman is still a very idiotic, boring and annoying chapter in the history of comic adaptions.
Your gona call it Catwomen and your gona sell it, "SLAP" ... that does NOT make it good...
