Why in the world would an Oscar winning actress choose to do this garbage? Is there a story? Does anyone care (besides Berry?) How's the popcorn? Is that Ray sitting over there? Do you remember where we parked? This film needs to die a horrible death so Hollywood can get with the program and stop making so much junk that panders to the bottom level of moviegoers.I could have made 100 great films for what this tripe cost in P&A budget alone.

reviews.review_title: A Diabolically Disgusting Cat-Food Cat-Litter Hollywood B**** Fest Piece of S***!!!!
reviews.content: CATWOMAN has achieved the lowest standards of film-making possible; I asked myself whilst watching this film "Is it even feasible to get away with making a film so mediocre?" Its insipid, abounding with clichés, absolutely empty of character, depth or anything remotely stunning and exceptional. The film's supposed saviour is the use of antagonistic,nails-driving-through-your-brain annoying hip-hop music and the personage of the 'b****' that people seem to find so attractive nowadays. Halle Berry proves that she's just a Hollywood mannequin with no exceptional talent. Ugh...the entire film was just the most repulsive, statement-making piece of filthy trash that I have ever seen. To begin with, the most irritating aspect of this film is the fact that some brainless moron out there thinks he has the right to take somebody else's character and mutate her to the heaviest extremity- SELENA KYLE is the true CATWOMAN, a tortured, slightly insane woman whose motivation was human hatred and self-destruction- PATIENCE PHILIPS is a timid little nobody who thinks that graduating from Art College makes her an artist, and whose 'cat woman' alter ego is in all senses nothing more than a hip-hop b**** in a dominatrix costume. Tim Burton/Michelle Pfieffer's 'Cat Woman' was a genuinely dark, sensual and believable character compared to this abomination. So we're expected to believe that there is such thing as a magical,presumably immortal cat who can boost a woman's ego just by breathing on her? Wow-what an almighty gift that this cat Midnight gives to Patience! The cat breathes on her...and what happens? Nothing. She just transforms from shrinking violet into bully-girl b****, and thats considered to be a super heroine power??? So being the almighty, sacred Catwoman entails utterly deliberate, completely unnecessary, conceited, rampant, sexually desperate behaviour? Since when did cats practise these characteristics? If behaving like the stereotype 'cat' human is considered to be a power, then why aren't mentally ill people considered to be sexy and heroic? The only 'power' Catwoman has is the power that all 21st century women have, which is the power of free will, only not all free women dress up in disgusting fetish costumes pretending to be a cat, treating people like dirt! There was no motive to this character other than the fact that it is considered cool to be a b**** nowadays. Its the only indication of female power that modern audiences understand, whereas being a b**** and being brave are two entirely different things.The old woman who explained everything to Patience is clearly a cat-fixated maniac; she irritated the Hell out of me with her twitchy, whiskery face and her staring, cat-fixated behaviour; ooh blimey the old lady surrounded by the cats with the sound of sickly, wet, desperate meowing echoing all around, with the sacred, ancient history, the terrible deadly line of the rampant, nasty cat b****es!!! So all great and powerful femininity stems from being a b****? I DON'T THINK SO. GET REAL!!!! This cat woman is entirely unlovable; a motiveless hip-hop b**** with the ultimate attitude problem, more a mentally ill dominatrix than a heroine. She's out for nobody but herself and her bland little career; she gets "flushed down the pipes" and we're all meant to feel terrible for her, like some terrible injustice has been done to her (by the way, I was laughing my head off when she got "flushed down the pipes") and the ending is clearly supposed to be something special, the bulky-bottomed, bulky-breasted b**** just struts off into an unrealistically huge moon, whipping her stupid whip with the hip hop blaring! B**** B**** B**** B**** B****!!!!!!!!!I didn't think it was possible to make a film this pathetic and weak and stupid until I saw this; AVOID!!!! And another thing is that Sharon Stone is practically portraying herself and her midlife crisis... "I was everything they wanted me to be; I was never too beautiful, never too powerful, and then I turned 40 and they threw me in the trash." It says a lot about her own career, wouldn't you say?

This is one of the most over-hype film I've ever scene. The CGI is crap like it look like a video game. I heard it was a box office bomb even though I didn't see it in theaters. This film is mostly likely unforgettable like no matter. The acting is poor in my opinion. My question is why is the Cat Woman costume look like what a 13 year old look at the picture and do you know what? Also it's worse than BatMan and Robin (1997). This film need a lot of improvement.

reviews.review_title: Makes Your Eyes Enjoy, While Your Brain Rests
reviews.content: I think the movie was butchered unfairly by so many critics & viewers. It is really worth seeing, at least once. The special effect are very good & are complemented with great soundtrack. As for Halle Berry, I think she was a great choice for the role of Catwoman: her plastic movements & expressive eyes are relevant additions to her great acting.The film features some very impressive fighting sequences, though the story in general is too straightforward & predictable with only two rather primitive story lines. The direction is also far from being perfect, to put it mildly, cause Pitof, whoever it is, definitely has problems with sense of time. Plus, the camera zooms in on Halle Berry's ass so often throughout the movie, that, I still don't know why, but it is becoming annoying.What the movie lacks is depth & meaning, otherwise it is a good action. Despite all the bad write ups & negative comments, I went to see the movie & I'm not sorry. Great Halle Berry's acting, breathtaking special effects, outstanding director of photography's job & catchy soundtrack makes Catwoman a sweet eye-candy, worth watching at least once.

While this movie isn't great, it's a very respectable B movie.  I have to say that the drubbing the critics gave it did it a favor, at least when it comes to myself and the group I saw it with.  We'd all heard how much it sucked, so we weren't expecting much.  But we were pleasantly surprised. 
Sure there were some plot holes and the CGI was pretty obvious, but Halle Berry played a very likable character--and she definitely had her sexy strut down.  When Catwoman wanted to kick butt, she did it with flair.And I've got to tell you, I didn't get the feeling that the movie makers took the movie too seriously.  Watching an ignorant Patience rubbing catnip all over her face in the throes of feline ecstasy and then a few minutes later trying to deal with why she'd done it was pretty funny.  And you gotta love her method of dealing with obnoxious neighbors.If you want to pick the movie apart, there's definitely plenty of room in this flick.  But if you're willing to just go along for the ride, it's a fun one.  The storyline probably could've been better, but I enjoyed the Patience/Catwoman character and I'd be willing to check out another film about her.  Whatever problems there were in this flick, Berry's character was engaging and entertaining.  I will be buying the DVD when it comes out.

I'm embarassed that this was one of the first films i ever saw.
It's hilariously bad so i guess you can watch it with that mindset but yh this film is terrible haha

Just watched this movie today, and it was abysmal. It was so bad from start to finish, and it is a waste of time more than anything.This is basically a pointless reworking of the same Catwoman origin from "Batman Returns." Halle Berry plays Catwoman, and my oh my, how far has she fallen! Her portrayal of the character is just awful, although it could in large part be the fault of the screenplay. She deserved better.The supporting characters are one-dimensional and not worth caring about, and the villains (the main one played by Sharon Stone) are boring.I'm not a huge fan of CGI, and this film has some of the worst I've ever seen. The action scenes are stupid, the script is weak, and the plot has many elements that don't even make sense.This film definitely isn't worth sinking your teeth into. It is near the bottom (but not quite at the bottom) of the superhero movie genre. Avoid this and just watch "Batman Returns" instead.RATING: D-

SPOILERS ALL THROUGH! A woman is out for revenge on whoever left her dead. In one scene, Patience Phillips is shown wearing a yellow tracksuit. In another, she wears leather while driving a motorcycle. In many of the fight scenes, people's punches and kicks make audible whooshing sounds, and they run up walls, in clear homage to Hong Kong wuxia movies. The best fight in the movie is woman-woman -- or should I say a "catfight?" And Sharon Stone's fight double is Zoe Bell, who so adeptly doubled for Uma Thurman in both volumes of "Kill Bill." However, there any resemblance to the Tarantino movies ends.Tarantino, for example, knows how to edit a fight sequence. Pitof does not. Nor, for that matter, sex scenes, nor scenes of extremely elite cops computer-comparing lip prints. (I'm sorry. I am a woman. I have worn lipstick. And you would have to press VERY carefully, and fairly slowly, to create a print as perfect as that allegedly left on Benjamin Britton's cheek.) He could do with some help framing shots that are not about "OMG sexy leading lady!" as well. In fact, the only sequence I can fairly call well-composed is that in which Patience, having been pushed off an indoor balcony by Ophelia and having landed safely and noiselessly on all fours (I have cats, too, and even cats go thud when they jump to a surface below them), stares at a shower of pictures of previous Catwomen (yes, yes, including Michelle Pfeiffer), and is framed perfectly as Ophelia calls down to her from above. Yet even that is spoiled by Pitof's cinematographic ADHD.Uma Thurman was also costumed with a certain practicality, and, well. What the HELL are those things wrapped across Halle's middle? Suspenders to hold up her falling-down, well-ventilated pants? Must the back straps on the bra part look like tribal tattoos from last century? The contrast in the final fight sequence (literally a "boss fight") between Halle in black and Stone in off-white is nice, but about as subtle as a cat who jumps on the newspaper you're reading.I agree with those who have said that the music utterly sucks; that the crappy CGI almost qualifies this as a direct-to-Xbox release (the only time in my life, dear reader, that I have thought Jar Jar Binks was better than a comparable element in a different movie); that the dialogue is so bad one suspects George Lucas was brought in as a script doctor; and that the female-empowerment theme doesn't entirely cohere -- one commenter mentioned this Catwoman as a positive role model for her daughters, but I wonder if she really wants them thieving jewelry or having wild, back-clawing sex on the first date. I also agree that the Patience-saves-the-kid sequence on the Ferris wheel is gratuitous and works too hard to build audience sympathy for the heroine -- Halle should be doing that. Too often, she doesn't. Even as Patience rather than Catwoman, she has none of the hurt and vulnerability that underlay Michelle Pfeiffer's performance.Not that this movie is 100% crap. If you approach it with the same level of expectation you would the aforementioned chop-socky genre, and forget the Batman continuity altogether, you can distract yourself with it for a little while. It's just that things like having a former model with a surname pronounced "head-air," who is married to a man with a godawful Eurotrash accent who is the least menacing evil conspirator on screen... the damn cats, especially the one with the stinky magic breath, are more menacing than the former Merovingian. So, come to think of it, is Sharon Stone's deservedly maligned haircut. So all in all, I'm glad I saw this one on cable.

reviews.review_title: It's not as bad as all that
reviews.content: Not only is Catwoman not a disaster, it's not even the worst superhero film of the year. Not that Catwoman is particularly great, but it's not as bad as everyone is saying, and in fact, it's fairly average. That's not an accomplishment, but for a film that should have by all rights been a disaster, it's a bit of a surprise.Halle Berry, of course, stars as Patience Phillips, whose introduction and storyline largely follows the territory Tim Burton laid down over a decade ago with his take on the character; Patience is a shlep who is under-confident and under-appreciated (as if someone looking like Halle Berry could turn out that way) and whose best friend Sally (Alex Borstein) always has to push her into everything. Together they work for Hedare cosmetics, run by George Hedare (Lambert Wilson, the guy who played the Merovingian in the bad Matrix films) and his bitch of a wife, Laurel (Sharon Stone). Much like in Burton's version, Patience finds out something she's not supposed to and takes an unfortunate spill that ends her life. Of course she's brought back to life by some sort of cat-magic (it's explained in the movie) and becomes the feral, ferocious Catwoman.Though it's a bit of a stretch to see Berry playing a frump, I have to congratulate whoever did her hair and makeup, because her varying looks fit the character's state of mind perfectly, and she seems just at home playing wimpy Patience as she does over-the-top Catwoman. Stone to me is the single most piece of ironic casting in ages; she plays a model who's being pushed aside due to her age and is desperate not to be put out to pasture. You'll also find some genre faces in some bit roles  Peter Wingfield miscast and strapped with an American accent as a scientist, and the Asian guy from Earth: Final Conflict as one of Stone's stooges. And of course, there's leading man Ben Bratt, playing Detective Tom Lone, who at least has the good manners to be interested in Prentice before she dons her dominatrix gear.Borstein and Berry get on well, and there is some real chemistry between Berry and Bratt, a warmth there that makes their flirtation believable. Catwoman swipes a scene from Daredevil, when Patience and Tom play hoops; it reminds you of the Matt/Elektra sparring scene at the playground, but this one's more fun and displays a lot more chemistry. In fact, the movie is pretty enjoyable right up until they decide that Berry has to dress like a stripper and act like a whore  and there Catwoman goes right out the window. No matter how you try to play the character (and Berry tosses subtlety aside in a flash), the Catwoman outfit is so outrageously stupid that it is simply impossible to take seriously. That Berry chooses a few times to try to channel Eartha Kitt  possibly the worst choice for a screen Catwoman ever  doesn't help things (any acting choice made to emulate any performance on the old Batman TV show is just a bad idea in general). The outfit single-handedly kills the film, though admittedly the crazy CGI stunts don't help much. The action is also wildly over the top, with Catwoman hopping around the place with greater speed and agility than Spiderman. Actually it's a shame, because those involved went to a great deal of trouble to draft a cogent mythology for the character, even down to the silly mask she wears, and they spent a fair amount of time trying to establish the bipolarity of Catwoman (a trait I've never cared for, but it is often a part of the character). The attempt at post-modern feminism is absurd, but a fair amount of work was put into this film in an attempt to establish a mythology (and probably a franchise). I was even impressed by the cosmetics company design work, because it was so terribly close to what real ones are like (and it was frustrating to think they had done so much with production design and dropped the ball on the most important costume in the entire movie).Most of the acting is okay. Borstein always seems like she's having a good time, and Bratt plays a slightly warmer version of his Law and Order character. But he's a very likable guy, and you can see why Patience (or any woman) would be drawn to him. Stone overdoes it a little, but really, when has she not? The irony of casting her as a former model who has turned to stone (almost literally) to me far outweighs any problems with her performance, which are minor in any case. Berry herself overdoes the Catwoman vamp, and I wish she hadn't, because this might have actually been a wholly enjoyable film if she had reigned it in a little.Catwoman is not a terrible film, though it misses its audience by a mile; it was obviously aimed at young women, but with that Striperella outfit, it's going to attract more men than gals. Actually I preferred it to the much more popular Spiderman 2; while this lacks a performance anywhere near Alfred Molina's Doc Ock, at least here the romance works, and much like Spiderman 2, a lot of the plot hinges on being able to buy into that. You can see some heat with Berry and Bratt; Dunst and Maguire sometimes seem like they filmed separately and were paired only in editing. Catwoman's probably going to be forgotten (or on deep discount on DVD by the end of the year), which is maybe not a fate wholly undeserved, but I've seen many worse films this summer. I can't really recommend this, but I can't tell you to stay away, either. All I can tell you is that it's being unfairly maligned by a viewing public who championed two films of monumental mediocrity masquerading as fun to the tune of almost a billion dollars this summer; you do the math.

reviews.review_title: Perfect example of how NOT to make a great super hero film!
reviews.content: I honestly believe that when the idea of a Catwoman movie came across someone's desk several years back, it was a good idea. Unfortunately what turned up in theaters in 2004 was this mess! 'm tempted to write a long piece explaining why this film was so bad, but I can all too easily summarize by saying "Everything".It was poorly acted, predictable, UN-enthralling, clichéd nonsense. And that was just the first half hour, at which point, for the sake of my brain and stopping it melting with the sheer tedium, I walked out of the cinema.This is the worst movie that Halle Berry has ever starred in and is another blemish is her movie career. The acting is dreadful and the action is a joke.

Well, I've heard all such bad things about this film like "This is the film that is going to ruin Halle Barry's career" and "Worst film of the century", but honestly in my opinion it was not all THAT bad. I've seen a LOT of FAR worse films this year alone. It's entertaining, wild, capturing and for the guys there is Halle Barry dressed in a cat suit which must be something that could turn on anyone. I've never been the biggest Halle-fan, but I think she does a quite believable presentation of the shy Patience Williams - shy, timid, cute.....and extremely beautiful without knowing it - where of course, Catwoman, is the meer opposite - kinky, wild, sexy like hell - but again, it works....a lot of cheesy one-liners, sure, but it WORKS..Thing that stuck to me, however, is the fact that this film could almost halfway have been written over the script of "The Crow (1994)", it's almost simply a female reshoot...of course, this doesn't match up to the "The Crow" at all, but there are incredibly many similarities...watch it to see what I mean....Still a decent film for sure..I don't know why people make such a fuss over this being that bad, cause it's really NOT. Admittingly, it's kinda odd watching an Oscar winner playing a super hero, but hey, why not - why should those Oscar winners always take on the "oh I'm so dramatic"-roles always, why not live a little and have a little fun once in a while..It's not the movie of the year, but it's definitely watchable! So can all the complaints, please ;-) I'd probably see it again when it's out on DVD7/10

I am a Halle Berry fan but disappointed to see this movie.
Nothing is there in the movie except style quotient of the lead.

Sometimes I think those who give bad reviews do so to enjoy the sound of their own pronouncement.We aren't talking "Plan 9 From Outer Space" here folks. We aren't even talking "The Hulk." It was a good decent movie.There are actually many things to enjoy about this movie.First of all great enjoyment may be had by watching Halle Berry. No stunt double could affect the walks she took on. Hey! Walking is acting! OK, the rest of the acting she did was great too.Sharon Stone really brought it for this movie as well. There are some people who can bring it to the screen and she is one of them.Great enjoyment is had in watching Catwoman kick butt. Great enjoyment is also had in watching Catwoman and Sharon's character square off.Personally I enjoy a movie in which a character, particularly a female character, learns to be come strong.The plot was logical and you could follow it.(BTW: Benjamin Bratt was great as well, though his part was pretty limited.) The critics do have some ground to stand on, however. It did not make the grade for a great movie for several reasons. The main character changes greatly through the movie but these changes are not explored or explained so they seem very disconnected. The rest of the characters were rather hollow and clichéd. You might expect this from the film's comic book origin but movie goers have come to expect more.The CGI Catwoman was very obviously CGI and was rather intrusive. The animation was jerky, did not maintain constancy of form and contained movements not natural to the universe or character.I am puzzled as to why the producers felt it necessary to change the name and origin of the character. No doubt this annoyed fans of the Batman universe.There were some other things that limited the movie, but not enough to take it down completely.Overall, I enjoyed this movie.

The problem with this movie is not that it's bad, but it's predictable and unmemorable. A couple months after this movie I've seen this movie, I probably won't remember a thing about it, because there's nothing about it that makes it stick out amongst other flicks in the superhero genre--unlike "The Punisher" which came out earlier this year and was much more edgy and original in its approach. I don't know anything about the director's background, but my guess is he had his start in music videos. "Catwoman" pretty much has the same hyper-kinetic, MTV-style direction that we see in way too many recent movies. Some of the shots are obviously computer-generated, and definitely took me out the movie. Halle Berry gives as good a performance as possible, but there's not much you can do with mediocre material. None of her one-liners are witty or funny. "What's wrong? Cat got your tongue?"--yeah, wow, that's a good one.

I won't discuss the story, it has already been done by others.Moments like this I wish my knowledge of the English language was better cause I feel that I at the moment ain't capable to describe properly how lame this movie was.It looks like is has some kind of message, like - it's cool to be a black women. Whatever, it doesn't make the movie an inch better. Well, let me tell you what we have: Cheese CGI, non-existent script, non-existent acting, extremely annoying music, silly product placement (I will never buy a Nokia again if they support garbage like this).Sorry kids, I just can't go on. This film is so awful. If you still feel like watching it, DON'T. Rent Striptease with Demi Moore instead. It's as bad as this one. No, it's actually worse which somehow makes it better.Halle Berry was hot as lava in Monsters Ball, but sorry kids, don't expect the same from this flic.

With the bar set high by the "Spider-Man" and "X-Men" franchises, today there is a certain expectation for movie adaptations of comic books. "Catwoman" fails to live up to the simple expectation that such a movie be more entertaining than "Daredevil." It is as if the filmmakers simply stopped thinking beyond the concept of "Halle Berry in a catsuit," and could not be bothered to fit around her an engaging story, a memorable villain, or colorful supporting characters. And most toxic of all is Berry's performance itself.Nearly a decade ago another film similarly tried to coast on the sex appeal of its central character. While "Barb Wire" did bomb at the box office, it nonetheless offered up entertainment. Pamela Anderson, as the title character, displayed little acting talent; as a walking, talking caricature, however, she thoroughly infected the movie with trashy appeal. Her utterly guileless line-readings even made the deadly dialogue spring to life. ("Don't call me 'Babe'!")Neither blessed (nor cursed) with Anderson's larger-than-life persona, Berry turns in an earnest performance not so distinguishable from her "Storm" in the "X-Men" movies, minus some garments. Whereas there she blended in as part of an ensemble, Berry's blandness is brought front and center here. Oscar-winning performance not withstanding, Berry's lack of range renders her transformation from timid Patience Phillips to Catwoman a mere cosmetic costume change from dowdy to S&M; she displays no matching inner change, aside from playing up some cattiness. And this exposes a fundamental weakness in the casting of Berry as Catwoman: instead of a transformation of a girl into a woman, the girl remains, only playing dress-up. The role required an actress who could project the sly, worldly adultness of previous Catwomen Eartha Kitt and Michelle Pfeiffer.But then again, with nothing else in place to prop up the central character, even better-suited actresses would be hard-pressed to transcend this material. Sharon Stone, as the villain, here lacks the charisma she brought to "Basic Instinct," "Total Recall," or even episodes of "The Practice." Benjamin Bratt ends up almost as anonymous as the rest of the supporting characters. And the only thing director Pitof brings to the table with semblance a comic book is his name.Successful comic books achieve the illusion of fluidity from panel to panel. In "Catwoman" the effect is the exact opposite: The movie always feels oddly static, as if entire scenes are stuck in singular panels. Fittingly enough, "Catwoman" never seems intended to be anything more than the movie equivalent of a Maxim magazine photo spread. And the costume itself reflects this entirely: Ill-suited for fighting, and made to fall off during a pillow fight at a soft-core slumber party.

reviews.review_title: It was a fun, stylishly sexy film about a woman, who finds out there's more fun and adventure with nine lives.
reviews.content: Catwoman shouldn't be seen as a feminist movie, but as a fun film about a woman, who finds that she's more than she thought she was. The visuals were good and so was the acting. I came to the theater with no expectation and enjoyed it because of that. It's not a deep movie and it isn't trying to be. Cat lovers Enjoy! Dog Lovers, I think you'll like this movie as well. Halle is one sexy kitten and brings a fresh feel to the character of Catwoman. She does seem to borrow certain mannerisms from past actors who played Catwoman, but she also shows that she was up to the challenge and comes across with a solid performance. The camera work was a bit over done and most of the time you could tell of the computer generated images of Catwoman doing her cat like moves. Even certain fight scenes seemed a bit awkward at times. Sharon's Stone's performance could have been better, but she was playing a vengeful, ex-model, who was being tossed aside for a younger beauty. How deep can you go when your playing a shallow character to begin with?

reviews.review_title: what was Halle Berry and Warner Bros. thinking?!
reviews.content: I know, I know, almost NO ONE liked this movie. It's completely understandable why.I can get over the fact that this is not the Catwoman we know and love from the Batman series (Selina Kyle) this is a new entity. Patience has superhuman abilities, cat-like reflexes, blah, blah, blah, where as Selina is more or less a human being. But this movie just sucks. There's no way around it.First, there's the costume. The initial "night out" where Patience wears the full leather suit with just the little mask over her eyes, THAT would have been fine. But then she puts on the ridiculous outfit she wears throughout the rest of the movie. High heels that would give anyone wearing them for more than ten minutes blisters the size of pancakes, basically a leather bra that any adversary could open by cutting the tiny string holding it together in the middle, and to top it all off a huge, pointed-ears helmet thing that is just plain lame. Whoever was in charge of costumes should be publically shot. Anyone who took it upon themselves to fight crime would never wear anything like that, it's just nonsense. Not to mention the fact that they never show her fashioning this hideous thing. She just sort of shows up in it.Second is the directing. Pitof should be shot along with the costume designer. Every shot flies by your face before you can see what's going on, and the performances from very capable actors and actresses fell flat -- the job of the director is to coax good performances from his/her actors. I'm wondering if Pitof was even present for filming. An intern could have done a better job with the direction.Third are the fight scenes. I didn't go into this film expecting much, but at the very least I expected decent fight scenes, especially considering all the hype about how the used capoiera and all that. I don't think Halle Berry did a single fight scene herself. Everything was CGI, a fact that left me disappointed after Spider Man as well. I want to see the actor WORK for their millions of dollars, is that so much to ask? Disappointing fight scenes.Fourth, the script. Was there a script? Was there a screenwriter? If so, he/she should be shot as well. We know it's a movie about a catwoman, but does she really need to say "purrrfect"? Come on now. And then asking a question and before the guy can answer grabbing his tongue and saying "cat got your tongue?" Please!I urge you, do not see this movie. If you do, you will be severely disappointed by some tried and true actors. Why is it that whenever an actress wins an Oscar she has to go on and do a HORRIBLE action movie?!The only thing that was slightly interesting was the whole "Catwoman Legacy" about past women who have inherited the helm and gone on the fight crime, save the world, etc. A nice touch, but the movie is as a whole unwatchable and I really hope Halle does something a little better in her next film.

Having read many horrendous "reviews" of Catwoman, I felt obliged to judge the movie from an objective viewpoint, if such a view was possible given all the negativity it engendered from sniping critics.After watching Catwoman I was pleasantly surprised that it wasn't as bad as critics said it was. The film isn't brilliant or as inspired as the first Spider-man in terms of digital effects and storytelling, but it holds it own, during its best scenes as a distinctively feminine/feline action film. Using the duality between passivity and aggression for Berry's character, Patience Phillips, and her feline alter-ego, Catwoman, was a shrewd move that invested the story with a moral ambiguity but the film itself is too shallow to properly explore what it sets up as Catwoman's conflicting inner core. Berry plays the docile Patience Phillips with a fragility only she could do; while her sexuality, which so many critics derided as non-existent, is brought to the fore with her highly seductive Catwoman in S&M attire. Rather than play Catwoman as solely as campy cartoon character, Berry exudes a typically feline sexuality - wily, sometimes amoral and vivacious. Moreover, she underscores her Catwoman voice with a gentle but suggestive cat-like intensity that is both alluring and slightly vampire-like in its soft undertone. I think it was very unfair that she was maligned by critics for this role. She was clearly an inspired choice - as was Sharon Stone, who plays Catwoman's nemesis but she isn't used enough in the final cut of the film. The deleted scenes on the DVD reveals more scenes with Stone and it's a pity she wasn't given more screen time. In the scenes she has, Stone is back in fine camp form playing a faded model-wife of the owner of a corrupt cosmetics company, played in a wonderfully camp performance by French actor Lambert Wilson. Wilson, it is fair to say, has the best lines, especially in his taut exchanges with his unhinged wife and his model mistress. Stone's delivery is self-consciously "wooden" in a good way. She probably knew the limitations of the script but she uses the somewhat wooden nature of her lines as a pastiche of the genre itself. Stone provides a striking counterpoint to Catwoman; she's a post-feminist villain whose vanity is as much a crime as her murderous deeds. Many have said the effects are not as sophisticated as recent films. In some night scenes Catwoman's exaggerated movements are very cartoon-like - yet this criticism could also be leveled at Spider-man 1 and 2, where it is fairly obvious digital effects are at hand. In this sense, it seems unjust to criticize the effects in Catwoman as being out-dated. Some fight scenes have a wonderful intensity, and thankfully the film avoids slow-motion Matrix-style acrobatics. The final "bitch" fight is certainly worth the wait for fans of Dynastyesque cat fights.What doesn't work? Benjamin Bratt as the romantic lead is awful. He has zero charisma and his scenes with Berry are embarrassingly bad, especially the scene playing basketball and in the fairground. Had these awful scenes been deleted I think Catwoman would have been a better film. Pitof - go back to the editing room now.Sadly there won't be a sequel even if the film's climax suggests that was the intention. I hope this film becomes a cult classic. Catwoman- Resurrection here we come....or perhaps the director's cut minus Bratt.

reviews.review_title: Batman & Robin doesn't look so bad eh?
reviews.content: Honestly, I had to watch this because I am a fan of Batman. But seriously, this movie is terrible. It spat in the face of the real character created by DC comics and it's a shame for the world of superheroes. First of all, the special effects are awful, there's no way that the real Catwoman makes all those climbs and jumps exactly like Spider-man does. And by the way, the references to the spider-man movies are obvious and though it is a totally different character from another comic book. WHY??? Secondly, the acting is terrible. Not only Halle Berry, but for me the guy who plays the cop is the worst. I don't remember so far having seen a single emotion on his face and he just doesn't look like a real cop on the first look. So overall I could bring so many bad things about this movie but I'm just gonna say that the plot is just uninteresting and the story boring. There you go, that's my review.

reviews.review_title: OK it's not horrible but in no way is it great either......
reviews.content: and that is what you get when you watch Catwoman. Personally, I don't really care that this movie is not based on the original Selina Kyle character, because I never knew much about her anyway. So big deal, though I can understand why fan boys will be upset. so why not something different? Well firstly, let's cut to the chase. Who cares if Catwoman is not white! Halle Berry is a fine actress and deserved a chance to play Catwoman. However, in terms of her performance in this movie, her acting gets a bit sloppy when she is in the catwoman suit. Her character becomes this over the top sexy woman who cracks the whip too many times and who is given a laughable script and plot line to lead this movie.Yes, my main problem with this movie is how silly the plot is. Halle Berry plays Patience Phillips (how they hell they come up with an absurd name such as Patience is anyone's guess) who is a shy, timid woman who works in a company that makes beauty products. When she overhears a secret in a new product called Beau Line and that if you use it, your face will deteriorate unless you keep using it, she is killed, then resurrected by some CGI cat, which is very obviously CGI. Now she has superpowers such as leaping from building to building, walking up walls like a cat and very clear vision.**********MINOR SPOILER*************** OK, the villain in this movie, Laurel Hadare (Sharon Stone). I don't have a problem with Sharon Stone, but for one thing, she doesn't really have a superpower that can match Catwoman's abilities. Her ridiculous strength is having a face like stone because she has used that beau line product for years. Hence she can't feel pain. Ha ha ha ha ha. When she says the line in the movie in the climatic fight 'skin like living marble...and you can't feel a thing!' it is just plain ridiculous. And Catwoman is knocking the crap out of her and hitting not just her face but her legs and everything. I mean did Laurel apply the cream on her whole body as well? How come she can't feel pain in those other areas? It is really that absurd.The editing in this movie is overdone. One of Catwoman's fight scenes with a guy outside a night club has probably over 40 images edited together so you can't follow the action properly. What's more, the action scenes are totally devoid of suspense or good choreography that it feels more like they made it up on the spot.The soundtrack of the film is alright. I did like how they used the music but at other times the film feels more like a music video sometimes. The best scene is where Catwoman is walking and the camera slowly reveals her in her costume to the song 'whose in Control?' Benjamin Bratt who plays the cop and love interest seems a bit wooden and flat, and there doesn't seem to be a spark between him and Halle. I think they could have picked someone a bit better.The character development of Catwoman is also not done very well because Patience seems to accept her being Catwoman very quickly before really coming to turns with her new identity. At times, it almost feels like she has a personality disorder and can't control who she is.So this movie does have some fun moments and you really have to turn your brain off to enjoy this movie, otherwise you will just see how stupid the plot, script and in particular some of the lines given from Halle Berry are. It should have been a really more in depth movie.What we know is that Patience is not the only Catwoman out there. She is in a line of previous women who were once catwomen, thus if a sequel had been made, she could possibly have met up with one of the other catwomen and teamed up or something. But that is never going to happen since they didn't do a good job with this one. Oh well, nice try guys.This isn't the worst movie ever, there are so much worse. I think this was harshly criticised but it makes sense when you think about it. If you're going to take a character well known such as Catwoman on a $100 million budget and not do much with it that is unique or groundbreaking, then why bother? Halle Berry really should have thought about this before she took on the role. And she does try her best, but since she is trying to be both good and bad in terms of the nature of her character, we don't really see the bad side.To the writers - for your next movie, please please do not make it about face cream whatever you do!

reviews.review_title: Allow me to be the dissenting voice
reviews.content: I watched this movie on cable, having been warned out of the theater by critics and media hype.Piffle! I have been led astray again. This is a perfectly enjoyable piece of fluff. Halle is charming and the cat-like animation of her movements is pleasing. Sharon Stone is a hoot as the villainess, and it is a joy to see Frances Conroy moving to the big screen. And what is not to enjoy about Benjamin Bratt with his shirt off?The script is as full-bodied as one can expect from what is a supporting character to Batman in the comics. We are not expecting a Shakespeare epic here, it is a graphic novel for the screen.Lighten up, and have some fun watching this.

Catwoman is yet another comic-book based movie... In traditional comic-book movie style - it focuses on the "origin" of Catwoman (Halle Berry) who is out for "justice" against her former employer - Sharon Stone.This movie is trashy, campy and not overly-deep. In what could have been deep material - a vigilante who is, in the eyes of many, a criminal... ends up being a relatively naft affair.The acting is lazy, the fight scenes look really bad (I hate fake looking CGI), the plot isn't very engaging.This movie is definitely on the lower end of the scale when it comes to Superhero movies. .

reviews.review_title: Not Good, but not THAT bad
reviews.content: Picked this up as a cheap DVD despite having read negative comments.Certainly not good, but not as bad as the rating suggests. Come on folks, there's a lot worse than this around. It's good in parts but it doesn't hang together at all. Basically it's let down by a poor script.A film such as this was always going to require a high profile star in the lead role and they don't come much more high profile than Halle. Sharon Stone does a decent job with her role, although she is capable of performing at a significantly higher level than was required here. Likewise Halle who with the right role is one of the finest actresses around.Catwoman also needed to be an attractive, sexy person who "looked the part". For this reason alone there was no better actress to undertake the role than Halle. She is one of the most beautiful actresses ever and would look good in a bin-bag, never mind the Catwoman outfit.Both Halle and Sharon seem to have fun in their respective roles and they dominate the screen whenever they appear. The rest of the cast seem overwhelmed by them.A fun movie which could and should have been better. It's saving grace is Halle and without her it would have been a real turkey.Certainly worth a look.

Finally got round to watching Catwoman an adaption I am unfamiliar with as I mainly known the Selina Kyle version from the much beloved Batman mythology. My expectations were low as I already knew of the bad publicity this film received during its release. Not all is bad here still there is plenty of room for improvement. I don't think the material is overly great for the actors to work with at the time yet it's probably more relevant nowadays in comparison. Many women do in fact have cosmetic surgical adjustment more than ever in todays times highlighting their insecurities and removing age lines. The point story is very one dimensional though coming off more like a romantic comedy than a fully devoted comic book adaption. Halle Berry isn't to blame for what i see as a poor depiction of Catwoman; the character development is poor here. There isn't a whole lot of obstacles for our main protagonist to have a reason for being Catwoman she just more or less stumbles upon it! By chance she comes across information she shouldn't have and bingo, through no fault of her own she is in danger. I don't think any of the actors were bad however with the material they were working with it is really hard to sell this concept. It appeared to be a movie that didn't know quite what it was. Do we go dark? Should she have a love interest? Or shall we go full on chick flick with this? Nobody seemed to fully invest into one idea so it became a movie that just didn't seem to work. Even the antagonists weren't fully rounded or developed characters.

reviews.review_title: Much, Much Better than I expected
reviews.content:
Halle really pulled it off.  Catwoman is super sexy and the action scenes are just plain cool.
The advance buzz for this movie was awful but Catwoman rocks.I think the people who gave it the low vote haven't even seen the movie yet. I just saw it in San Francisco and everyone in the audience was cheering.If you believe the negative buzz, you'll miss a very cool action movie with a totally different theme.Besides, seeing Halle in the leather suit is almost worth the price of admission.Rrrrrrrrow!

I always liked the idea of a Catwoman movie, she was always one of the most intriguing villains in the Batman universe and the fact that a brilliant actress such as Halle Berry was involved told me that I would love this movie. That was nearly three years ago, since that time I have seen this movie three times, and each of those three times I have unfortunately been left feeling cheated after seeing it. You see the movie Catwoman basically takes the character of Catwoman that I loved, dumps her into a bizarrely ridiculous universe revolving around make-up, gives her one of the most ludicrous costumes to date, and to top it all off just ruins every likable aspect of her character. So what's so bad about it? The action? The performances? The story? Well if I'm honest I'm not sure, the action has its moments despite hardly being amazing, the performances range from half decent from Halle Berry to stupid, Lambert Wilson, to just the plain horrifically ludicrously nasty performance by Sharon Stone. The story could have worked I suppose if given the proper treatment, even though the story about the main villain being evil because she isn't the front page girl anymore just never could work. No the biggest problem is the the fact that the script and direction basically mutilates this movie. This might have scraped mediocre had the camera bothered to stay still for two seconds and the dialogue been devoid of some of the worst clunkers in cinema history! Catwoman herself is a great character, and thankfully Halle Berry manages to make a terrible script not sound awful. Why she received the Razzie for Worst Actress is beyond me as she really does still have moments to shine. After she gets past the pathetic whimpering girl stage early on in the movie and gets serious she works very well. Of course her romance with Benjamin Bratt's policeman could never work, the pair have no chemistry and Bratt seemingly the charisma of a gnat. In fact the scenes where them two do a weird basketball sequence doesn't fell sexy as its meant to, in fact it just feels odd and misplaced. Sharon Stone clearly makes the biggest career mistake of her life in this movie though. Her character to be frank shouldn't exist in the first place, but just her performance itself is awful. I can't comment on her any more as she really is that hate-able in the movie.Catwoman isn't the worst movie in the world, and the action does manage to make the movie rise a teeny bit above one of the worst movies I've ever seen. But the fact that no real effort has been placed into it just annoys me to the extreme. I would watch a Catwoman 2 on three conditions, Halle Very is back, the director and scriptwriter are fired, Sharon Stone swears that she will never act again, especially in a superhero movie. Then I'd consider watching a sequel, but since this was globally despised I really doubt I'd ever have to endure one anyway. So if you wanted to see this, take my advice don't, go watch Batman Returns instead.

reviews.review_title: Was it serious, or a parody?
reviews.content: I am still not sure.As a straight-up, comic book adaptation, it is not great. As a parody of this type of movie it is very funny.A shy girl gets breathed on by a mystical, ancient Egyptian cat, thereby raising her from the dead. She then battles an evil corporation, marketing killer face-cream.The Hero is the least observant Police Detective ever. I am sure that anyone, having the major hots for someone, would recognise them leathered-up and masked. Personally this would open up all kinds of fun possibilities :-). Contrast this with the scene in 'Mystery men' where William H Macy's character states that Captain Amazing and Lance Hunt must be different people because Lance Hunt wears Spectacles.This is the level at which Catwoman must be enjoyed, because the alternative is too horrible to comprehend.

There have been many movies made from comic books lately. Some good (Road to Perdition, Spiderman, The Hulk and some of the Batman flicks). Some bad (Daredevil and some of the Batman flicks). Where these movies succeed is in there simplicity and straightforwardness in its storytelling. Where they fail is found in their excess. Catwoman is a failure because they took a good actor(Benjiman Bratt, Alex Borstein, Frances Conroy) and paired them with gorgeous but lukewarm talent like Halle Berry and Sharon Stone. Couple these casting faults with an overuse of CGI tricks, gaudy set design and cutesy music video moments and you have this movie. The plot line put forth by Ms. Conroy's character should have been the focus of the movie instead of putting so emphasis on the damned costume and the overbearing soundtrack and violence. Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed watching Ms. Berry and Ms. Stone having their cat-fight but I think that the audience is smart enough to have had a little "story" thrown their way. It's a crying shame that so much money and time was wasted for so little return.

reviews.review_title: OH COME ON! IT WASN'T THAT BAD!
reviews.content: (Please note this review may contain spoilers)OH COME ON! IT Wasn't THAT BAD! Okay, this movie could have been a lot better, but a place in the bottom 100? Its not that bad!Halle Berry as Catwoman will not please most Batman and Catwoman fans, and the only thing that really annoyed me about this film was that it didn't stick to the original Storyline. Another annoying thing about this film was Catwoman's costume, which is unfaithful to the comics. AND ITS NOT EVEN BASED IN GOTHAM! And giving her the Name of Patience Phillips was another bad idea, IN THE COMICS SHE WAS CALLED SELINA KYLE! STICK TO THE ORIGINAL IDEA!But despite its flaws, Catwoman is a very entertaining, and nearly satisfying film, Halle Berry, as I said before, may not please comic fans, but she does a very good job in my book, as the sly, seductive, Catwoman.Verdict: Very entertaining, despite its flaws.7.5/10

I think Michelle Pfeiffer played a better Catwoman. The big problem with this movie is its goal of emphasizing how supposedly sexy Halle Berry is. Michelle did it cooler, more subtle. She didn't go into its making, thinking, "Ok, I have got to put on a show for the world just how amazingly sexy I am." Halle's a pretty girl but doesn't strike me as exceptionally "sexy". Especially at the end of this one, with the way she walks away and cracks her whip, I think the movie got carried away with the whole "sexy" thing.

I really had a hard time sitting through this one. Watching a movie when knowing its going to be terrible becomes much harder to do when the evidence is spitting corny dialog and scratching away at you from a leather-clad dominatrix costume. Trust me, it IS as bad as people have made it out to be. The plot is ridiculously too simple, the cgi takes over every single action scene, there are no twists, there is nothing to look forward to throughout the whole movie with the exception of wondering what "special" power the skin cream has given Sharon Stone. Then we come to discover she has skin, and this is quoted from the movie, "like living marble". Of course she doesn't go fantastic four and turn into a she-thing or anything like that. Not really sure if that would have helped though it might have been more entertaining. This movie offers nothing worthy of writing more then a paragraph or two about. Nothing works out the way it was supposed to come across and the CGI hurts more then it helps with it killing any possible realism this movie could have envisioned. In closing, I have a couple of "nevers" I'd like to express. Never entrust an entire movie to CGI. Never entrust an entire plot to Hollywood. Never entrust Halle over Michelle.
A disaster from the beginning to the end. Watch it just to have a good laugh with your friends. One of the worst films of the 21st century.

reviews.review_title: It's so beautiful to look at, just turn off the music :)

The idea of how Catwoman came to be should turn out a good viewing, but how was I wrong! The entire film unfolds as a lengthy music video clip for the choreographed fight scenes with many obvious CGI plans, interspersed with some dramatic takes so it can be called 'a movie'. It is especially the synonymous of 'style over substance', ideal for futile women - who are certainly the target audience of this product. Halle Berry's portrayal of Patience Phillips is acceptable, but as Catwoman she looks more like a ho than a respectable BD character - one can be sexy without being that, as Michelle Pfeiffer.

Movies like "Catwoman" are the reason why I'm sad "Mystery Science Theater 3000" no longer airs. This is the type of material that begs to be talked back to--misguided at its best, and utterly laughable at its worst. I almost wish there were more of it--say, for example, a scene in which Patience Phillips (Halle Berry), the newborn Catwoman, comes up with her costume. A scene which justifies the existence of the ripped leather pants, S&M bra, bullwhip, and mask would almost have to be as delightfully ridiculous as the outfit itself. But hey, there's still plenty of silliness to go around.This is what comic-book experts call an "origin story," so we first meet Patience before she starts getting into leather and whips--a quiet graphic artist whose cubicle is flanked by a sex-obsessed friend and a man who's the most over-the-top gay caricature since Jack on "Will and Grace." Director Pitof (isn't that a rice dish?) dresses Berry in baggy clothes and long curly hair in an attempt to convince us that one of the great natural beauties of the screen is a mousy wallflower, and has her working for that good-old standby villain, the Unethical Corporation. How do we know it's unethical? Because her boss (Lambert Wilson) speaks with a condescending British accent, and is accompanied by a shrewish wife (Sharon Stone). And indeed, it isn't long before Patience overhears the news that her cosmetics company's new anti-aging cream causes illness and scarring but (gasp!) they're going to put it on the shelves anyway, despite the protests of the resident lab rat who declares he can't support a product that turns women into "monsters." (I think he's overreacting; the woman in his file looks no worse than the "before" picture in an average dermatology clinic ad.) Patience is drowned to ensure her silence, but she washes up on shore where a bunch of fake-looking CGI cats crowd around her, and one breathes on her, causing her to open her eyes. That's cat-food breath for you--enough to wake the dead.Sentient moviegoers will note distinct similarities between this scene and the origin of Catwoman in "Batman Returns"--and indeed, much of what follows has been cribbed from other, better comic book movies. Patience discovering her new cat-like abilities, crouching and twitching her head like a road-company Rumpleteaser and downing sushi at an alarming rate. The random thugs who get beat up by the new costumed vigilante, accompanied by R&B ululations that sound as if Mariah Carey has stubbed her toe. The woman who explains that Patience is now the latest in a long line of catwomen, accompanied by some badly touched-up pictures of women in cat masks. The love interest who complicates the protagonists double life--in this case, a cop blandly played by Benjamin Bratt. All of this could have been fun on its own terms--guilty pleasure fun, yes, but fun nevertheless. But Pitof doesn't know how to put it all together in an exciting or involving manner. Scenes feel like they're shot and edited at random, with the camera refusing to linger anywhere for more than a few seconds. I have no problems with quick cuts in the right place, but Pitof doesn't know how to use them effectively--a quiet scene between Patience and her friend (who's been hospitalized thanks to the Unethical Corporation's latest product) features the same frenetic cuts as the earlier fight scenes. Berry, bless her heart, tries to do what she can, but she's overwhelmed by the paint-by-numbers script and clumsy direction.There's more, of course, much more. But three scenes in particular stand out in my mind: 1) During a date between Berry and Bratt's characters, it starts to rain, and Berry dashes for cover--her cat side, of course, doesn't want to get wet. This begs the question: how is she keeping clean now? Does she still use the shower? The thought of Berry washing herself as felines do is one I prefer not to think about in great detail. 2) While trying to find her "killers," Patience confronts Wilson's character--not in an empty office or deserted alley, but in a crowded theater featuring some sort of Cirque du Soleil-ballet hybrid. The police show up, and a chase scene ensues backstage--all while the performance continues. If there was a potentially dangerous criminal in the theater, don't you think the cops would stop the show? 3) Later on,Patience is imprisoned (for a crime she didn't commit, of course), but this doesn't stop her--she uses her cat-like flexibility to slide in between the bars of her cell. Mystic powers or no mystic powers--unless cats have the ability to shrink their skulls, this should be impossible.

reviews.review_title: It's a bad movie, but not the train wreck I was expecting... or hoping for.
reviews.content: I remember way back when Batman Returns was released, that warner bros. was planning to make a catwoman spin-off movie. This was back in 1992, when the "Batman" franchise was still going very strong. In 2004, a good 12 years later, and a good 6 or seven years after the franchise was demolished by Joel Schumaker, the people got their catwoman movie, and most of them shouted "what the...?" As most of you know, Halle Berry plays Patience Phillips, a very shy mousy woman who works at some cosmetics company in an unnamed city. About 10-15 minutes into the movie, she gets bumped off, gets CPR from a cat, gets cat-like powers and turns into Catwoman. Is she a hero, or is she a criminal, yadda, yadda, yadda...we get the idea.I'll get to the first order of business: the acting. Fairly over-the-top, but not gut-wrenchingly awful. Halle did do a decent job, but I (like many other movie fans) would wonder why she would so something like this just after winning an Oscar. Friends of mine speculated that she turned into a prima donna and started demanding movies where she gets top billing and dominant screen time, which makes sense, but something tells me that she was so hungry for it that she didn't exactly take the time to read the script.Next thing: the visuals. First of all, they spent over $100 million on special effects, and it shows. All the swooping shots of "the city" really looked CGI, not to mention all the parts where catwoman jumps around. They're trying to pull an "agent smith" and try to make every Catwoman moment look badass. Sorry, guys, but I'm just not convinced. Also, the constant scene cuts (I estimated about 3-4 cuts per second) are very confusing, if not disorienting.Now I come to my biggest gripe: the COMPLETE and utter LACK OF REGARD for the SOURCE MATERIAL! Many comic book fans (along with some lay people) know that Catwoman is a DC comics character, a very significant member of Batman's rogues gallery. In the comic, her name is Selina Kyle, an orphan who was once a hooker but turned to burglary instead. She hasn't given up on crime completely, but most of the time she works with Batman towards a common good. She has no super-powers, save for an amazing natural athletic and gymnastic ability. I guess the studio execs, however, didn't think this was flashy enough to get as many people into their seats as possible. So instead, they decide to make her have cat-like powers handed down to her from a mystical cat-god. When I finally heard about this, I, and many other comic fans were less than happy. We felt that this would not only be a box office failure, but it would hurt the chances of resurrecting the Batman franchise. The movie did fail miserably, but hopefully, there is "Batman Begins" which will be released this coming June, maybe warner will begin making halfway decent DC comics adaptations again.Over the past couple of years, we've seen some really good movies in general and some kick-ass comic book movies in particular. Unfortunately, for every movie like "Spider-Man 2" and "X2: X-Men United" there comes crap like "Catwoman" to feed the masses who don't know any better. Some people actually like that, and more power to them. I'm just glad that movies like these are the exception, rather than the norm.

reviews.review_title: I would've voted lower if I could have.
reviews.content: This movie along with it's first theatrical trailer was a blatant rip-off of the original Crow trailer, almost verbatim. "Sometimes, when you a cat will bring you back from the dead." This movie was a disaster. Single handedly this film has ruined the Catwoman character for movies. Because of this horrid piece of film, we will never see a good Catwoman movie. Which is a shame. This film was a prime example of a studio pumping out a comic book movie in order to try to rake in some of the comic movie cash that recent films have made. It was an attempt to make some profit without any thought to film quality.It is expected for comic films to change a bit of the context from the books. However, the character's style and arch-type was thrown away in order to make some quick cash. Unlike the silent cat-bugler of the comics, this Catwoman is a dark vigilante out for revenge... Revenge on...and evil make-up executive! WTF?!

Catwoman is ridiculous and is definitely picked up by the crap o meter but to say it's in what i call the crap o meter's biggest piles (or my worst movies list) is rather harsh.Yes the action is cheesy and yes the storyline is unbelievably ridiculous but the acting is not at all bad and it's definitely fun.I believe Catwoman was targeted at the wrong audience and is something younger girls would like.The style of the film is very urban and hip hop like from the surroundings to the soundtrack giving me the impression that they want to attract teenagers.Catwoman is better for 10 year olds because it's fun and entertaining but horribly lame and pretentious.Halle Berry did a great job as Catwoman however the costumes,the storyline,and the karate fights are all unbearable to anyone over 16.The one woman who informs Halle of her cat powers is a goofy character who acts like some gypsy from the House Of Wax.A lot of cheesiness is in catwoman like when she's resurrected and when she plays basketball.Definitely aimed at the teen market and definitely a good attempt but sadly Halle Berry's Catwoman is so deep into the crap o meter it's never going to get out.

For comic book purists who worship at the altar of continuity, Catwoman will probably come across as a nightmare. However, I'd heard about the reworking of the character before seeing the movie and went in with low expectations.
I must say I was pleasantly surprised. While Selina Kyle, Batman and other Gothamites are nowhere to be found, if you take this movie as what it's intended to be, Catwoman re-imagined, then you should enjoy it as much as I did.I think the composite rating for this film is waaaay too harsh. Enjoyable popcorn fare. 7 of 10.

Yes, its a bad movie. But by what standards? Blade? Daredevil? Batman and Robin? On second thought, maybe it wasn't as bad as I thought. It didn't matter anyway, because Halle Berry was a "10" in that costume and Sharon Stone's sex appeal was off the charts. After you get used to Pitof's cheesy, fake directing and the horribly insignificant story and characterizations, its fun to watch Halle and Sharon heat it up. Their cat fight at the end was worth waiting for.What Halle Berry lacks in talent, she makes up for in charisma and screen presence. She is smokin' even before she turns into a bronze goddess Catwoman, and then she's on fire. As for Sharon Stone, she looks like she can bring a man (or a woman) to their knees just by looking at them. Two out of four paws for this movie.

If they would just change this bad script into a comedy this would be a great movie. There were two movies that I can think of that destroyed comic book heroes. One was Captain America and another one is this Catwoman. Bravo! Another history in the making.The acting for Halle Berry is the worst acting I have ever seen. This show-off style she would be a shoe-in playing the dominating wife controlling Tommy Lee Jones.As a cat, while she did display many characteristic of a cat, a cat does not overact like Jim Carrey. It does things when it has to do it, quietly an unassuming and when you least expect it, whether it be going on a sofa, etc.Now this Catwoman does things unnecessary or over-exaggerates the traits of a cat. Also cats are associated with the darker side of things, more like quiet and secretiveness in the same spirit as Spiderman, instead of a show.Apparently it is understandable that catwoman tries to emulate the Catwoman played by Michelle Pfieffer from Batman Returns. However, the original Catwoman did a beautiful job in that she displayed the dark secretive hidden side of the cat. It was extremely memorable when catwoman secretly scratched the stomach of Batman without him knowing. This is the likes of the true Catwoman, secret, hidden, dark and putting you in fear.Now Halle Berry very similar to Madonna, as Michelle Pfieffer to Marilyn Monroe (almost). One is boastful and brass, the other is secretive and dark. The sadistic side of a cat is more sinister rather than boastful. For a cat the latter trait is much more desirable.Take for instance when someone called Catwoman and she starts pouncing on the sofa - the single worst mistake ever. Take her jumping from building to building, it looks like giant cockroaches jumping over buildings - and in my lifetimes, I am an authority on cockroach movement. Cats are graceful, not hippity hoppity cockroaches.People need to be convinced that Halle Berry IS the catwoman, not be forced fed down the throat that she is catwoman. O.K. some total idiot with an I.Q. of 2 1/2 might not think so. But for people like us whose average I.Q. is near Moron watching this toilet flushing movie, that is going way over the hill.Now, mind you I am sure Halle Berry will do A GREAT job as catwoman. There is no doubt about it, the hitch is that she should be at least 80 years old to do it. At that time she might learn the subtleties of being at Catwoman.As to the director of Catwoman, I don't he ever did watch Batman returns. One sheer quality that this movie totally miss is the deceptiveness of being a cat. There's nothing deceptiveness about this ego-trip Cat! I mean is there any differences in the personalities of Catwoman and those of the movie The Chronicles of Riddick. I am sure Halle Berry will do a great job doing a screen play as a Vin Diesel replacement. In fact, may I dare say, Vin Diesel looks fit to cast the role as Catwoman (after the silicone breast implants off course).Some people thing we critics are not constructive. Well here is the constructive side: Catwoman should be on the darker sinister side. Hidden from the true depths with deep inhumane emotion. Deep and uncaring. Exploring the dark side can really helped this comedy blockbuster - oh did I say comedy? I mean, unintended comedy.Great Movie I give it 2/10

And enjoyed it tremendously!I really enjoyed the bits when Patience is bewildered then delighted by her feline abilities. Halle's expressions at each new experience are wonderful to behold! The supporting characters are fun, the villains suitably villainous...a fine tribute to Bob Kane's jewel-thief but not all bad Catwoman. Check your brain at the door and enjoy!

...that it is just bad.A star celebration for Barre's body in a leather catsuit... no acting ability required and nothing worth mentioning delivered. Writing poor, humor not even up to sophomoric levels. Cinematography amateurish. Special effect poor by even 20 year old standards. Plot non existent. Directing apparently done by an overly hormonal teen male. High point(if there is one)...Barre looks good in the catsuit.Free on Netflix and still way over priced.

The Summary is not about the movie because of course I understood it (pretty easy plot to follow) No, what I didn't understand was why this movie ends up with a 3 out of 10 note. Which makes this movie one of the lowest rated comics to movies flick over the last twenty years. The grade is even lower than Batman and Robin. To be frank I was more than reluctant to see this movie in the first place. When it hit the theater it was definitely on my movies-to-skip list. And I don't actually pay to see movies in the theater so that gives you a pretty good idea of what my opinion of the film was back then. A year or so have passed since it's release and having seen all the movie at my video store I decided to give it a shot (I don't pay for rental either so it was really a matter of waste of time) I throw the disc in my DVD player and launch the Title 01 of the DVD (this way you skip all the annoying animated menus and other previews that some DVD company includes in the rentals)The beginning credit is a real bore so I fast forward my way to the actual start. Here it goes, it's pretty nice, some nice effects and camera angles. Good introduction to character somewhat cheesy nonetheless. Everything looks good so far not boring a good general pace. I'm actually surprised by the general looks of the film, having seen Vidocq I expected another Digital Effect Vomit but I guess the technology advanced really fast in the last three or so years. Because it's looks pretty real to me. Then we get to the drowning scene. The following shot feature Berry on some kind of Island surrounded by cats. Which was very lame. Because there's no way a cat or any number of them for that matter would drag a dead body out of the water, and it's kinda stupid to have CGIed the cat that's on Berry. However that lame scene apart the general tone of the movie was very good. The most important of all it was not boring at all. So except for a couple of CGI overuse and some cheesy line I just don't get why this movie got a rating that low. Because as I said before I don't pay for movies and rentals so lemme tell you I watch a lot of them (1 to 5 a day, being insomniac and sleeping three hours a day helps too)And it's one of the best I've seen so far. It's no Tim Burton's Batman or Bryan Singer's X-Men but it's way better than Spider-Man 2 who's actually number 244 out of the IMDb Top 250. And apart from a couple of good action sequence Spider-Man 2 is all about endless pathos scenes, pseudo right or wrong philosophy and cheesy love story about two actors that overplay those moments with the "I-Want-To-Be-Nominated-To-The-Oscars" spark in their respective eyes.So I just don't get people bitching about this movie when the Director actually tries to make things a little different and use the latest technology in order to bring this comic character to life. He did some stuff wrong but the biggest part is done right. There has been so many movies in the last 5 years that came from Comics characters and nine tenth of those movie were really poor. So why picking on this one when so much worse has been done. Daredevil, Hulk, The Punisher to name a few. So if you like action movies, with nice fighting sequences, sexy characters, and beyond laws of physics action. Then this movie is for you . Don't listen to the bad reviews this movie had because most of them are just gratuitous bitching from people who either are racist (Unfortunatly those people exist and bitch about everything with black or Hispanic actors in) or those people just don't like this genre of movie so they cannot be objective about reviewing this movie.

reviews.review_title: Not the Catwoman that comic book fans know, but I think that it was all right for what it was.
reviews.content: I can recall seeing this when I was at the Drive-in a few years ago, and I was surprised that it was panned as much as it was. I actually liked it. I recall people saying that this Catwoman made no sense because of the origin presented. Personally, I think the origin story here made more sense than the one in Batman Returns or even in The Dark Knight Rises. Think about it. Selina Kyle in Returns and the Phillips character in this film were both found by cats after being thrown off of high distances and survive an attempt to murder them. Returns showed Kyle going completely ballistic afterwards and taking on the characteristics of a cat because of her abuse from her employer and her downtrodden life. This abuse and unhappy life was another thing that each character had in common with each other. Phillips herself became Catwoman because of an experience with more supernatural implications, which I found a bit more concrete even if I did not agree with the notion of Egyptian Deities. With Rises, Selina Kyle was shown to be a thief, albeit with natural ability to fight, but with little back-story, except for the fact that it was seen early on that she despised those that were wealthy and blamed them for the troubles of the World (whether individually or as a whole) who, too, decided to "fight back" by taking on the persona of a cat. When it comes to Returns and Rises, the question must be asked as to how does Kyle in either of those two films acquire her agility and athletic prowess? At least this version of Catwoman gave a reason for it. It may have disappointed those that were expecting a Catwoman movie based more on the comic book character, which would have been fine, but what I would have expected even from that is a further explanation as to why Kyle would become Catwoman in the first place, and not just what was presented in Batman Returns. There would have to be more substance to this matter.

reviews.review_title: More big budget dreck from our friends in California
reviews.content:
Nice to look at, probably real nice to hold . . . but "Monsters Ball' notwithstanding, this decades over-rated eye candy, Halle Berry cannot act to save her life.
